111231.content:
Lena takes a deep breath and sits down in her chair behind her desk. She had just had a heated debate with the city council as well as the president on the legality on creating a brand new city for Minizora’s to live in. The argument and went on for a couple of hours with heaps of concerns raised. Where was this going to be built, how will it work and why would this need to happen when Minizora’s and others live side by side as it is with no real concern. Lena explained to them that because of all the invasions and fights happening in the city now that aliens are living among them Mizizora’s are more likely to be killed in a crisis and the numbers show that. Police keep track of the deaths whenever a war or attack happens and Minizora’s out number the others.

“Everything okay Lena?” A voice calls.

Lena looks up and sees Kara standing on her desk with a concerned look on her face. Kara is one of the many Minizoras that live in the city.

“Yeah fine.” Lena sighs. “That just took way longer than expected that’s all, and was more heated.”

“Yeah I heard.” Kara says. “I was waiting outside for our lunch date and heard bits and pieces.”

“Oh shit,” Lena sighs. “I’m so sorry Kara, I completely forgot.”

“It’s fine.” Kara says with a soft smile. “So what’s the verdict? Is Project Minizora City going a head?”

“Kind of?” Lena sighs.

“What do you mean kind of?” Kara asks.

“While the president and council had no interest what’s so ever and didn’t want to actually give me the funds for it they still gave me the go a head.” Lena says.

“Lena, that is great news!” Kara says with a huge smile. “But it sounds like there is a catch, there is isn’t there?”

“I have to do everything myself,” Lena says. “The funding has to come out of my pocket and I have to be the one to do everything, while I can hire help I need to be the one in change.”

“I mean that’s still great,” Kara says. “Isn’t that what you were hoping for?”

“Yeah, it was, but I was hoping for a bit of support from the government.” Lena says. “Then again what’s new?”

“Well you do have my support.” Kara smiles. “You always do.”

“I know.” Lena smiles. “And that’s why you are the best.”

“Duh,” Kara giggles.

Lena smirks and rolls her eyes. “Now I’ve got a lot of work to do keep you all safe.”


Six Months Later


Lena is nearing completion on the Minizora city, she sits in her office with Kara at her desk watching the workers over the monitors. Lena has built the city on the top floor of LCorp, it has a glass ceiling to help with the more natural feel of the city. The city is fully functioning just like a normal sized city on difference being that it’s made for Minizoras. Power, internet, water, everything identical to a normal city just scaled down.

“So how long until it’s done?” Kara asks.

“Another couple of days. Maybe a week.” Lena says. “I’ve sent out applications but so far I haven’t gotten any responses.”

“No one?” Kara asks. “I’m sure there is a lest someone.”

“Nope.” Lena says. “Well there is this one girl but she still sounds a bit undecided.”

“You’ve still got time.” Kara says. “I mean the city isn’t even open yet, people would want to see what the city is fully like before they actually sign up.”

“I guess you’re right.” Lena sighs. “But the opening is in a week and I have no one wanting to live there so that doesn’t exactly sound the best.”

“What are you talking about?” Kara asks. “You have someone interested.”

“The other girl is still undecided so I don’t know if she counts.” Lena sighs.

“Me you idiot.” Kara giggles as she flies up to Lena's face. “You didn’t think that I wouldn't want to live in your city?”

“I just didn’t think too much of it.” Lena smiles.

“I’m sure there will be someone who wants to live in your wonderful city besides me.” Kara says floating down to the desk. “Just give it time. How about I invite some Minizoras living on the other earths?”

“You can do that?” Lena asks.

“Yeah,” Kara smiles. “Cisco made this for me, its a teleportation device thing that allows me to travel to earth one when I’m needed or I need them. I’m sure they wont mind the visit.”

“Just be safe.” Lena says.

“You know who you’re talking to right?” Kara smirks. “I am Supergirl, did you forget?”

“No I didn’t, and that’s why I’m asking you to be careful.” Lena smirks.

Kara giggles and shakes her head. She jumps up and flies towards Lena’s face kissing her check. Lena smiles and blushes slightly before kissing Kara’s tiny little face.

“I wont be long I promise.” Kara says. “I might be a little while as I’m sure they would want to catch up.”

“Just take your time.” Lena smiles.

Kara smiles and nods. She opens the breach with a huge smile and files in before giving Lena a wave and a smile. Lena smiles and waves back.

The room goes quiet as Kara leaves, the sound of the blearing breech stops. Lena stands there for a couple of seconds before sitting down at her desk. Lena smiles as Kara pops into her mind.

There is nothing sexual or romantic going on between Kara and Lena but often Lena can’t help but think what if. Kara is smart, very kind and very beautiful. Lena has had moments where she has caught herself staring at Kara or even day dreamed about her. Almost all the times she has she’s shrugged it off and didn’t think too much about it. Lena just thinks of it as a stupid little crush and she might be a little desperate as it’s been a while since she has actually been with anyone.

Lena shugs it off and gets back to work as she still has a lot of financial difficulties to sort out between now and the completion date as well as other things to organise.
111231.title: Lena's Toy City

1112311.content:
Elizabeth Stark walks into L Corp with her backpack and a suit case. Elizabeth is a Minizora standing at four inches tall and is about to move into Lena Luthor’s new Minizora city. The twenty two year old wears her blue hoodie with her long red hair tied in a ponytail and tightly fitted jeans.

It’s opening day for Lena’s city and Elizabeth is surprised but happy that she was able to get a placement. Elizabeth sent Lena her application a couple of days ago and during that time the two had been emailing each other back and forth. Lena respond to Elizabeth as soon as possible asking her a lot of questions. While it did sound like Lena was happy for Elizabeth to move in she wanted a little interview before she moved in.

“Ms Luthor your two o’clock is here.” Lena’s secretary says opening the door for Elizabeth.

Elizabeth gives her a smile and heads in. She looks up and sees Lena standing up with a friendly smile.

“Ms Stark, it’s so nice to meet you.” Lena smiles.

“It’s nice to meet you too.” Elizabeth smiles as she walks in.

“Let me get that for you.” Lena smiles offering to take Elizabeths bags. “Put Ms Stark’s bags in her apartment.”

“Yes mam,” The secretary says taking the bags from Lena.

Lena guides Elizabeth over to the couch sitting in Lena’s office. Elizabeth climbs the little staircase and sits on the couch nervously. Lena sits a fair part away from Elizabeth to give her a bit of space. Elizabeth gives Lena a soft smile and starts to fiddle with her rings, she can feel her anxiety kick in.

“There’s no reason to be nervous Ms Stark.” Lena smiles. “I’m more than welcome for you to live in the city I just wanted to get to know you a bit before you move in that’s all.”

“It’s no problem.” Elizabeth smiles as her green eyes dart around. “It makes sense, I was just kind of surprised how often you replied to me that’s all.”

“It was no trouble at all.” Lena smiles. “I’m just happy that you wanted to come and live here. So what made you want to choice my city?

“I just needed somewhere to stay,” Elizabeth says. “I’m kind of in between jobs at the moment and my room mates kicked me out the other day because I struggled to pay rent.”

“I’m so sorry.” Lena says.

“Thanks.” Elizabeth says. “I mean it’s better than living on the street.”

“I’m glad someone thinks that.” Lena says.

“What do you mean?” Elizabeth asks.

“When I sent the information out about my new city I did have some people tell me to fuck off and that they would rather live on the streets.” Lena sighs.

“That’s horrible.” Elizabeth says.

“I know,” Lena sighs. “ But I’m used to it at this point, it comes with the reputation of being a Luthor.”

“That’s still awful.” Elizabeth says.

“Well what can you do.” Lena smirks. “There are people who hate me in this world but there are also a few who love me. It’s better to put my attention on the ones who love me than hate me.”

“At lest it doesn’t bother you too much then.” Elizabeth smiles.

“It does occasionally.” Lena says. “Enough about me though, we’re here to talk about you.”

Elizabeth giggles and blushes a little. Elizabeth had a question but is a little nervous to ask. “Um, during our back and forth in the emails I noticed you never said anything about how much it was going to cost me.”

“Don’t worry about it,” Lena shrugs.

“I feel like I should,” Elizabeth smirks.

“Honestly, you don’t have to.” Lena says. “I’m more than happy for you to stay here for free regarding your current situation.”

“I really don't mind paying.” Elizabeth says.

“With what money?” Lena teases.

“Fair enough.” Elizabeth smirks.

“You are one of the rear people in this city who actually wants to live in my city.” Lena says. “You giving me a chance and taking a risk on something you don’t know is good payment for me.”

“There must me something I can do.” Elizabeth says. “I’m not going to shut up about it until you give me something.”

“I mean I guess you can work for me in my lab.” Lena says. “How much do you know about technology and science?”

“While it’s not my go to I did learn enough from my ex girlfriend.” Elizabeth says.

“Then welcome aboard.” Lena smiles.

“Thanks Ms Luthor.” Elizabeth smiles.

“Please, call me Lena.” She smiles.

“Will do Lena.” Elizabeth smiles.

“I still have quite a bit of work I need to finish so while I do that how about you go get settled in and we can meet up later.” Lena says.

“That sounds perfect.” Elizabeth smiles. “Thank you so much for this Lena.”

“It’s no problem,” Lena smiles. “That’s what I made the city for.”

Elizabeth smiles and Lena flashes her a soft smile. Elizabeth can’t help but blush a bit as Lena’s smile is very pretty. Lena hands Elizabeth a little key with the number four on it before guiding her to the small elevator in her office. Lena waves Elizabeth off as she steps inside, as the elevator ascends Elizabeth watches Lena head back to her desk. Elizabeth smiles as she finds Lena to be very friendly and sweet, she’s completely lost on why no one who actually like her.

The elevator door opens giving Elizabeth a full view to a lobby very similar to a hotel. Its very fancy and something you would see at five star hotel. She steps out and marvels at he surrounding. There where another three elevators beside the one Elizabeth walked out of that lead to other parts of the building. Elizabeth smiles and walks towards the main entrance. She steps out side and is hit was a gentle breeze. Her jaw drops.

The landscape stretches out for what looks like miles and miles and the attention to detail is beyond incredible. Right outside the lobby there is a fully functional water fountain and further down the road there is a lot of shops. A cafe, a restaurant and even a shoe store. Elizabeth glances in the shops as she walks by, she’s never seen anything in such equal scale to her and that is fully functional. The shoe store has boxes and shoes presented and the cafe looks to have a proper coffee machine. Elizabeth looks around, there is still more she didn’t pick up on, a spa and so much more.

Elizabeth left the shopping district and enters the neighbourhood with all the houses. The houses are like little apartments, they are small but have enough space in between each complex to give each place a cosy feel and not make each place looked cramped. Each building was pained white with a red roof and a little number on the fence. Elizabeth looks at her key, she has the number four apartment. This must be her apartment.

Elizabeth opens the door to the apartment and her jaw drops. Without a doubt this was the nicest place she would have ever stayed but everything looks to be custom made especially for her. During their emails back and forth Lena had asked Elizabeth questions about her and she was paying attention. The kitchen was huge, two stoves and ovens with a good sized bench in the centre. Elizabeth had told Lena that she likes to cook but she never expected to get this. There was the lounge witch had a good sized television and surround sound and a very comfortable lazy boy couch.

“Holy shit,” Elizabeth smiles and squeals.

Elizabeth feels like she could cry, she’s never had any kind of luxury before in her life or anyone spoiling her this much and she’s only seen the kitchen and lounge. Elizabeth sits down on the couch and takes a few deep breaths. She giggles to herself as she tries to calm herself down so she doesn’t get overly excited.

There is a knock at the door, Elizabeth jumps up with glee and heads over as it must be one of her new neighbours. She opens the door and sees…

“You must be Elizabeth. I’m Kara Danvers your new neighbour.” She smiles. “I just thought I’d come over to say hi and welcome you to the neighbourhood.”

Her hair was two toned one side grey the other dark blue, and she had dark pink skin with large bat or dragon like wings jutting out of her back. Despite the clearly demonic appearance Jaden felt comfortable in her presence, which is probably why he didn't react much when the card ripples and the monster blinks

"Hello, I'm Jaden, who are you?" the boy asks, having not checked the card before now

"Haou" Yubel gasps, then smiles "I'm Yubel little one"

"Sweet, do you want to be my friend Yubel, I don't have many friends, or any really" Jaden admits sadly, making the spirit frown

" why wouldn't people want to be friends with an adorable thing like you?" She asks aloud

"Well I'm a minizora, other kids don't want to play with me because they think I'm fragile like a doll, or that they could catch the mini if they hang around me like I have cooties" Jaden wrinkles his nose, making Yubel giggle at the cuteness, as well as imagining Haou running away from her when they were kids because she 'had cooties'.

It was then Yubel decided to do something she probably shouldn't, she wasn't strong enough to physically manifest her LV 10 body, never mind her 11 or 12 bodies, so the only way to keep her beloved safe was to bring him to her, luckily his size was a benefit to her as it meant she didn't need to lead him to a natural portal, or snatch him away during Spirit day. Instead she just had to reach out with her power, link it to Jadens and yank.

Jaden yelped as the card of his new friend smiled demonically, then he sank into the image box, only to land in cupped, scaly hands "what? Where am I?" He blurts out

"With me" Jaden looks up and scurries back as he sees Yubels grinning face over her large, but oddly for a duel monster, completely covered breasts "My precious Jaden, we're together again, and this time it's forever " she purrs, raising him up for a kiss before cuddling him to her expansive chest "I should show you around, so you know where everything and everyone is" she pulls open her top enough to partly sit Jaden in her cleavage and flew off.

What is this world?

1) Yubel rules Dark World, keeping the throne warm for it's rightful King, though for now he may be more use helping keep her throne warm under her colossal tush
2) Yubel lives with Haous former royal guard and elite soldiers, who had eventually become the Elemental and Evil Hero Monsters. Most of who recognise and know Jaden and he knows them, as even now he was a HERO deck user.
114211.title: In the claws of the protector

1142111.content:
Large bat wings erupt from the shadows, before Yubel steps through, her prescious cargo nestled between her soft bosom and innocently happy to cuddle her tits

"You have returned your highness, wondrous news" she turns at the sound of the sly and insane man/creature

"Brron, of course I returned, I was merely looking for the Supreme Kings spirit" she explains, watching thenformer king, now advisor cackle and clap his formerly chained hands together

"Wonderful, were you successful?"

"I was, though he is once more a minizora" Yubel informs him, the fiend waves her off

"He didn't need size to command us, he ruled with his dark power. Train him well and he might last long enough to fill that flat stomach of yours" he cackles as he left, dodging a wing slap from his irate Queen

"Boshtet" she hisses, but knows he means her no harm, he's insane, but also unthinkably loyal, to Haou, and her. She hums to herself before walking to the window, where she often gazed out into this region of the duel spirit realm

"Wow, everything's so big and purple" Jaden gasps, amusing Yubel who looks down at him peeking out of her shirt

"Yes, and everything you see is my kingdom, to be yours once more when you grow up" Jaden pouts

"But that's forever away" he grumbles, which has Yubel giggle, jostling his hidy hole

"Maybe for a little boy, but for a duel spirit it's not long at all, and soon this Queen will have her King" she purrs and kisses his head, making Jaden blush

What happens next?

1) Yubel begins teaching him how to rule, by having him sit in with her at meetings, which here means hidden in her cleavage while she tells idiots how to do their job
2) to ensure her future king knows his place in the hierarchy, Yubel decides he should learn to love her womanly assets, starting with her wide and plump ass
3) while deep in thought she's tit tackled by a furball, it's a Kuriboh and not just that but a Winged Kuriboh, the fairy type rare in this part of the world. It turns out the thing is a girl and Jadens spirit guide, so wants to help Yubel raise her partner.

11512.title: Sequel time

1152.content:
This one is a modern classic with a lot of potential. All sorts of weirdness can happen in the town, so some minizoran might actually be the least strange thing around.

Option 1: Only one of the Pines twins is a mini. They're still twins, but being fraternal means that they also have quite a few differences.
Option 2: Both twins are minizoran. What kinds of shenanigans can a couple of tiny pre-teens get up to? You already know the answer.
Option 3: Reader's choice.
1152.title: Gravity Falls

11521.content: Mini Dipper or mini Mable?
11521.title: Mini Pines Twin

115211.content:
Dipper had had an eventful last few hours to say the least. After being dropped off by their folks in this tourist trap town, he and his sister Mable had a bit of an incident. And by incident, he’s obviously referring to Mable being kidnapped and almost forced into marriage with 1,000 gnomes, followed by an epic chase in a golf cart from a composite gnome monster, and ending with the defeat of said monster with a leaf blower. However, now that the adrenaline had fallen and they were up in the attic for the evening, Dipper took greater interest with his initial big discovery: a mysterious journal with a six fingered hand on the cover. Of particular interest to the three inch tall boy was that the book was sized to minizora like himself.

“What’ch’ya readin’ there, bro-bro?” asked Mable. The regular sized twelve year old was hanging upside down off the edge of her bed. She wore her usual purple sleeping sweater as her feet kicked idly in the air.

“The journal about the mysteries of Gravity Falls,” Dipper explained. “You know, the one I showed you a few hours ago back when I thought the gnomes were actually a zombie.”

Mable gave a snorting laugh. “Yeah. Great job being the smart twin. Can’t even tell the difference between gnomes and zombies.”

Dipper narrowed his eyes on his sister. “Oh yeah? Well you followed a strange guy you’d only just met out into the woods where anything could have happened! Honestly, it turning out to be gnomes was pretty lucky on your end.”

“Hey, it’s not my fault! I thought he was a vampire.”

“And that makes it better?”

Mable folded her arms and turned away in a huff, still upside-down. “I won’t even dignify that with a response.”

“He’s been out in the sun all day wearing only a hoodie,” reminded Dipper.

“He could be using super vampire sunblock. You don’t know,” Mable whined.

“Mable, that makes literally no sense.”

“Sure it does. In fact, I know how to settle this. You’ve got a journal full of weird stuff, right? Go ahead and check.”

Dipper gave a soft chuckle as he flipped through the pages. “You know, that was a lot more mature than what I was expecting from you.”

“What is that supposed to mean? I’m super mature! I’m the most maturest mature person to ever… mature! Also I’m a girl, and everyone knows girls mature faster than boys,” she finished with a dignified huff.

Dipper rolled his eyes. “Riiight. Mable is sooo mature. She shops for teddy bear undies in the big girl isle.”

Cheeks flushed, Mable’s hands shot down (relative to her perspective) to cover her sweater over her unmentionables. “You saw nothing!”

“Yeah, yeah,” Dipper said with a dismissive wave. “You and your… wait a minute.” He stopped flipping through pages and brought the book up to his face. “I found it! The section on vampires.”

“Show me!” Mable tried to stand, but only managed to flip onto her face with a thud. “Ow. Ugh. Just read it to me.”

“Huh. Well I’ll be. It says here that vampires do sometimes use a super sunblock.”

“Ah ha!” Mable shot a fist up in triumph.

“Buuut,” Dipper continued, “it’s made of ingredients considered repugnant by vampires. If a vampire were actually using the stuff, they’d also have to wear nose plugs so they don’t gag.”

Mable’s arm fell limp. “Ah poo.” Once she grew bored of lying on the floor, Mable sat up and walked across the room to the side of Dipper’s regular sized bed and planted her chin on the sheets. She looked down at him with curious and thoughtful eyes.

“Mable,” Dipper said warily as the big face loomed over him. “What’s that look for?”

“Oh nothing. Just thinking how lucky I am to have a little,” she snickered, “brother like you.”

“Oh ha-ha.”

“I mean it. You’re so tiny, but you still came after me even when you thought I was about to be eaten by a zombie. You also drove a golf cart like a total pro. How’d you do that again?”

“Specially modified for minizora drivers,” Dipper explained, trying to focus on his reading. Now that he’d started, there were just so many interesting factoids about vampires he’d never considered before. “Besides, you’d have done the same for me.”

“Well duh! But that’s different. You were in, like, way more danger than me back there. What if one of those creepy gnomes stepped on you?”

“I’ve been stepped on before. Not that big a deal,” Dipper explained dismissively. “Also, I wasn’t the target for what I assume to have been an attempted gang bang by said creepy gnomes.”

Mable pouted cutely. “You’re making it really hard to give a heartfelt thank you for saving my life, you know. You put your life on the line for me when you didn’t have to, and that means a lot.”

Dipper finally closed the book. “Actually, I did have to.”

“Huh?”

“It’s like when someone’s driving and a rabbit runs out in the middle of the road. Technically they don’t have to slow down and let the fluffy adorable critters live, but if they don’t slow down, then they just end up feeling awful all day. I wasn’t about to spend the rest of the summer feeling awful about myself, so there really wasn’t a choice.”

Eyes shimmering, Mable shot out a giant hand and snatched up her diminutive brother and pressed him firmly against her cheek in her closest approximation of a hug. “I love you Dipper. You’re the best brother ever! I don’t ever want to let you go.”

Then there came a tapping from the floor.

“Hey, keep it down up there!” groused the gruff voice of their Grunkle Stan. “I don’t need to hear what a couple of preteens are doing so late at night alone in their room.”

“Ugh, gross!” growled Mable as she stomped the floor in retaliation.

Dipper began to laugh as Mable continued to hold him. “You’re not a half bad sister, either.”

“Watch it, bro-bro.” Suddenly serious, Mable pointed an accusing finger at Dipper. “If you make me mad, then I’ll show you just how immature I can really be.”

“Oh really?” Dipper asked in taunting. “Well that would certainly be a change of pace.” Even as Mable fumed, Dipper couldn’t help himself and laughed at her expense. As her brother, he had a moral imperative to tease her at every opportunity, regardless of the consequences.

“Fine! If you like my teddy bear panties so much, then maybe you’d like to get acquainted for the rest of the night,” she warned, giving him a chance to back down.

Dipper’s eyebrow climbed up his forehead. “You realize that’d just prove Grunkle Stan right, don’t you?”

Ire gone, Mable blinked like a deer caught in the headlights. “Shoot!” She kicked impotently at the floor. “That’s no fair. How can I be a good big sister and keep my little brother in line if I can’t use my go-to for punishment?”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “Are you actually asking, or are you just thinking out loud? Because if the latter, can I get the journal back?” He pointed back down at the bed. “I dropped it when you grabbed me.” When he caught a devious glint in his sister’s eye, Dipper knew he had to act quickly. “Keep in mind that this journal has all kinds of information regarding the dangerous secrets of this town. If it weren’t for that thing, I might not have gone after you in the first place. If anything bad happens to that book, I might not be able to save you next time.”

Mable deflated and blew a raspberry. “Double poo.” She turned a longing eye on the mini boy in her hand. “Isn’t there anything I can do to punish you?” she pleaded pitifully.

“You’re seriously asking me that?” Were this anyone but Mable, Dipper would be floored by the audacity of it all.

“Yeah. You’ve got some pretty good ideas sometimes. What’s something I can do to assert myself as the dominant twin that doesn’t cross the line into, you know, weirdness?”

Dipper smirked. “That’s never bothered you before. I think I’ve completed, like, half my homework while stuffed in your clothes somewhere.” He gestured up and down her body. “At this point it’s not even really a punishment. More like my second room.”

“Pleaaase!”

“Oh fine. Let me think.” Dipper tapped his chin in thought, silently cursing himself for being unable to resist his sister’s cute antics. “Hmm. I guess we could…”
115211.title: Mini Dipper in Gravity Falls

1152111.content:
After settling into this den of weirdness, Dipper and Mable were in the Mystery Shack’s dining room having just completed an epic syrup race. Mable had won, much to her regret, and Dipper was reading the towns’ newspaper; scaled down for minizora of course.

“Hey Mable. Look at this.”

The bigger – but not older – sibling peered down at the tiny article. “Human sized hamster ball. Wait a minute… I’m human sized!” She sucked in a shocked breath. “And so are you! But with a regular hamster ball. We can be hamster ball twins!”

Dipper rolled his eyes and pointed to what he actually wanted to show her. It was a contest for photos of monsters. The winner got $1000. “We see weirder stuff than that every day. Did we get any photos of those gnomes?”

“Nope. Just memories.” Mable waited a second before holding up a tuft of white hair. “And this beard hair.”

“Why did you save that?” asked Dipper, backing away in revulsion.

Speaking of revulsion, that was when Grunkle Stan came in dressed in a pair of boxers and a night shirt with stains that were better left not thought about. The old man wanted to close the shop early and have a bonding day with the family. He promised that this would be nothing like the last time in which they made counterfeit money, which was followed up by a trip to the freezing county jail. With assurances like that, how could they refuse?

After a harrowing blindfolded drive across town, the twins were finally allowed to uncover their eyes and behold the lake, where apparently fishing season had opened. Said lake was positively lousy with the town’s colorful denizens doing all sorts of wacky antics. Watching some of the rougher antics led to Mable grabbing Dipper and setting him on her shoulder for safe keeping. But just as Grunkle Stan was finishing his less than stellar sales pitch for fishing for the next ten hours, that’s when another old made started going off about some monster called the Gobblewonker.

“Aww,” Mable cooed. “He’s doing a happy jig.”

That’s when old man Magucket grabbed her shoulders and started screaming. “No. It’s a jig of grave danger!” warned the guy who had earned the title of town kook. He gave a far more convincing pitch for why the gobblewonker was real, pointing a boat that looked to have been bitten in half and offering a pretty detailed description of the creature. Alas, everyone else was entirely dismissive of his claims and soon the crowd dispersed.

“Mable, did you hear what he said?” Dipper asked excitedly.

“Aww, donkey spittle,” she said in approximation of the old man’s funny way of talking.

“No, the other thing. The monster. If we can snag a photo, we can split the prize fifty-fifty.”

“That’s two fifties!”

“Imagine what you could do with $500,” Dipper encouraged, not bothering to correct her math. He then sat back as his sister’s pupils went wide. Clearly she’d been kidnapped by her own imagination again and it was just a matter of waiting for her to come back.

“Dipper. I am one million percent on board with this!”

Once again, Grunkle Stan delivered an inferior sales pitch for fishing, although this time he lost to Soos who’d just driven up in a far superior boat. It wasn’t a hard choice.

“We’re gonna find that gobblewonker!”

“We’re gonna win that prize!”

Once the excitement tempered a bit, the team of a pair of twins and the pair shaped chipmunk faced guy set about their plan. They’d gone and bought an excessive amount of disposable cameras, which made a lot of sense given that none of them owned smart phones. As the boat neared Scuttlebutt Island, an ominous fog descended upon them. The island itself was just as creepy, but spirits were still high.

“So, do you carry him around with you everywhere?” Soos asked.

Mable shrugged. “Not everywhere. Just most wheres. Hehe. Saves him the trouble of getting lost.”

“Me, lost? You once got lost on the way to the bathroom.”

“The point is that it’s just easier this way,” Mable insisted. “He’s like a knight riding atop his elegant and beautiful steed.”

“She’s absolutely right,” agreed Dipper. “The real steed’s at the shop for repairs, so they gave me this,” he gestured with his thumb, “cheap rental.”

“Heh. Good one, dude.”

“Cheap? I’ll have you know that I’m about to be a five hundred-naire.”

“Yeah? Well so am I.”

“I’m just happy to tag along,” Soos offered. “Speaking of tagging, I’ve never really known a minizora before. What’s it like being so small?”

“Terrible. No matter what I do, I can always look up people’s noses and see the horrors that lie within.” That got everyone chuckling. “But seriously, it’s not too bad. It doesn’t hurt that I’ve got a nice steed to take me places.”

“See. He admits I’m a steed.”

“It’s just easier than saying rented mule-ow!” Dipper groaned as his head was pinched. “Somebody help! A pair of sausage fingers are crushing my head!”

“You sure that’s safe, dude?” Soos asked.

“Oh he’s fine,” assured Mable. “First day here that lumberjack guy stepped on him and he just walked it off. This,” she tightened her pinch, “is nothing.”

Dipper finally stopped yelling, showing that he was just putting on a show. “Yeah, she’s right. There’s a reason most stunt men are minizora, you know. We can handle just about anything.”

“Anything?”

“Anything,” Dipper affirmed.

“How much can you bench-press?”

“I once saw him lift up a whole pizza crust.”

“Wow, dude. You’re like a super hero. Got the proportionate strength of an ant, only you’re already pretty small, so it’s not that impressive, but it’s still pretty cool.”

“Wow. Thanks a lot, Soos,” Dipper said, feeling genuinely moved. Part of why he was the bookish type was because most kids his own age just made fun of him for being small. It was a refreshing change of pace to actually hear praise.

Mable grinned from ear-to-ear. She’d already liked Soos. They got each other’s humor. But seeing how nice he was to Dipper, Mable knew she’d made a new friend for life.

That’s when a roar echoed through the woods. Birds were sent cawing in terror as the team finally had a direction.

“This is it. This is it!” Dipper said in whispered excitement. Still sitting on his sister’s shoulder, he kicked at her through her sweater and urged her onward. “Ya, mule! Ya-ya, mule!”

“Dude. That’d be so offensive… if it weren’t so hilariously accurate,” commented Soos as he grabbed a long and sharp stick. Perfect for stabbing.
1152111.title: Gobblewonker 1

11521111.content:
Unfortunately, it all turned out to be a false alarm. What looked like the gobblewonker through the fog was really just a destroyed boat. And what sounded like the gobblewonker was actually an old chainsaw engine being messed with by a beaver.

“But… I was so sure.”

“There, there, little bro,” consoled Mable, petting his head.

“Hey. At least we got to see a beaver with a chainsaw. That’s pretty sweet.”

“Maybe that old guy was crazy after all.” Dipper slumped on his slumping seat.

“He did use the word ‘scrap-doodle’,” Mable agreed, just as despondent. While Soos was preoccupied with the beaver, the preteen girl decided to make some distance to give her brother some ‘alone’ time; which of course meant that she stuck nearby at all times.

“This sucks. We didn’t find the gobblewonker, and what are we gonna say to Grunkle Stan? We ditched him over nothing.”

“It’s not so bad. I mean, yeah, it’s pretty bad,” agreed Mable. “He seemed really excited just to hang out with us and we left him high and dry… in that dinky little boat.”

Then there came a rumble.

“Mable. Did you feel-whoa!” Dipper slipped, but thankfully caught himself on Mable’s lifejacket.

“Ahh!” Mable screamed, pointing out into the water where something big was swimming around.

“This is it!” cheered Dipper, pulling out one of their last few cameras. “I just have to-agh. Mable, hold still. I can’t get a good shot with you moving.”

“Uh, dude,” intoned Soos worriedly.

In the few seconds since Dipper had taken his eyes off the lake, the gobblewonker had come up to the shore, rose it’s long neck out of the water, and loomed menacingly over the trio. And then, just as Dipper turned back around, it roared.

“Ruuun!”

In complete disregard to logic, the aquatic gobblewonker flopped its mighty frame onto land and used its flippers to give chase after the trio. Dipper couldn’t run on his own, but he could stare into the jaws of death and warn the others where and when trees were falling on them. And while Soos was able to get them to the boat, the gobblewonker just hopped back in the water, where it was significantly faster. What followed was an exciting chase across the lake, overturning many boats and causing general mayhem. Grunkle Stan would have found it hilarious, were he not on the business end of it.

“Ahh! Beavers!” cried Mable as beavers began raining down on the boat. With their home just destroyed, the little fuzz balls were understandably agitated and were biting at anything they could reach. “Ahh! My brother!” Before one of the overgrown rats could chomp the little guy, Mable beat him to it and stuffed Dipper in her mouth.

This was hardly a new experience for Dipper. He’d been eaten by his sister more times than he could count, though usually it was under less life threatening circumstances. The air was humid, Mable had apparently forgotten to brush this morning, and saliva was creeping into his clothes. Keeping her lips shut, Mable was still screaming as Dipper bounced around on the soft tongue. In a brief respite, he caught himself thinking that this wouldn’t be so bad if only he weren’t wearing sticky clingy clothes, but that was neither here nor there.

Pulling out a flashlight, Dipper opened the journal and quickly searched for anything related to the gobblewonker, but instead found a very interesting map of the lake. He tapped at Mable’s teeth and signaled her to open her mouth. She did, screaming as she’d taken over the steering after Soos had been incapacitated by a beaver. “Head for the waterfall!” Dipper instructed.

Mable did, and everyone braced themselves for the worst. Fortunately, the journal proved true. There was a cave on the other side. Even better, it was too small for the gobblewonker, rendering it stuck.

“It’s stuck!” Dipper cheered, patting himself down within his sister’s maw. “Wait, I don’t have any more cameras!” he exclaimed in a sudden panic.

“Blah.” Mable extended her tongue with her brother upon it and removed his hat where he still had one camera left. “Zare,” she said helpfully with her tongue still occupied.

Overwhelmed with elation, Dipper danced around on the tongue as he ran through the entire roll of film. “This is it! We finally got the picture.”

“Yay!” Mable also cheered, ignoring the taste of fabric. It was more fun to play with a naked brother in her mouth than a clothed one. This would be important information to consider for later.

However, while everyone was cheering, the gobblewonker’s flailing caused a light cave in, leading to a large rock crushing its head and making some odd metallic sounds.

“What the?” Mable started to ask. “Ahh, Dipper.” She reached out, but the little guy was already hopping down the cliff with the speed of a goat.

“Wow. Quick little dude, ain’t he,” observed Soos.

“You have no idea,” Mable grumbled irritably. She hated when Dipper ran away from her, especially towards something so obviously dangerous. Her own efforts to follow were slower and more careful. Oh, Dipper was going to pay for making her worry like this.

“Hey guys, come check this out,” Dipper called from atop the creatures back.

Once they’d arrived, they found one of those spinning door cranks. It was on Mable and Soos to open it up, revealing…

“Old man Magucket!”

The town kook was at some kind of control panel. It was defunct now, but clearly he’d been piloting the gobblewonker. As it turned out, he’d built this behemoth killing machine because he felt neglected and wanted some attention, especially from his family. While even he admitted that it was pretty contrived, his story did move the kids to sympathy for their own old person.

In the end, they all decided to make up with and spend the rest of the day with their favorite Grunkle. Fishing turned out to be a lot of fun. Even fleeing the lake police was enjoyable. All was well, except that there was an old man in a cave with a history of building death machines and the stated intent of making a death ray. Not to mention that Dipper never finished reading the lake segment of the journal, which had a good many pages devoted to the gobblewonker.

With the sun set and the day concluded, the Pines family and Soos departed the lake for their respective homes. Mable held Dipper in her lap all the while, wondering how she was going to deal with her brother’s reckless behavior.
11521111.title: Gobblewonker 2

115211111.content:
Following dinner at the Mystery Shack, Dipper and Mable decided to wash up before heading to bed; especially Dipper who was all too eager to discard his saliva drenched clothes.

“Hey Mable, could you get a cup of water or something?” asked the naked twelve year old of his undressing twin sister.

“Huh?” Standing in the bathroom, Mable was down to just a pair of blue panties. She stared at her tiny naked brother, free of any sense of shame. They’d been bathing together since they were born, so the sight of the other’s naked body was nothing new to either of them.

“It’s just I don’t want these,” Dipper gestured to the clothes in his arms, “to dry and get all crusty before they can get washed. You know what crusty clothes are like.”

“Ugh! Only cuz you won’t shut up about it,” grumbled Mable as she picked up the pile of garments and reached over the sink to ready a glass of water. This brought her bare and underdeveloped chest awfully close to her brother, but Dipper’s eyes were on something more important than her little nubs.

“Is something wrong, Mable?”

“What? No. Of course not!” she kicked at the carpet. “Why would you think something’s wrong?”

Dipper cringed. “Oh, you know, no reason. Just being a concerned brother is all.”

“Concerned brother, huh? Is that what you call it when you leave me behind and run straight towards a giant monster?”

“Hey, give me a break. I was curious.”

“Curious, huh? Curiosity killed the cat, Dipper!” she said like it was some scathing accusation.

“In my defense, a giant rock just fell on the thing’s head. It was either dead or concussed. Either way, I’m too small to be looked at as prey. I was perfectly safe.”

“There’s nothing safe about giant sea monsters, little Dipper. You could have been hurt. Do you have any idea how worried I was?”

Dipper was taken aback when he caught his sister sniffling. Her eyes glistened before she turned her back on him. He reached out for her. “Mable…”

“I’m taking a shower,” she huffed, slipping off her panties and discarding them to the side. Her immense hair shielded the back of her body as she marched off to the tub.

With a defeated sigh, Dipper turned back to the sink. He’d have preferred to shower with his sister, but there were accommodations in the nozzles for a minizora to handle, so at least he could pour himself a steamy bath. The little boy dove in like it was a pool and swam around idly. Every now and then he’d turn to the silhouette of his sister in the shower, but she said nothing. She wasn’t even singing the latest awful boyband hit, but the only thing more awful than that was the ongoing silence.

“Um, Mable,” Dipper called, but got no answer. He heaved a sigh. “Look Mable, I’m sorry I made you worry, but I don’t think you’re being very fair right now. We were both in danger you know. How do you think I felt with everyone running for their lives and me being able to do nothing to help?”

Finally Mable tossed the shower curtain aside and turned the water off. “That’s not your job, Dipper. I’m the big sister, so that means I-”

“There, right there!” Dipper accused. “That’s what’s not fair. We’re twins, but you’re always putting it on yourself to protect me even though I’m just as worried about you.”

“That’s not the same.”

“Except it is. That whole gnome debacle could have been avoided if you’d just listened to me from the start. I tried letting you do things on your own, and look where that got us.”

Mable scoffed in disbelief. “So what? You want to be the big sibling and look after me from now on? Ha! I’d like to see that.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “I’m trying to say that it’s unfair of you to think you’re the only one that gets worried. You’re my sister and I want to see you safe, but I still let you go out and make your own mistakes. I don’t smother you.”

Mable blinked. Dripping naked, she stepped out of the shower and over to the sink. “Is that how you feel about me?”

Feeling sheepish, Dipper grabbed his arm and averted his gaze. “Sometimes.”

“Well… I guess it was kind of unfair of me to forget that you get just as worried as I do,” Mable conceded. “And maaaybe I overreacted just a tad this time with the gobblewonker.”

“Not during the attack, though. Only after,” Dipper corrected. “When that thing was after us, you actually listened to me. You trusted me to make the right call and that’s what pulled us through.” He reached out and motioned for Mable to come down to his level. She did, lowering her chin to the counter and extending a hand; whichever he’d prefer.

Dipper went for Mable’s cheek and gave it an affectionate pat. “All I’m asking is that you trust me a bit more. Trust me like I trust you.”

Mable sniffled and stroked a finger down Dipper’s back. “I’m still going to be worried about you, though.”

“Like I could stop you,” chuckled Dipper. “Hey, you forgot to tell Soos the whole story with the lumberjack guy. You know, where you started attacking him like you had rabies or something.”

Mable giggled. “Hey, I was just trying to teach him a lesson about watching his step.”

“Animal control was called and the guy’s shoes were ruined,” Dipper deadpanned.

Mable sighed fondly. “Yeah. I think I hate the taste of shoes.”

“Everyone does, Mable. But you’re one of the few people who takes the time to make sure.”

Humming contentedly, Mable picked her little brother up and carried him to the shower. “Want to join me?” she asked while stepping in.

“Sure thing.” Though Dipper just expected their typical mutual wash, his sister had something else in mind as she casually tossed him in her mouth.

“Ooh yesh,” Mable said through her mouthful. Naked Dipper was so much better than clothed Dipper. She couldn’t quite put a name on his flavor. She’d licked skin before, her own and that of others, but in those cases it had been tasteless at best and gag inducing at normal. But with Dipper, there was just some intangible quality that made him absolutely delicious. She was content to just chalk it up to being another minizora thing and leave it at that, for right now she had the more pressing priority of running her tongue over every square inch of his body.

Mable licked over Dipper’s face, feeling him smile. She licked under his armpits, which made him thrash about from being tickled. Over his butt got a similar result, but by far the most exquisite part of her brother’s body was his groin. Somehow that tiny penis and pair of balls had the strongest flavor of any part of him. And when she devoted special attention there, she giggled at how he grew erect. She loved how she could do this to him. For all their talk of trust and respect, Mable would never relinquish the power of being the big sister.

Inside the moist maw, Dipper was moaning as he was pelted on all sides by soft flesh. When it was just his bare skin, the stickiness didn’t bother him as much. In fact, he rather enjoyed being in his sister’s mouth. He enjoyed being played with, of being tossed around and toyed with. Mable knew all the right ways to touch him that just felt so incredible. And now that she was focusing on his penis, the little boy cried out in rapture as he bucked his hips into the slimy organ.

Mable continued her affectionate tongue bath until she’d achieved her reward. A tiny but potent sprits of sweet and sour flavoring. It was the perfect dessert after a long day of monster hunting, a treasure that was hers alone to enjoy. She hummed, continuing to toss her brother around her mouth until finally that extra special flavor disappeared and she spat him back out. “Have fun?” she beamed, already knowing the answer.

Panting from his ordeal in Mable’s hands, Dipper looked up and gave a weak-armed thumbs up. This was their way of saying that all was forgiven. From there they got cleaned up properly, dressed for the night, and went to bed. All was as it should be, with not a care in the world devoted to the old man and his death ray, nor the mysterious triangular constellation that briefly appeared in the night’s sky.
115211111.title: Sibling Confrontation

1152111111.content:
In the TV room, Dipper sat on his sister’s shoulder while they ate popcorn and watched the latest episode of Ducktective.

“That duck is a genius,” awed Mable as she went through the motions of giving a single corn to her shoulder occupant.

Dipper shrugged unimpressed. “Eh. It’s easier to find clues when you’re that close to the ground.”

“Speaking from experience?” teased Mable as she poked him in the gut. “Like you could actually outwit Ducktective.”

“I’ll have you know that I have very keen powers of observation,” Dipper boasted. “For example: Just from smelling your breath, I know that you’ve been eating… an entire tube of toothpaste?”

“It was so sparkly,” Mable confessed, sounding just a bit sick.

“Hey dudes. You’ll never guess what I just found!” declared Soos.

“Bur-” Dipper was silenced by a finger over his mouth.

“Buried treasure!” exclaimed Mable. “Ha. I win.”

As it turned out, the ‘buried treasure’ was a secret door hidden behind the wallpaper. Within was a room filled with wax dummies of various historical figures. Grunkle Stan told the story of how he’d ‘purchased’ the figures years ago, but then locked them in here after the wax museum stopped being profitable. When it was discovered that wax Abraham Lincoln had melted, Mable had jumped at the chance to remake it into something new. When being offered free labor to resurrect an old and profitable attraction, Stan was all too happy to oblige.

Later that day, Dipper was enjoying a rare instance of independence without being carried around by Mable. It felt good to stretch his legs and do little things like get his own soda. Walking down the hall, he was enjoying a few sips when Mable sprung out of nowhere, causing him to drop his drink.

“Dipper, I have to show you my ideas.” She held up a sketchbook. “She’s part fairy princess, and part horse fairy princess,” she described of the abominable centaur monstrosity.

“Mmmaybe you should carve something from real life,” Dipper suggested, not wanting to crush his sister’s artistic dreams.

It took a bit of trial and error, but eventually Mable settled on sculpting a very special member of her family.

“Wow, dude. Your sister’s, like, really good at this,” Soos commented from the doorway.

“Yeah. Once she gets in one of these artsy moods, basically nothing can stop her.” Then Dipper got an idea. “Hey, Soos. I’ll pay you five bucks to go in there and tell her to stop.”

Soos glowered down at the little dude. “Dude, I’m no Albert Einstein, but I’m not stupid. I heard the full story of what happened to Manly Dan and there ain’t no way I’m sticking my hand in a fish tank filled with piranha.”

Dipper chuckled. “Yeah, fair point.”

Later still, there was a big ceremony for the reopening of the wax museum. At the ticket booth, Dipper sat alongside Wendy. She was the fifteen year old ginger who worked the Shack’s counter most days. Her body was leanly built with well-defined muscle, a modest chest for her age, and a rump that was nothing to scoff at.

Dipper was pretending not to notice the afore mentioned details as he sat in a tiny chair on the table. Technically his job was to guard the money jar, but he had the feeling that he was actually being used as just another oddity to attract customers. “I can’t believe how many people showed up for this. It looks like half the town is here.”

“I know, right,” agreed Wendy in her usual laidback demeanor. She was also pretending not to notice Dipper. She’d never seen a minizora before and there was something about this little cutie that kept drawing her eye. “Folks around here must be super bored. Either that or Stan bribed them.”

Dipper unfurled a green bill from his jacket. “He bribed me.” Wendy pulled out her own bill and they shared a laugh. This was nice. Aside from his mother and sister, Dipper had never really hung out with a girl before, especially not one this pretty. It wasn’t weird that he thought she was pretty, right?

When the unveiling finally got underway, it was tragically met with a lukewarm response from the audience. Fortunately, Mable was not so easily deterred. “Thank you all for coming. I made this sculpture with my own two hands. It’s covered in my blood, sweat, tears, and other fluids.”

While the rest of the audience gagged at the implications, Wendy stole a wary glance at Dipper. Reluctantly, the minizora nodded that this was the case, to which Wendy commented, “Hehe, gross.”

“I will now take questions!” Mable announced.

“Old man McGucket. Local kook,” he introduced himself. “Are the wax figures alive and – follow-up question – can I survive the wax man uprising?”

“Um… yes! Next question.”

A few more questions followed before Shandra Jimenez spoke up. In this one horse town, she was considered the only ‘real’ reporter. She was Hispanic with dark skin, high cheek bones, and one of the finest bodies in all of Gravity Falls. “Your flyer promised free pizza with admission to this event. Is this true?” Despite her dispassionate tone, this questions seemed to wake the audience up as everyone was up in arms. Literally. Some people had actually brought pickaxes and pitchforks to a wax museum opening.

“This probably isn’t good,” Wendy observed, bracing herself to run. She then remembered her table companion and suddenly felt awkward. Was it okay to pick up a minizora without asking, even in an emergency?

Sure enough, Stan dismissed what had apparently been the primary interest of the audience and attempted to flee with the money. This in turn led to a small riot in which chairs were thrown and poles were punched. Wendy, ever a girl of action, snatched Dipper off the table, stowed him in her breast pocket, and ferried him out of the danger zone.

Dipper wasn’t too worried about his predicament. He’d been picked up by strangers before, but Wendy wasn’t exactly a stranger. She’d never been overtly hostile and generally treated him with better courtesy than she did most patrons of the Shack. The inside of her breast pocket was hot and the fabric was a little itchy. It also smelled. Dipper knew that there was only one thing he could be smelling at this time and wasn’t sure how he felt about it.

“Hey! No punching the banner poles!” Mable snapped, pointing at Manly Dan the lumberjack. As soon as the pair’s eye’s met, the man who resembled a shaved red yeti decided to be anywhere but near that sack of adorable crazy. Once the audience dispersed, Mable casually walked over to Wendy and with her eternal cheerfulness, held out her hand in a gi-me gesture. Wendy obliged and surrendered the tiny twin. “I think that went well,” Mable commented.

“Actually, yeah,” agreed Wendy. “Compared to how these things usually go, there’s almost no damage. Oh, and sorry little dude,” she said to Dipper. “For picking you up without asking, I mean. It was kind of a spur of the moment thing.”

“Oh hey,” Dipper laughed nervously. “It was no big deal.”

“Not big, but adequate sized,” Mable commented to the confusion of the others. “You acted quick and decisive, prioritizing safety over personal autonomy. And for that, you have my respect.” She extended her hand, which Wendy happily shook.

“Wow. That’s… unsettlingly authoritarian, but whatever.” The red head shrugged. “I just didn’t want the little guy hurt is all. Oh well.” She set her hands on her hips and surveyed the mess. “Looks like a lot of work to do. Think I’ll clock out early.” And she beat a lazy retreat.

Mable grinned as she watched the taller girl go. “I like her.”

What next?
1152111111.title: Headhunters

11521111111.content:
Later that night, Dipper and Mable were upstairs brushing their teeth. Mable had just suggested a tooth brush race when they heard the cries of horror from downstairs. Being a couple of twelve year olds who’d faced down two horrifying monsters in less than a week, they decided to run towards the sound of danger. That’s where they found the source of the commotion. Wax Stan had been murdered via decapitation and his head was nowhere to be found. It was so gruesome that Mable fainted; (accidentally) crushing Dipper under her butt.

The police arrived in short order, given that this was probably the biggest criminal activity they’d seen in weeks. Even so, the sheriff seemed reluctant to even do minimal investigation, so Dipper volunteered.

“Thank you Dipper,” squeed Mable, hugging him to her cheek. “I knew I could count on you.”

“Oh, well would you look at what we got in here,” taunted Sheriff Blubs. “City boy gonna solve the mystery with his fancy computer phone.”

“City boooy!” called the deputy. “City boooy!”

“You are adorable,” Blubs added, leading the both of them to laugh.

“Adorable?” Dipper asked. He’d been called a lot of names over his life and had learned to shrug off most of them, but for some reason this one really dug under his skin. When the cops left, Dipper was filled with righteous indignation. “That’s it! Mable, you and me are going to find out who did this and get back that head. Then they’ll see who’s adorable,” he snarled, trying to look as tough as possible. Then he sneezed.

“Aww. You sneeze like a kitten,” Mable cooed, finding his wrathful glare all the more endearing.

The next morning, the investigation was underway. The twins were taking photos for evidence, compiling a list of suspects, and consulting the journal for anything supernatural that might be related. Yet it was Mable who found the first clue in the form of shoeprints in the shag carpeting.

“Dang. How did I miss that?” Dipper grumbled. “So much for being closer to the ground.”

“Some things you can only see from high up,” Mable explained.

“Whatever. The point is that these shoeprints have a hole in the left shoe. That’s pretty unusual. And they lead to…” An axe was found just behind the chair. Dipper just glowered at the axe for a solid few seconds. “We’ve been here literally five minutes and already found the murder weapon, but a couple of ‘professional’ cops didn’t do jack,” Dipper ranted.

“Hey, maybe they were tired,” Mable excused. “Or, you know, I hear towns like these include playing FPS games as part of their police exams.”

Dipper frowned. “Now it feels like I’m racing against someone without arms or legs.” He then slapped himself for daring to pity the enemy. “Doesn’t matter. We’ve still got a mystery to solve!”

After conversing with Soos, the axe was connected to Manly Dan, who frequented an intense biker joint downtown. Soos also tried coining the term ‘mystery twins’, but Dipper was in no mood for cute names. Grunkle Stan, upon seeing the kids with an axe and plans on confronting the possible murderer, cheered them on to “Avenge meee!”

Dipper was suffering an increasingly low opinion of the town’s collective IQ after Mable’s fake IDs actually got them into the bar. Inside there were all manner of ruffians punching one another for no discernable reason. Still the picture of perkiness, Mable deposited Dipper in her sweater collar and attempted to hold him close. However, much to her consternation, he wiggled free.

“Come on, Mable. We talked about this already.”

“Now? You want to go off and do your own thing here of all places?” When Dipper just crossed his arms and impatiently tapped his foot, Mable gave a conceding groan. “Okay, fine. But if you get stepped or sat on, that’s on you.” And they split up. Dipper went straight for Manly Dan while Mable decided to destress by chatting up a very tattooed and burly man.

“Manly Dan, just the guy I wanted to see,” Dipper greeted, trying to look tough as he stood on the arm wrestling machine Dan was playing. “Where were you last night?”

“Punching the clock,” growled the lumberjack, sounding like he was perpetually on the verge of going into a blood rage.

“You were at work?”

“No, I was punching that clock.” He pointed out the window to a clock atop a crooked post. “It offended me with its incessant ticking.”

“Ten o’ clock, the time of the murder,” Dipper mumbled. He then regretted not bringing Mable along as he dragged the axe over for inspection. “So I guess you’ve never seen this before?”

“Listen here, little girl,” Dan barked.

“Uh, actually-”

“I wouldn’t pick my teeth with that axe. It’s left handed. I only use my right hand.” He demonstrated this by ripping the arm off of the machine. “The MANLY hand!”

As Manly Dan proceeded to beat the snot out of what remained of the machine, Dipper backed away, feeling that he’d been sufficiently emasculated for one day. He caught up with Mable doing some weird school yard fortune telling thing and gave her the update. They just had to run through the list of suspects and see who was left handed.

Unfortunately, that proved easier said than done. One montage later and it turned out that there wasn’t a single leftie in the whole town. Even when the twins thought they’d cornered someone, they learned far more than they ever wanted about Toby Determined. They did get an extra clue that the axe had no prints at all, but that just deepened the mystery. Worse, the cops laughed at them.

Defeated, the twins returned to the Mystery Shack to attend the funeral of Wax Stan. It was a tasteful ceremony held in the wax figures’ old room with all of their lifeless forms in attendance. To Soos and Stan it looked like the twins were down about the murder, but they were mourning another loss.

“Those cops were right about me,” Dipper grumbled in Mable’s lap.

“Come on, Dipper,” Mable encouraged, petting Dipper with one hand and holding the axe in another. “We’ve come so far. We can’t give up now.”

Dipper sighed, hopped down to the floor, and headed for the casket. “But I considered everything. The weapon, the motive, the clues…” He climbed up to get one last look at the dearly departed, where he noticed something odd. “Hmm. Wax Stan’s shoe has a hole in it.”

“All the wax guys have that,” Mable explained plainly. “It’s where the pole thingy attaches to their stand dealies.”

“What has holes in its shoes and no finger prints?” It didn’t take much before Dipper’s eyes went wide and his pulse quickened. “Uh, Mable!” he whispered in alarm. “I think the murderers are-”
11521111111.title: Wax Murder

115211111111.content:
“Standing right behind you,” finished Wax Sherlock Holmes as he and the other wax figures all came to life.

“Oh-my-gosh-oh-my-gosh-oh-my-gosh,” Mable panicked as the axed was ripped from her fingers by Wax Lizzie Borden, the infamous axe murderer. Naturally, Mable responded by immediately pulling her brother close for safety.

“Congratulations my two amateur sleuths. You uncovered the truth,” patronized the detective. “And now we’re going to bury you.” He pointed his magnifying glass like a weapon.

“But… how is this possible. You’re made of wax,” asserted Dipper in disbelief.

“Are you… magic?” asked Mable, giving in to her girlish wonder.

“Magic. She wants to know if we’re magic?” mocked Wax Sherlock before slamming his fist on the casket. “We’re cursed!”

“Cursed!” echoed the other figures.

“Cursed to come to life whenever the moon is waxing.”

“Uh, sorry to interrupt, but that doesn’t sound like a curse,” Dipper piped up. “Curses have more of a negative implication. Like if you were the real guys who were turned into wax. That’d be a curse.”

“Yeah,” agreed Mable. “Being able to come to life sounds like a blessing.”

Wax Sherlock, unable to think up a counterargument, decided to tell their backstory. After they were stolen from their previous owner, they were set up here for the wax museum. By day they were overpriced attractions, but at night they were free to do as they pleased. It was a pleasant life, all things considered, right up until the money stopped coming in and they were locked in here.

“Can I just say one more thing?” asked Dipper.

“Oh fine. Go ahead,” allowed an annoyed Wax Sherlock.

The minizora pointed at Wax Lizzie. “You have an axe. If you didn’t like being locked up, you could have just broken out at any night.”

“And go where, hmm? You want us to be caught out in the sunlight just like Wax Lincoln?”

“I’m also not seeing how the wax museum stopped making money,” Mable added. “I mean, it doesn’t take much to maintain you guys. Stan would have just had to do a minimal cleaning, like, once a week, which isn’t that expensive. You’ve been locked up for years and you all look in pretty good shape.”

“Thank you,” said Wax Shakespeare.

“I just… I really don’t see why you guys would be locked up in the first place. At the very least you’d be making enough money to cover the cost of cleaning.”

Wax Sherlock snorted. “That’s because your uncle is a big fat jerk.”

“Granted,” allowed Dipper. “Hold on. You guys ever see Night at the Museum?”

“I loved that movie,” gushed Mable. “Robin Williams makes everything good.”

“It’s this movie about museum exhibits that also come to life at night.” Dipper explained to the intrigue of the figures. “The museum was about to be shut down, so they solved the problem by the end by opening the museum to night guests. That way it’s like there’s a big animatronic t-rex skeleton in the front lobby and a Wax Teddy Roosevelt who can talk with people about the real Roosevelt’s life.”

Pipe in one hand and Wax Stan’s head in the other, Sherlock’s brow made a climb up his forehead. “What are you getting at?”

“Maybe you guys could do the same. Show Grunkle Stan that you’re really alive. We can basically employ you guys and extend the Shack’s open hours.”

“Hey, yeah!” cheered Mable. “You can be the evening crew. Give tours, talk about yourselves, and jack up prices.”

“So you guys would be able to walk free at night, and the Mystery Shack would make more money. Everyone wins.”

“Uh, hold that thought.” Sherlock motioned for the other wax figures to all gather at the far end of the room while they discussed this alternative.

“Do you think they’ll buy it?” Mable whispered through a forced grin.

“No clue, but try scooching closer to the fire,” urged Dipper. “Their wax, so we can just melt them if things get bad.”

“Good idea.” And she discretely shuffled her way over to the fireplace to await the figures’ verdict.
115211111111.title: Wax Man Uprising

1152111111111.content:
The wax conference concluded as the figures approached the twins. “Sorry kids, but no dice. We’ve been waiting ten years to get our revenge,” he flipped the Wax Stan head around in his hand, “and next time we won’t miss.”

“So you were trying to murder Grunkle Stan for real?” asked Dipper in alarm.

“Enough, you little pipsqueaks! Now that you know our secret. You must die!”

“You first.” Mable then wielded the fire poker like a javelin, hurling it at Wax John Wilks Booth’s head and spearing it to the wall. “Haha, got’ch’ya!” Her cheer was short lived when the body kept moving and the remaining wax figures just looked peeved. “Oops.”

“The candles!” Dipper pointed over to where Grunkle Stan had set up a refreshment table, including a pair of electric candles. Mable wielded hers like a sword easily enough. Dipper, through much effort, wielded his like a human trying to manage an artillery cannon without wheels. “Get back or we’ll melt you into candles!”

“Decorative candles,” Mable added threateningly.

The wax figures were intimidated at first, but then they remembered that they had the advantage in both size and numbers. “You really think you can defeat us?”

“Eh. Worth a shot.”

“So be it. Attack!”

The first casualty of the battle was Dipper’s footing as the weight of the candle threw him off balance and he fell to the floor. When Mable turned to retrieve him, she accidentally severed Shakespeare’s arms. Dipper recovered to find the wax figures closing in on Mable from all sides, clearly judging her to be the bigger threat.

“Never underestimate the little guy,” Dipper muttered before rolling his candle with all due haste, melting a good many feet all the way up to the ankle. In one case, Wax Robin Hood tripped and knocked Wax Larry King over, who then fell neck first onto the candle and was subsequently decapitated. “Ha! Interview that, Larry King! You alright Mable?” He turned to his sister, and were they not in mortal danger, he would have burst out laughing.

Mable was using the severed Coolio’s head like a mace, swinging it by the hair to bludgeon the other figures, knocking them back while she retrieved her candle. With her primary weapon retrieved, the little girl made a lunge for Wax Lizzie, but came up short and only tore her dress open. The adrenaline evaporated almost instantly as everyone paused to gawk. “Uh… wow.”

Wax Lizzie’s hands shot down to cover her exposed groin. “Don’t look!”

“I mean… damn. I knew waxing was kind of a more recent thing but… wow. You’d need a freaking lawnmower to trim that bush.”

“Sh-shut up!” cried the wax woman.

“I’m more concerned that someone took the time to make her that way,” commented Dipper. “All these other guys have their clothes as part of their bodies, but her…” He gestured. “Someone sculpted her to not only go commando, but also have a bush big enough to hide a whole person.”

As the other wax figures began snickering at Lizzie’s plight, her cheeks began to burn from embarrassment. They burned so hot that she ended up melting herself. Once everyone got the giggles out of their system, the fight resumed.

Wax Sherlock finally did something smart by tossing the Stan head aside and grabbing a real sword off the wall. Dipper’s candle was smashed in short order. In response, Mable found a broken sliver of metal near the fire place and threw it to Dipper.

“Catch!”

It was hot on both ends, but not enough to harm minizora skin. “Uh, thanks, but how do I fight a sword with a toothpick?”

“Figure it out,” Mable urged, once more being swarmed by the remaining figures. “Die Nixon!”

With Wax Sherlock in pursuit, Dipper could only avoid and evade his strikes. Thankfully he had a lifetime of experience to help him through, but he was ever on the retreat. He knew there was only one chance. The minizora dove out the window and began ascending the Mystery Shack’s roof, once more demonstrating the climbing skills of a mountain goat.

“You think you can outwit me, boy? I’m Sherlock bleeding Holmes! Have you seen my magnifying glass? It’s enormous,” ranted the wax man as he haphazardly swung his sword around and dislodged the big S from the sign. Eventually he cornered Dipper, pinning him to the shingled roof with his shoe. Wax Sherlock tried increasing the pressure to crush the boy like a bug, but the minizora only laughed.

“That the best you got?” he wheezed.

“Grr. So be it.” Wax Sherlock raised his sword high. “Any last words?”

“Yeah actually. Got any sunblock?”

“Got any-?” Wax Sherlock was cut off by the drip-drop of wax dripping onto his nose. His hands were liquefying and he lost his grip on the sword. He then turned and beheled the golden glow of the sun peeking over the forested horizon. “… no.”

“Letting me lead you to the roof? Yeah, probably not your sharpest decision,” Dipper taunted.

“Outsmarted by a child in short pants, and a minizora at that. Nooo!”

Any feelings Dipper might have had for killing a person were rendered null at that moment. “Sucks to be you, buddy. All my life guys like you have been looking down on me. But in just another minute, I’ll be looking down on you!”

Sure enough, with each passing second, Wax Sherlock lost more and more height, along with facial features. And then, just as the wax man was finally shorter than the minizora and Dipper was about to deliver the last word, he sneezed. “Ha-ha-ha. you sneeze like a kitten,” ranted the wax puddle in a mad delirium. “Those policemen were right. You’re adorable. Adorablllllle.”

*Splat*

His thunder stolen, Dipper heaved a sigh and returned to the wax room. Mable was just finishing up with chucking severed wax limbs into the fire.

“Dipper, you’re okay!” Mable rushed over and scooped him up, holding him tight to her cheek. “You solved the mystery after all.”

“See, I told you I can handle myself,” he strained to say. Mable’s grip was more constraining than Wax Sherlock’s shoe, so he tapped her cheek to signal her to loosen up. “And I couldn’t have done it without my sidekick.”

Mable giggled and picked up the Wax Stan head from the floor. “No offense Dipper, but you’re the sidekick.”

“What? Says who? Are-are people saying that? Who’s saying that?” Dipper asked self-consciously.

“Aww, don’t be down. You’re still the best sidekick a hero like me could ever want.” And she gave him a big wet kiss that encompassed most of his head. “Ew. You taste like wax.”

When Grunkle Stan came in to the warzone of a room, he was immediately placated with the presentation of his missing head. His reward was some affectionate noogying. That was nice, but far more gratifying was when the police pulled up and the twins had evidence of having solved the case. It didn’t matter that no one believed them about the wax people. What mattered was the hilarious sight of two cops spitting scalding hot coffee in one another’s faces.
1152111111111.title: War of Wax

11521111111111.content:
It was early morning in the Mystery Shack when Soos was on break and decided to join Dipper and Mable in the TV room. Mable held her brother in her lap as her fingers idly fiddled with his tiny form. So long as his vision was unobstructed, he made no complaint, not even when she poked his butt.

“Hey, its that commercial I was telling you guys about,” Soos informed.

Said commercial was for some self-proclaimed psychic over at the Tent of Telepathy. That there was an unflattering video of Grunkle Stan towards the end only confirmed that these people were his direct competition for, as their dear old Grunkle would so eloquently say: “Fleecing roobs.” And when Stan forbid them from going to the show that evening, their childish rebellion left them with no choice but to visit.

With nothing better to do while they waited for the evening, the twins went up to their room to relax. After the door was locked and blinds closed, Mable removed her sweater to give her chest some open air. “Ahh, much better.”

“Seriously? As far as summer days go, this one’s pretty mild.”

“What can I say? I’m just,” Mable tittered, “one hot mamma.”

“Eh. I’ve heard worse,” Dipper allowed as he opened up the journal. He didn’t even make it to the second line before being picked up by his shirt. “Hey, what gives?”

“Just giving you an extra special study spot, bro-bro,” Mable graciously said as she laid on her back and rested her brother down atop her chest. “Hehe.”

“Um, uh, sure, I guess,” Dipper accepted of his sister’s silliness. Mable’s breasts weren’t anything to write home about, but they weren’t completely flat. There was enough there for Dipper to rest his head on like a pillow.

“Hehe. Comfy?” she asked, using her elbows to try and press her breasts together.

“Good enough,” answered Dipper distractedly, trying to ignore the way Mable pouted.

“Hmph. I bet you’d notice if Shandra Jimenez put you on her chest.”

“Mable, she’s like in her late thirties. Plus I’d bet those things are plastic. There’s no need to get-”

“Don’t you say it!” Mable accused, her finger pointed like a deadly weapon at the boy resting against her tiny boob. “I am not jealous.”

“Hey, if anyone around here is going to be insecure about their size, it’s going to be me. Got that.”

Mable huffed and turned away. “At least you could show me a little affection now and then.”

“Now and then? Mable, I was literally in your mouth this morning.”

“That was me showing you affection. I’m always the one doing the petting, the hugging, the licking, and all that stuff. Maybe you could throw a little sugar my way once in a while.” Her tone was pleading and her eyes were doing that shimmery thing that she knew Dipper couldn’t resist.

“Okay fine,” Dipper surrendered, closing the book as he was clearly not going to get any reading done until Mable was satisfied. “First, put this up so it won’t get damaged.”

Mable happily obliged and set the book on her dresser. As she did, her frown started to turn upside down as Dipper undressed. She clapped her hands and kicked her legs in anticipation of the fun that was coming. “Ee-he-he! Naked Dipper is best Dipper.”

“Uh huh. Sure,” Dipper agreed dispassionately as he threw his underwear off to the side. Standing there in the buff atop his bare-chested sister, the minizora was still as soft as a noodle. Just being naked and looking at his half naked sister did nothing for him. It’d take some serious stimulation to give Mable what she wanted, but that got Dipper to thinking. “So if you want me to show some affection for a change, then you’re gonna have to commit to it.”

“What do you mean?”

“I mean you gotta sit on your hands. Literally. If we’re doing this, then I’m in charge. You can’t do anything. For once, you’re the one who just has to sit back and let your twin have their way with you.”

“Oh wow. So forceful,” giggled Mable as she slid her hands under her bottom. “I like it.”

Dipper gave a curt nod. “Good. Now, let’s see here.” After a second of surveying the smooth landscape beneath his feet, deciding a course of action, the minizora returned to his sister’s chest lumps and climbed up onto the nipple. Mable moaned quietly, but that was just a taste of what he had planned. Dipper dropped down onto his belly, pressing his limp dick against the little girl’s nipple. “Ohhhh,” he shuddered, having not expected it to feel that good.

“I feel it,” Mable moaned. “I feel your itty bitty weewee against my nippy. Te-he.”

“Baby talk only makes this weirder,” Dipper informed as he began experimentally grinding himself against the nub. He rotated his hips around in circles, trying to cover as much surface area as possible with his crotch. The texture of her nipple skin was different than her hands in a way that Dipper couldn’t put into words. It felt amazing, though. Mable moaned all the louder as she fought to keep her body still. A grin grew across Dipper’s face as he came to terms with the control he now exerted over his sister. “Wow. So this is what’s it’s like to be in charge.”

“Pretty great, huh.”

“No kidding,” he agreed while pressing his erection into her hardened nub. The friction of foreign skin against his sensitive prick combined with the knowledge of who he was humping; all adding up for some pretty amazing stimulation.

“D-Dipper,” moaned Mable. “When you’re in my mouth, and I make you cum with my tongue, you taste sooo gooood.”

“I… figured,” Dipper panted, now getting into the swing of things. “It’s not just your tongue, though. I think every part of you is amazing.”

“R-really?” Mable had never done much with her flat chest before, having always dismissed it as too underdeveloped to play with. However, as Dipper was demonstrating, she was a lot more sensitive around there than she’d initially believed. “C-can I play with the other one?” she begged.

The minizora shook his head. “Uh-uh. This isn’t about you feeling good. This is about me showing my sister some affection, remember. I’m showing you what a minizora can do, and you’re gonna sit back and take it,” he growled, trying to channel some of Manly Dan’s authority. “Damn, you’re sensitive.”

“H-harder!” Mable begged. With Dipper’s stupid rule in place, she was powerless to do much. However, with him preoccupied with her chest, she was able to arch her back just enough to slip both hands beneath her skirt. The angle wasn’t ideal for doing much and still maintain discretion, but it would have to do. Unable to think clearly, Mable attacked both her ass and pussy, make believing that her fingers were Dipper. Lots of little Dippers, all rubbing and humping to their little hearts’ content, and all at her command. They were doing this for her. The little Dippers were rubbing their little bodies against her most sensitive parts because she wanted them to, because they loved her and wanted to make her happy.

“Hegakurgurk!” Dipper gasped, his ejaculation jumping out at him like a snake. His body spasamed and he lost his grip, collapsing onto the erect nipple.
