Somehow, Mable was able to feel that tiny splash of liquid onto her nub. That combined with the stimulation from her hands to push her over the edge. Reflexively, she broke the rule by bringing the hand from her ass up and clamping it over her mouth to keep herself silent. It was a habit born out of having done this so many times at their parents’ home.

The two siblings, naked and half naked, laying atop the other and the bed respectively, panted. Their chests rose and fell with labored breaths, their bodies were all sweaty, and their groins were especially sticky. Dipper, to the surprise of no one, called upon his minizora endurance to recover first and stand. Hands on his hips and cock contentedly soft, he proudly surveyed his good work before smirking up at Mable’s face.

“You cheated,” he playfully pointed out, indicating her hand.

Mable, still recovering, scowled down at the minizora. Through her fingers she said, “Screw off.”

Dipper scratched his chin, pretending to think. “Hmm. Sure.” And he began walking off. “I need a shower anyway.” But before he could jump from the little girl’s body, a hand snatched him up and brought him to the little girl’s big glowering face. “Don’t tell me you’re going to be a sore loser about this,” he said with a punchable smirk. “Fair’s fair. You agreed to the rules, so that means-agh!” His lecture was cut short after being tossed in his sister’s mouth.

“Nom!” Mable pushed him into her cheek like a chipmunk storing food, not really up to a proper taste session. She just casually licked and sucked as strength returned to her body. When feeling returned to her legs, she headed for the bathroom and poured herself a glass of water. With Dipper secured with her tongue, she drank around him in an effort to punish him. Now internally refreshed, she looked herself in the mirror and did her best to speak around her mouthful. “You’re the best brother ever, and I hate you for it.”

It was impossible for Dipper not to grin.
11521111111111.title: Passing the Time

115211111111111.content:
With the twins cleaned up and the adults none the wiser, Dipper, Mable, and Soos paid their visit to the Tent of Telepathy. At the entrance there was a man named Bud Gleeful. A portly man, he was holding out a bag to accept ‘donations’ into what he called Gideon’s Psychic Sack.

“You think he knows what that sounds like?” Mable whispered to her shoulder rider.

“Given what we’ve seen so far from this town, I have no idea.” Dipper looked around the tent. “This whole place is like a bizarro version of the Mystery Shack. They even have their own Soos.”

When the audience was seated, the lights dimmed and the curtains rose. The person at the center of all this hype was just a pale freckled kid. He’d be only half as tall without his hair and there was something off about how he would bat his eyelashes.

“That’s Stan’s mortal enemy?” Dipper said in disbelief, suddenly having a far lower opinion of the old man for considering this kid a threat.

“But he’s so… little.”

“Hey!”

“Little by big people standards,” assured Mable.

Dipper continued to be unimpressed as Gideon went through his performance, discerning ‘secrets’ about his audience members that were obvious to anyone who wasn’t blind. “How are these people buying this? He’s just doing cold reading. It’s literally the oldest trick in the book.”

“How’d he do that?” Mable awed after Gideon had guessed her name to the beat of an annoyingly catching song.

“It’s literally written on your shirt,” griped Dipper. He did not care for how his sister was looking at this chubby kid like he was made of glitter. The minizora was all too glad when the show finally ended. “Man, that kid’s an even bigger fraud than Stan. No wonder our uncle’s jealous.”

“Oh come on. His dance moves were adorable. And did you see his hair? It was like… whoosh!”

“You’re too easily impressed.” The twins then descended into a poking war, laughing as they left through the parking lot and completely unaware that they were being watched.

The next morning, Mable was feeling a little glum. She’d just bedazzled her face and Dipper didn’t seem the least bit impressed. Then when there was a knock at the door, she decided to cheer herself up by talking to a potential stranger. “Ahh! It’s wittle old you!” she gasped at the sight of Gideon’s hair, followed by Gideon.

“Heh-heh. Yeah, my song’s quite catchy,” Gideon laughed a bit apprehensively. “I know we haven’t formally met, but after yesterday’s performance, I just couldn’t get your laugh out of my head.”

“Oh, you mean this one? Ah-ha-hahahaaa.”

“What a delight.”

The two continued their little back and forth, mostly about their mutual appreciation for sparkly things. Mable even covered for him when Stan asked who was at the door. And then Gideon invited her over to visit his dressing room.

“One sec.” Mable ran back to the dining room. “Hey Dipper. Gideon just invited me to his dressing room to play dress up. You wanna-”

“Oh, would you look at the time,” Dipper said, pointing to his nonexistent watch. “I have to be… somewhere!” And he made himself scarce.

Deciding that Dipper would be safe enough at the Shack, Mable accompanied Gideon for a few hours of dress up. All the while she remained utterly oblivious to the subtle and less-than-subtle hints the short stack kept dropping. When she returned, showing off her new do, she was once more confronted by an unimpressed Dipper.

“Mable, I don’t trust anyone whose hair is bigger than their head.”

“Oh leave him alone,” Mable snapped. “You never want to do girly stuff with me. You and Soos get to do boy stuff all the time.”

“What do you mean? We did that… thing, yesterday.”

“That was a minizora twin thing, not a girly thing.” In no mood to argue, Mable returned to Gideon for some quality feminine hanging out time. They’d found a nice roof high up on a cliff that provided a great view of the town.

“You know Mable, when I’m up here looking down on all them little old people, I feel like I’m king of all I survey,” he whispered in a low menace. “I guess that makes you my queen.”

“Whaaat? You are being so nice to me right now,” Mable gushed. She slapped him in the gut and said, “Quit it.”

“I can’t quit it, Mable. I’m speakin’ from the heart.”

“From the where now?” Mable asked, finally noticing the red flags. Sixty third one’s the charm, as they say. But alas, she was unable to get out of his invitation to a date.

Back at the Shack, Mable was trying to get her mind off the not-date with some video games. “It’s not a date-date. It’s just, you know, I didn’t want to hurt his feelings, so I figured I’d throw him a bone.”

“Mable, guys don’t work that way,” informed the wise tiny on her shoulder. “This is called ‘leading a guy on’. You’re building his hopes up, despite having no real intention of getting serious. I know I’d be pretty mad if a girl did that to me.”

Mable scoffed. “Oh what do you know? Not like you’ve ever dated anyone.”

“Maybe not, but you know all those times you stuffed me in your underwear with nothing to do but read those minizora cutouts from your girly magazines? Well those things are mostly trash and even they agree that what you’re doing is, at best, a dick move.”

“You’re a dick move.”

When the doorbell rang, Mable set Dipper aside to open it, expecting Gideon. She was right, but she hadn’t been expecting him to be on a horse, or to call her mi’lady.

“Oh boy.”

The longer the not-date at the fanciest restaurant in town went on, the harder it was for Mable to convince herself that this wasn’t a real date. There was an indoor fountain, aromatic flowers, more utensils than she knew what to do with, French stuff, and an overall creepy vibe as everyone – even the other guests – seemed to bend over backwards for Gideon. Was he some kind of cult leader or something? Mable asked herself this after that one couple begged Gideon to bless their newborn baby.
115211111111111.title: Wittle ol' Me

1152111111111111.content:
Upon learning that that ‘little gremlin’ was dating his great niece, Grunkle Stan stomped right out of the shack to put a stop to this once and for all. He drove up to Gideon’s less-than-humble abode, fully prepared to curb stomp the little piglet, and maybe his stupid faced father while he was at it. Bud, however, proved his smooth talking prowess and quickly diffused the situation. And even as committed as Grunkle Stan was at the start, once the prospect of making more money was brought up, he was putty in Bud’s hands.

Back at the Shack, Dipper was sitting on the store counter while Wendy – without customers or Stan around – wasn’t even pretending to work.

“You seem down, squirt. Wanna talk about it?”

Dipper sighed. “I don’t know. Mable being on a date is just kind of weird for me. Does that make sense?”

“Oh, totally. First time my brother brought home a girl, my first instinct was to kick that little bitch’s teeth in. It’s perfectly normal, dude.”

Dipper laughed nervously. “Did you… do it?”

“No way, man. Go around kicking little kids in the teeth? That’s how cops get called and you’re sent off to juvi for, like, ever. The trick is to play nice at the start. Smile, get to know ‘em, learn their weaknesses,” she added darkly. “That way, if it turns out they’re jerks, you can just blackmail them into breaking up.”

Dipper laughed more sincerely this time. “I can’t tell if that’s super sweet or super creepy.”

“Its family,” Wendy stated plainly while opening a soda. “They’re all a bunch of idiots, so you gotta do what you gotta do to keep ‘em safe.”

“Wow. You are really smart.” And pretty. Dipper looked around, wondering who’d just said that.

“Nah. My mom told me that. She’s good with this kind of stuff.”

“Well, you came from her, so you’ve gotta have some of her smarts too, right?”

“That’s sweet of you to say, but I’m pretty tame compared to my folks. People think my dad is intense, but mom can be a demon when she gets upset. This one time I brought a guy home, I’d left him in the living room to powder my nose. Anyway, just as I come back out, the window breaks. The dude actually jumped out the closed window to get away. Dad was sweatin’ bullets while mom…” Wendy trailed off, laughing nervously. “Anyway, the point is that it’s perfectly natural to not trust your family’s dates.”

“But this isn’t a date,” Dipper insisted. “Well, Mable says it isn’t. Her words were ‘throw him a bone’,” he said with air quotes.

Wendy sucked in a breath like she’d stubbed her toe.

“I know, right.” Dipper fell back on the counter and stared up at the ceiling. “If I were there I could help. I could be a little shoulder angel and whisper what she should do to break things off as quickly and painlessly as possible.”

Wendy smiled kindly. “Mable’s lucky to have a brother like you.” She tapped at the table as a thought occurred. “Um, this might sound weird, but would it be okay if I… pet you?”

Dipper frowned thoughtfully. “Huh. I think that might be the first time someone’s ever asked.”

“So is it weird?”

“I mean, only if we make it. Mable and my parents just do whatever they want. Whenever some stranger tried reaching for me, Mable would just bite their fingers. But if you’re going to ask, then sure. Go right ahead.” Dipper laid himself flat on the counter, suddenly feeling far more vulnerable than a few seconds ago.

Biting her bottom lip and with much trepidation, Wendy reached out with a single digit extended and touched Dipper’s chest. Nothing happened, but she still exhaled her relief. She didn’t know what she was expecting. She’d played with dolls before, but that didn’t seem like an adequate comparison. This was a minizora. His chest rose and fell with his breathing and he was warm to the touch. Wendy’s instincts told her that this was a fragile creature that needed protecting, but common sense suggested otherwise. Minizora were tough, people said. They could handle all kinds of things that would kill a regular person. And yet this knowledge contradicted so starkly with what she was feeling right now. At that moment, she wanted nothing more than to hold this little guy.

Dipper, meanwhile, was in a similarly perplexing predicament. A stranger was touching him, and he was okay with that. She was petting him, showing the same sort of everyday affection he was accustomed to from family. Much to his own surprise, he was totally relaxed, not even feeling the usual tension of going to the doctor. Did he trust Wendy that much? How far did that trust go?

That’s when the doorbell jingled, startling the counter people to straighten up and attempt to look as innocent as possible.

“Oh, h-hey Mable,” Dipper strained to say. “How did the… what happened?”

Mable gave a long and drawn out groan, not even looking up as she trudged into the shop.

“Whoa, dude. Normally I’d think she’d just broken up, but you said she didn’t want to date him,” Wendy observed.

“She didn’t.” Full of purpose, Dipper hopped down the makeshift staircase from the counter and scurried off after Mable.

Wendy smiled as she watched him go and rested her chin on her hand. “There goes a pretty cool brother.”

When Dipper finally caught up with Mable, he found her having had withdrawn her limbs and retreated into her sweater like a turtle. “Mable.”

“Mable’s not here. She’s in sweater town.”

“Are you going to come out of sweater town?”

Mable whimpered and shook her head.

“Then can I come in?”

After a second’s thought, Mable stuck her hand out of the bottom and motioned him forward. Dipper climbed on and let himself be pulled up to his dower sister’s face. Everything was cast in shadow, including her bare chest, but the minizora kept his eyes on what mattered.

“How bad was it?”

“I agreed to a second date.”

“How?” Dipper asked incredulously, his tone just making Mable feel worse. “I mean, you had a plan. Say you just want to be friends, and then be friends. No more dates.”

“You don’t understand. He had a talking bird, and the rainbow machine, and this one lady said she’d die of sadness if I didn’t say yes. She even had a doctor confirm it.”

Dipper suddenly became less sympathetic. “So someone you never met just happens to be so invested in you dating Gideon that they’d die otherwise? And they just happen to have a doctor there to make sure you’re manipulated into doing what Gideon wants?”

“Well…”

“Mable, he’s just like Grunkle Stan: a showman and a con artist. I’d bet anything that those people were just actors planted to guilt you into dating Gideon.”

“Now hold on a second. He’s not… that controlling.”

“Ah! You hesitated,” Dipper pointed out. “So you do think he’s that controlling.”

“Great news, Mable,” announced Grunkle Stan with a beaming grin and a ‘Team Gideon’ shirt. “You have to marry Gideon.”

“What!?” the twins exclaimed together, both poking their heads out of the sweater.

“It’s part of my long-term plan with Buddy Gleeful. There’s a lot of cash tied up in this thing. I even got this shirt.” Then he wandered off, muttering about how bodies change.

“Okay, that’s it!” Dipper stomped his foot on Mable’s palm. “Enough is enough. If you can’t break up with Gideon, then I’ll do it.”

“You will?” awed Mable.

“Hey, remember that talk about the rabbits and feeling lousy.”

“Oh thank-you-thank-you-thank-you,” Mable gushed, pelting Dipper’s body in grateful kisses while he offered up only a token resistance.
1152111111111111.title: Plans Laid

11521111111111111.content:
The next day, while Mable stayed home to avoid the paparazzi, Dipper grabbed a ride from Soos to pay Gideon a visit. He entered the second fanciest establishment in Gravity Falls and it certainly fit the title. Seriously, how does a place like this stay open when the number of locals who can afford to eat here can be counted on one hand? Anyway, the minizora held his head high and strutted inside like he belonged there. Although he did find it odd that a place this expensive didn’t have some kind of security to keep people like him out.
Upon arriving at Gideon’s private booth, Dipper ascended the table cloth and cleared his throat.
“Ah, Dipper Pines. How are you? You look good, you look good.” Gideon’s greeting sounded like he’d been rehearsing for a school play. “You know Mable has told me quite a lot about you.”
“Whatever it is, it’s all lies.” Dipper strained to smile at his bad joke.
“Really? Because whenever the topic of you came up, it was often accompanied with words like reliable, dedicated, fun, and various synonyms that made my beloved ever so happy.” He laughed that cutesy laugh of his before shifting to a whispered intensity. “She seems quite fond of you.”
More and more Dipper was having a hard time understanding why Mable couldn’t say no to this guy. If he’d been in her position, he’d have thrown himself out the window and booked it like Wendy’s old boyfriend by now. “Look buddy. We’ve got to talk. Mable isn’t going to join you tonight. She, uh, doesn’t want to see you anymore,” he laughed uncomfortably. “Sh-she’s kind of weirded out by you. No offense.”
Gideon just kept on smiling that serene, creepy smile of his. The only indicator that he wasn’t the picture of happiness was the twitching in his left eye. “So, what you’re saying is, you’ve come between us.”
“Look man, some people just don’t click. It’s not really anyone’s fault, except maybe yours. Uh, you’re not going to freak out or anything, are you?”
“Of course not,” Gideon tittered like a little schoolgirl. “These things happen. Bygones and all that.”
“Okay cool. Sorry again man, but I, uh, gotta go,” explained Dipper as he backed away, unwilling to turn his back on the giant shorty.
When Dipper made it back to Mable and gave her the news, her hug about crushed the life out of him.
The next day, while everything seemed back to normal, Toby Determined called wanting to interview Dipper about the unusual happenings he’d seen in town. The minizora was all too excited, right up until he was given the time and place for the meeting.
“Who was it?” Mable asked.
“Toby Determined. He wants to interview me, alone, after dark, in an abandoned building on the outskirts of town.”
Mable blinked. “That’s literally the opening scene of the horror movie we watched last night.”
“Pretty generic, if you ask me,” Dipper agreed nonchalantly.
“You’re not going, are you?”
“Well obviously I have to. If someone’s going through the trouble of setting a trap, I’d like to know who they are so we can keep an eye out for next time.”
Mable did not care for this answer and not-so-gently grabbed her brother. “But what if you get hurt?”
“Hey, no big deal. It’s not like I’m going alone.” He bounced his eyebrows suggestively and gave a winning smile.
“Wha? Oh. Ohhh! Hehe, good thinking.”
Entering the old warehouse at the appointed time, Dipper was greeted only by darkness. Was this actually just a prank and not a trap? The light at the far end of the room ominously shining onto a swivel chair suggested otherwise.
“Hello friend,” greeted Gideon, spinning around in his chair and, in place of a super villain’s cat, petting a little doll of himself.
Dipper blinked. “Somehow this is way creepier than the horror movie.” It was honestly rather impressive.
“Let me tell you, boy. This town has secrets you can’t begin to comprehend,” Gideon threatened, shaking his fist.
“The only secret here is how you can delude yourself like this. I told you, Mable’s not into you.”
“You liar!” Gideon screamed shrilly. As he hopped off the chair and began marching toward the minizora, his hand gripped tightly on the green amulet on his shirt collar. “You turned her against me. She was my peach dumplin’!”
“Aaare you okay man?” Dipper asked, fighting his tiny instincts to run. Running just made the bullies want to give chase. Besides, he was confident he could take any blows this pipsqueak could dish out. And when his body was encased in a green aura that matched Gideon’s amulet, followed by being hurled across the room into the brick wall, Dipper had second thoughts about running. “Oh crap!”
Outside the warehouse, hidden behind a tree, Mable was left to stew in her own thoughts as she searched for any signs of danger. In hindsight, that first date really had been a dick move, but letting Dipper break up for her had been an even bigger dick move. Gideon might have his… quirks, but he at least deserved an honest break up. As soon as this hole trap thing was sorted out, she’d march over to his house and do things right.
Inside the warehouse…
“Ahhhh!” Dipper was getting more exercise in the last few minutes than the last couple years. Everywhere he turned there was something floating, flying at him, dropping on him, or maybe gravity would just have a hiccup and he’d be the one sent flying. There just comes a point in a young man’s life when he can’t help but think that a bully giving swirlies is the lesser evil.
“Once you’re out of the way, Mable will be all mine! Mwahahaha!”
“You really are insane,” Dipper spat as he was lifted high in the air. “If anything happens to me, she’ll know who to blame. She’ll hate you forever.”
“Oh, I don’t think so,” tittered Gideon as he levitated a pair of scissors up to the minizora. “You underestimate just how persuasive I can be. Te-he.”
Mable threw the doors open. “Gideon, we have to talk.”
“M-Mable? My marshmallow. Wh-what are you doin’ here?” asked Gideon in a rare moment of uncertainty. He knew things looked bad, and so quickly discarded the scissors in the hopes that Mable hadn’t seen them yet.
“I’m sorry, Gideon, but I can’t be your marshmallow,” Mable answered calmly, not even paying Dipper a glance. “And I need to be honest and tell you that myself.”
After all of his denial, Gideon finally looked crestfallen. “I-I don’t understand.”
With an inviting smile, Mable approached with hands outstretched in friendship. “Hey, we can still be makeover buddies, right. Wouldn’t you like that?”
“Really?” asked Gideon hopefully, only for that hope to be snatched right off his neck.
“No, not really!” snarled Mable, the magic amulet in hand and out of Gideon’s reach. The magic faded and Dipper dropped to the ground. “You were attacking my brother. What the hell?” And she slapped him across the face with a thunderous thwack.
“N-now Mable, I can explain.”
“No. Fuck your explanations!” She slapped him every other word. “Fuck you! Fuck you forever! Go fuck yourself! You fuck!”
Every f bomb was like a stab into Gideon’s heart. How could his sweet peach suddenly grow so sour? Then the amulet started glowing again, only this time its glow encompassed Gideon’s body and he floated helplessly before Mable.
“Let me make this as clear as possible,” Mable hissed. “I will never date you. You crossed a line and now I will never even like you.” She then spent about a minute experimenting with the durability of Gideon’s face vs. the floor. “If you ever come near me or my family again, I will end you!” Teeth bared, she crushed the amulet in her bare hand, ending its power forever and dropping Gideon. “Now get out.”
“Okay fine. I’ll leave,” Gideon conceded, backing away with a limp. “But I promise. This isn’t the last you’ve seen of Wittle. Ol’. M-”
“Get out!”
“Agh! Ah’m gettin’!”
Dipper waited until things quieted down. “W-wow Mable. I-I’ve never seen that side of you be-”
“Wha-ha-ha!” Mable cried as she flung herself onto Dipper, tears gushing from her eyes. “You idiot! You stupid, stupid idiot! You knew it was a trap, but you still went anyway. That shit almost cut you with scissors. You can’t handle scissors!”
Dipper opened his mouth, but didn’t know what to say. He could point out that there were factors that couldn’t have been accounted for, that he’s withstood worse and maybe could have handled the scissors, or that Mable had agreed to this whole plan, but he couldn’t see any of those arguments ending well for him. And with the tears of his beloved sister ripping his heart out, he finally settled on something to say. “You protected me.”
Mable took a break from her constricting embrace and pulled back enough to look Dipper in the eye. She was ugly crying and hated that he was seeing her like this. However, there was something about his smile that lifted her spirits just a tad.
“I knew I’d be fine, because you protected me like you always do.”
Mable fell right back to bawling, but with most of the fear and anger removed. Now there was only relief mixed with a bit of joy that everything was alright. No more words were exchanged as the pair sat there in the warehouse, holding one another for comfort.
When Gideon finally made it back home, the first thing he did was have Stanford Pines tossed out. The merger of their families was off. As far as he was concerned, this was a full and proper feud. It hardly mattered that Stan stole an expensive painting on the way out. Oh, there would be recompense and it would go far beyond petty thievery. This, Gideon knew with absolute certainty. He knew it because in a secret compartment at his desk, there was a book; an itty bitty minizora book. It bore no title. Just a little six fingered hand and the number 2 on the cover.
11521111111111111.title: Rejection

115211111111111111.content:
Over the next couple of days, Mable was being especially clingy with Dipper, which he wasn’t too bothered by. They’d both gone through some pretty heavy stuff: him almost dying and her having to watch her most favorite person suffer. They were each other’s comfort object. Ever since they were little, their default response to any kind of stress had always been to seek out the other. That was the case now, with Dipper offering no complaint even when Mable insisted on escorting or being escorted by him to the bathroom. And right now, the twins were undertaking a heavy emotional ordeal. They were going to be within two feet of one another, but not actually touch. This was an important step in their recovery process.
At the entrance to the gift shop, Mable was sitting on a spinning globe. “Hehe. My butt is crushing Canada.”
“Mable, do you believe in ghosts?” Dipper asked while flipping through the journal.
“I believe that you’re a big dork. Haha.” For her impudence, Dipper pressed a pencil into the globe, bringing it to an abrupt halt and sending his sister flying. “Ow.”
The bell rung and Stan poked his head in the door. “Soos. Wendy. I’m headin’ out. You two are going to wash the bathrooms, right?”
“Yes sir.” “Absolutely not,” they answered respectively, each with a firm salute.
“Haha. You stay out of trouble.” With his old man scowl delivered, Stan departed for parts unknown and deeds most likely of the extra-legal variety.
“Hey guys. What’s this?” Wendy called, gesturing over to a mysterious curtain in the corner. “Is it a secret ladder to the roof?” Pulling back the curtain, she revealed that it was just that.
Soos was reluctant, but the teen was easily able to bring the preteens onboard. She even showed them to her secret cot and cooler.
“Wow, did you put all this up here?” awed Dipper. “Huh. Funny I didn’t notice any of this when Sherloc-er, never mind.”
Wendy gave her hair a casual flip. “I may or may not sneak up here during work… all the time, every day.” She then grabbed a pinecone from a bucket and tossed it across the lot and hit a target that had been strapped to the plastic tiki tower. “Yes!”
“Oh I want to try,” squealed Mable as she grabbed an armful and began chucking the things, each round coming up short.
Not wanting to be left out, Dipper figured he might as well try. His pinecone hit someone’s car and set off the alarm. At first his gut sank in fear that he’d just royally screwed up, but Wendy’s laugh said otherwise.
“Ha-ha-ha, jacpot!” Bending down with one hand on her knee, she extended her other palm down to Dipper’s level. “High five.”
Dipper suffered a momentary mental blue screen. The hand of someone other than a relative was reaching out for him in… comradery? What’s more, that hand was attached to a young woman with cute freckles and a lovely shade of red hair that was being picked up just right by the wind. And her smile…
“Don’t leave me hangin’.”
Dipper snapped out of it and delivered the high five. It was oddly exhilarating.
“Oh hey, it’s my friends,” Wendy said as a car pulled up. She then looked apprehensively at the twins. “Uh, you guys aren’t going to tell Stan, are you?”
With a resolute smile, Dipper made a zipping motion over his mouth and threw away the key, which Wendy mirrored. The teen then said “Later dorks,” before descending down some nearby trees with a level of prowess rarely seen outside of professional acrobats, or minizora.
“Later Wendy,” Dipper called after they’d already driven off. His laugh was forced and his waving was frantic. “Haaa, good times.”
“Uh oh,” beamed Mable, not so oblivious when it came to other people’s relationships.
“What?”
“Somebody’s got a cru-hush,” she sang, poking him in the cheek.
“What? No. I just think Wendy’s cool is all. It’s not like I lay awake at night thinking about her.”
“Oh? So when I catch you staring blankly up at the ceiling at night, who are you thinking about?” inquired Mable, continuing her poking assault.
“Her name’s Business. First name None-Ya.”
“You can’t fool me. I know when my little brother’s crushing on someone.”
“What? No you don’t.”
“Oh really? So if I were to, say, offer you this handkerchief that Wendy used to wipe her chest earlier,” Mable said while producing said fabric from her pocket, “you wouldn’t be interested?”
“How much?” Dipper’s mouth said before his filter could switch on.
Mable’s smirk was downright devilish. She had him cornered and they both knew it. “It’s actually clean,” she said before returning the white cloth to her pocket. “So, got a thing for red heads, huh?”
“No. I mean, I don’t know. Just… this one, I guess,” he admitted apprehensively. “C-can we just drop this, please?”
“Fine. Whatever you say, bro-bro. Just know that I’ll be here when you’re ready to talk. In fact…” Mable then unceremoniously snatched up Dipper and stuffed him down the back of her underwear.
Wedged between her soft cheeks, Dipper was left to consider how surprisingly mature that response was, at least by Mable standards. Still, with nothing better to do today, he decided to make himself comfy in the warm softness, pull out his flashlight and journal, and get some reading done.
The next day, Mable seemed to have fully returned to her usual chipper self, as indicated by the “Random dance party for no reason!”
As she and Wendy got their groove on, Dipper pretended to read, all while peeking over the top of the journal. He was starting to notice things about the red head. Her dancing really showed off how nice her hips were. While she lacked the perpetual sugar rush that was Mable’s energy, her moves had a more mature elegance. That one move resembled a pelvic thrust, which set the minizora’s imagination into overdrive.
“Hey Dipper. You gonna get in on this?” Wendy called.
“Oh, I, uh, don’t really dance,” Dipper dodged with a blush, only to spy the sadistic gleam in Mable’s eye. She was about to do her sisterly duty and embarrass him for her own amusement.
“Yeah, ya do.” She turned to Wendy. “Mom used to dress him up in a lamb costume and make him do… the Lamby Dance,” she said as if imparting some ancient and holy secret.
“Now is not the time to talk about the Lamby Dance,” Dipper said through gritted teeth.
“Whoa, lamb costume?” Wendy chuckled. “Is there, like, little ears and a tail, or-?”
Mable immediately produced a picture for Wendy. “He used to be so cute. He’d prance around and sing a song about grazing,” she laughed with nostalgic fondness.
“Oh wow.” Wendy covered a hand over her mouth to stifle her giggles. She understood how embarrassing this was, but couldn’t tear her eyes away. “Just look at him. Aww, he’s so sweet I think I just got diabetes.” While the ladies laughed, Dipper was left to seethe in silent humiliation.
Then the clock chimed.
“Op. Quitin’ time.” Wendy pocketed her name tag and made for the door.
“Uh, hey wait,” Dipper called. “Maybe I-er-we could come with you.”
“Ooh, I don’t know. My friends are pre-tty intense. How old did you guys say you are?”
“Uh, we’re thirteen, so technically teens,” Dipper lied.
“Alright. I like your moxy, kid. Let me get my stuff.”
Mable picked Dipper up and tutted her disappointment. “Lying to a girl just to hang out. Oh Dipper. I thought I taught you better.”
“You’ve taught me literally nothing about dating… which this isn’t. It’s just one group of friends hanging out with another group of friends, all connected through one mutual friend. It’s all very friendly, and nothing else.”
“Uh huh. Yeah. Sure,” Mable teased.
“Hey, quick question. Um, why are you being so cool about this?”
“What do you mean?”
“Like, I’m not saying I like Wendy or anything, but if I did, I kind of expected you to be a little more, you know…” He gestured vaguely.
“Finger bitey.”
“That’s a good way of putting it.”
Mable laughed and shook her head at her pitiable little brother. “Because I realized something, Dipper. You and me, we kind of, how do I put this? Suck. Yeah. When it comes to love, we kind of have sucky tastes in picking people to crush on.”
Dipper scowled. “That sounds like the worst revelation ever.”
“Buuut, we don’t suck at judging the other’s love interest.”
“I’m not following.”
“It’s probably a twin thing. We started out as the same cell, but then we became two. I think it’s like we’ve got one whole person’s worth of common sense between us. I tend to miss a lot of stuff that’s obvious to you, but you’re basically blind to stuff I can’t not see. So whenever one of us finds someone we like, we should trust the other twin’s judgement instead of our own. That way we can avoid the awkwardness of gang banging gnomes, magic creepoids, or that one girl with chronic diarrhea.”
Dipper shuddered with revulsion. He’d have been happy to never think about Patty ever again. But in thinking of her now, Mable had warned him beforehand. “Hmm. You know, that’s not the worst idea I’ve ever heard.”
“High praise.”
“So, if I’m following, does this mean you approve of Wendy?”
“Does she still have all her fingers?”
“Uh, yeah.”
“Then yeah. I like her fine.” Mable emphasized by clicking her teeth together.
115211111111111111.title: Someone's got a Crush

1152111111111111111.content:
The meeting with Wendy’s friends went less than ideal. Nothing he did impressed anyone and he kind of pissed off Robby by calling his drawing of an explosion a muffin. The rest of the guys were pretty rough with one another and prone to frequent punching. The only other girl, Tambry, was so glued to her phone that it was a miracle she could walk. Since the twins didn’t take up much space, they were made to sit in the back of Thompson’s mom’s van with Tambry.

“So, uh, you like spending time on your phone, huh?” Dipper asked awkwardly, trying to break the ice while sitting in Mable’s lap.

Tambry finally paused in her texting to give the pair a once over. “So you’re, like, twins?”

“Uh, yup. Sure are.”

“So are you, like, identical?”

Mable and Dipper shared a look. It was the look of people who’d been asked a particular question so often that they’d put serious thought into starting a petition to get that particular string of words criminalized.

“No, we’re not identical,” Dipper said as politely as possible. “We’re a boy and a girl, not to mention the whole height thing.”

“Yeah. Plus I’m the cute one,” Mable added.

Tambry hummed thoughtfully. “So, I’ve never seen a minizora before. What’s that like? Do you, like, get stepped on a lot?”

“Kind of, but almost never twice by the same person.” Dipper then gestured up at Mable. “Guess why.”

“Oh yeah. I saw a photo of that on BookFace.” Tambry flipped through her timeline and turned her phone towards the twins. Sure enough, there was a photo of Mable frothing at the mouth and biting into Manly Dan’s ankle while he wore an expression of abject horror.

“It was actually whipped cream, but I think it sent the right message,” Mable added, almost bragging.

Tambry finally smiled. “You guys aren’t half bad.” And she went back to texting.

The van finally pulled up at their destination and they all disembarked.

“There it is fellas. The condemned Dust 2 Dawn,” Wendy ominously announced to the awe of the others. The building had been fenced off and looked like it hadn’t seen human activity in decades.

“Why’d they shut it down?” Dipper asked, not wanting to show his anxiety at entering another abandoned building. “Some kind of health code violation or…”

“Try murder,” said one of the guys whose name Dipper had already forgotten. “Some folks died in there. The place has been haunted ever since.”

“This town has such a colorful history,” Mable cheered.

“Wh-wha? A-are you guys serious?”

“Chill out, man,” Wendy said before poking his arm, what she felt to be an appropriate equivalent of a friendly punch. “It’s not that big a deal.”

While everyone else had to climb the fence, Dipper was able to just walk between the holes. Unfortunately, the doors were locked, but then Dipper got an idea. “Hey, let me take a crack at it.”

Robby scoffed. “Yeah right. I can’t get in, but itty bitty pipsqueak is gonna break it down like-Agh!” He winced as a can hit him in the face. “Who threw that?”

No one gave any response; least of all Mable who was innocently whistling.

“Come on, leave him alone,” Wendy pleaded. “He’s just a little kid.”

Dipper’s expression of hurt quickly morphed into determination and he snapped his fingers. “Mable.” She manifested behind him. “Roof me.”

With a wide grin at the chance to show off their twin skills, Mable picked up her brother. With him curled up in a ball, she took aim at what looked like a vent and tossed him. Everyone else was gob smacked, unable to believe what they were seeing as the little fella climbed. Mable had only thrown him half way up, meaning he’d have to make the rest of the ascension on his own while the others watched. He disappeared. There was a commotion on the roof, like metal being punched, and then came silence.

Robby scoffed and turned to the others. “Who wants to be he doesn’t-”

“$100!” Mable shouted urgently.

“Pssh. Like he’ll actually-”

With the door unlocked from the inside, Dipper was able to push it open and motion the others to enter. While the others congratulated the minizora, even giving him the nickname Dr. Funtimes, Mable stuck by Robby’s side.

“We can discuss a payment plan later. I’d prefer cash, but I’m willing to settle for the equivalent in fingers and toes.” Her ultimatum delivered, she merrily skipped on into the haunted shop.

“Oh man. It’s even creepier than I imagined,” commented Wendy as the group split up to explore the dark isles.

Everything was covered in dust and there were more than a few bugs scurrying about. The whole experience of a convenience store at night was pretty novel for all of them. It wasn’t long before Wendy found the light switches and, much to everyone’s surprise, they still worked. With that set, the games were on. They had a food war with expired pastries, dropped mints in soda bottles just because, and pretty much whatever else they wanted.

Then Mable squealed. “Oh my gosh, Smile Dip! I thought this stuff was banned in America.”

“Maybe they had a good reason,” Dipper observed responsibly. All the tape wrapped around the display saying ‘Do Not Sell’ seemed to predate the store’s closing. But the cheering of the teens throwing liquefied food at one another called him back to the fun, leaving Mable to her own devices.

Up on one of the isle shelves, Dipper and Wendy were enjoying some (miraculously) still frozen ice cream sticks. After an initial period of awkwardness, Dipper agreed to sit on her knee.

“Haha. Dipper, this night is, like, legendary.”

“Really?”

“Just look around. The guys are bonding.” She pointed to where they were pouring ice into Thompson’s pants. “I’ve never even seen Tambry look up from her phone this long.” Tambry just looked up to check on the shelf sitters, but looked away the moment their eyes locked. “And your sister seems to be going nuts for that Smile Dip.” Pink sugary stuff stained Mable’s hair and clothes. Her eyes looked glazed over as she seemed to be imagining eating something very large. It was unsettling to look at.

“You know, Dipper. I wasn’t sure if you could hang out with our crew at first, but you’re surprisingly mature for your age.”

“Yes. Yes I am, though that’s probably just cuz I’m a minizora.”

“Oh yeah. I think I heard that somewhere. You little guys mature, like, super quick or something.” That was the SFW version, though. When Wendy had read about this online, there had been lots of comments talking about the sexual side of things. Something about them evolving to develop early to ensure survival. There’d been a lot of talk about hormones, or maybe it was pheromones. Lots of people were arguing on the particulars. The overall conclusion was that even if a minizora kid looked like any regular kid on the outside, on the inside they were, like, twice as old. In that sense, depending on how you looked at it, Dipper was kind of like an adult in a little kid’s body. Wendy wondered if this new info made her feelings towards the little dude less or more awkward. Probably the latter.

“Yeah, definitely,” Dipper agreed, oblivious to Wendy’s inner turmoil. He was glad that from his position, he could sneak glances of her chest without her noticing.
1152111111111111111.title: The Inconveniencing

11521111111111111111.content:
Dipper had gone to fetch some more ice cream for everyone. “It’s really a shame this place shut down,” he said to himself as he opened the freezer door. “Not many places are this minizora friendly. I wonder if-” His train of thought was broken when he beheld a floating brain. The nervous system floated beneath it like the tendrils of a jelly fish, along with a gurgling mouth and a pair of eyes that got way too close. Naturally, Dipper screamed and shut the door before anything else could happen.
Then the teens all came over to investigate. “What was that? I thought I heard some lady screaming back here.” Said one of the no-names. “You freaking out kid?” asked the other no-name.
“No, no. I’m fine. Everything’s fine over here. Um, how are you?” Dipper’s eyes nervously darted about in search of some sort of distraction. “Hey look. Dancy Pants Revolution, the game that tricks people into exercising.” After taking one last look inside the freezer and finding it empty, Dipper decided that it had just been some trick of the light and rejoined the teens.
Dipper’s smile was forced as he tried to play it cool. Then he looked at the reflective glass and saw everyone – including himself – as skeletons. He then slapped himself and the reflections went back to normal. “I’ll be right back.” He tried to phone Grunkle Stan. The good news was that it was minizora accessible. The bad news was that no one was picking up.
Dipper then returned to Mable. He climbed on her palm and her fingers reflexively curled around him in a protective embrace. “Mable, I need your help. I think this store really is haunted, I can’t get ahold of Grunkle Stan, and if I say anything to these guys,” he gestured to the teens, “then they’ll just think I’m a scared little kid or something. Uh, Mable?” Her only answer was a low gurgle as pink foam poured from her lips. Dipper then climbed up to her shoulder and started slapping her cheek. “Mable, how many of these did you eat?”
“Eleven… teeeeen. Blagh!”
“Oh man-oh man-oh man!” Dipper shook his hands as his body felt hot and cold all at once. They were in danger and his other half was in a sugar induced coma. How could things get worse?
Robby then called everyone over behind the counter. There were a couple of chalk outlines of where the bodies had fallen. Everyone was impressed and, in typical teen fashion, decided to prove their bravery by getting inside the lines.
“Wait!” Dipper urged, positioning himself between the teens and what was definitely a bad idea. “Maybe let’s not do that.”
“Heh-heh. This guy’s scared.”
“All I’m saying is: Why tempt the fates? I mean, what if this place really is… haunted?” The fallout was as bad as he’d feared. Everyone was booing, his nickname was changed to Captain Buzzkill, and worst of all, Wendy looked disappointed with him.
Tambry just kept texting. “Status update. Trapped in convenience store with insane 9 year old.”
“I’m not 9!” Dipper stomped his foot like a petulant child and, like a child, surrendered to peer pressure by laying down in the chalk outline. “I’m 13. Technically a teen.”
With his announcement made, it was like the whole store gave a groan. The lights turned an eerie green and the chalk outline began to glow. The change in scenery caused Tambry to look up from her phone just in time to vanish in a blinding flash.
“Whoa, what the hell?”
Dipper ran over and checked her phone. “Status update. Ahhh,” he read. Then the security camera flipped on with the girl inside and trying to break out of the glass. Everyone had the appropriate reaction of screaming like a bunch of sissies.
Thompson, who was still playing on the machine, was the next to vanish. He reappeared within the game screen and was pummeled by arrows. With nowhere to run, he curled up in a ball and started to cry. Tension only escalated when the doors closed on their own and no amount of force could break through.
“Everybody wait,” Dipper called, pulling out the journal and flipping to the ghost section. “Whatever is doing this has to have some kind of reason. If we can figure out what it is, thennn maybe they’ll let us go.”
When the white no-name made a sarcastic remark, his reward was to be transported within the art of a cereal box where the bird mascot tried to eat him.
Then, just as everyone was onboard with the only actual plan, Mable floated about six feet above the ground. She had no pupils, her body glowed, and she spoke with a deep masculine voice. “Wel-commme.”
“They got Mable!” Dipper cried.
“Welcome to your graves, young trespassers. Mwahahaha!”
“Look, we’re super sorry for hanging out in your store,” Wendy pleaded.
“Yeah. Can’t we just go now and leave forever?” begged Dipper.
The ghost possessing Mable hummed. “Hmm. Okay, you’re free to go.” The doors opened. However, just as the guys tried to run, they were sealed shut all over again. “Ha! Just kidding.”
“You creepy freak! Just let us out already,” demanded the black no-name.
“Yeah, loser,” Robby agreed.
“I don’t like your tone.” The ghost snapped Mable’s fingers, turning the disrespectful teens into hot dogs and putting them on the rollers to cook. “It begins.” Gravity decided to take the day off as everything fell to the ceiling.
Wendy winced in pain. “Agh! Dipper. Dipper, where’d you go?”
“In here,” called a voice from within her shirt. In the fall, Dipper had somehow been wedged waste deep between Wendy’s boobs. Were they not in such great peril, they’d have both been more embarrassed. With the items of the store now swirling in a whirlwind, Dipper directed Wendy to run into an empty soda machine for safety.
Inside, Wendy caught her breath with her hand against her chest, along with the boy. Ever since meeting Dipper, she’d been secretly fantasizing about this exact thing happening, only in the fantasy she’d been a lot cooler and able to enjoy the moment. “What do they want from us?”
“Revenge, I guess,” Dipper suggested while he tried to wiggle free. Wendy’s breasts were a lot bigger than it appeared through her casual clothes. The rapid rise and fall of her chest made it hard for the little guy to keep his balance and he kept having to brace himself on his hands.
“What did we do?” Wendy demanded of her boob sitter. Despite her panic, the little guy’s struggling against her sensitive area was causing her body to react very unfortunately. Her only hope was that he didn’t notice and think she was some kind of pervert.
The two had a back and forth until Dipper figured out the pattern. Everyone had been taken after doing ‘normal teen things’. “That’s it. Stay here until I get back.” Before she could stop him, he’d already hopped out of her shirt and hurried out onto the main floor/ceiling. “Hey ghost! I’ve got something to tell you,” he declared even as he was lifted up into the air. This whole thing was giving him some seriously bad flashbacks, but he still had a mission to complete and a sister to save. “I’m not a teenager!”
And just like that, the magic faded. The ceiling was still the new floor, but everything still dropped, including him and Mable. Then a couple of ghosts – a man and woman in their late eighties – manifested. Were they not transparent and floating, their smiles would be quite charming.
“Well why didn’t you say so?” asked the man with a good-natured laugh. “How old did you say you were?”
Mindful of Wendy’s eyes upon him, Dipper sucked in a breath. “I’m… 12. Technically not a teen.”
The ghosts then told their backstory. They hated how teens behaved in their store, eventually getting so fed up that they banned them all. In retaliation, the teens had some kind of rap battle dance off in the parking lot. The lyrics were so ‘hateful’ and shocking that the pair were stricken with double heart attacks. It was the most tragically hilarious thing the minizora had ever heard.
“But, they’re my friends. Isn’t there anything I can do to help them?” pleaded Dipper.
In fact, there was. These ghosts wanted to see a minizora do a funny dance. When Dipper let slip that he knew one, they were even generous enough to provide him a lamb costume. As the minizora swallowed his dignity and humiliated himself before these strangers, Wendy was enduring her own brand of suffering. Seeing such a cute boy in such a silly costume was unbearable to behold, but she couldn’t tear her eyes away. She had to resort to biting her arm until blood was drawn to keep her imagination from wandering. She’d think about it later, though.
“That was some fine girly dancing,” said the ghost. “Your friends are free.”
The lights returned to normal, as did gravity. Everything fell back to the old floor and the formerly captive teens crawled out of the wreckage, all suffering the spectral equivalent of a hangover.
“Evil,” Mable burbled, her stomach expressing it hatred for her as she stared at a pink package. “Eeeviiil.”
With everyone still disoriented, Wendy saw fit to tell the story. Once the ghosts appeared, Dipper MacGuivered an array of slingshots that propelled him all around the room. He was like the world’s deadliest pinball and battered the ghosts until they ran away crying. While everyone was in awe, Wendy turned back to Dipper and made the zipping motion, which he returned.
On the ride back, Mable was amazingly able to keep from spewing. Dipper, meanwhile, was thinking of Wendy. She’d been impressed by him, covered for him, expressed an interest in hanging out further, and her chest had been so soft. So… soft.
11521111111111111111.title: The Lamby Horror

115211111111111111111.content:
Grunkle Stan was in the middle of selling literal garbage to a local, who really ought to have known better, when the twins came in.

“Grunkle Stan, can we go to the diner? We’re huuungryyy,” Mable pleaded, pinching her stomach and shaking it. Soon dipper started doing the same as both made sounds like they were dying. “If I don’t get something in my tummy quick, I might have to eat Dipper.”

“She ain’t bluffing, man,” deadpanned the minizora. Mable had only ever swallowed Dipper by accident. The exception being that first time back when they were three and she was trying to get him away from some bullies. Later, after he’d been cleaned, she’d apologized until she lost her voice. Even so, it was fun to freak people out with the threat.

Stan agreed, leaving the idiot locked in the gift shop. Greasy’s Diner was a local joint with a lot of character, which was a nice way of saying it wasn’t up to code. There were even woodpeckers and beavers chewing on the wood. Their server was Lazy Susan, a woman about Stan’s age with a dysfunctional left eyelid. After some rather forced banter, Stan ordered the cheapest item on the menu for himself and leftovers for Dipper and Mable to split.

“But Grunkle Stan, I want pancakes,” whined Mable.

The old man was as stingy as ever, but then Dipper saw his chance to shine. At the far end of the room was a machine called Test Your Manliness, with the promise of free pancakes for winners. Cracking his knuckles, he said, “Don’t worry guys. Pancakes are on me. I’ll win us some by beating that manliness tester.”

After a second of disbelief, both Mable and Stan burst out laughing.

“What? What’s so funny? It’s got a setting for minizora, so I can do it.”

“Sorry Dipper, but you’re not exactly Manly Manington,” cackled Mable.

“Hey. I am so Manly… Many or whatever.”

“Face the music, kid,” Stan lectured. “Even by tiny people standards you’ve got no muscle, you smell like baby wipes,” he didn’t notice Mable’s eyes guiltily darting around, “and let’s not forget last Tuesday’s… incident.”

“Hey, Baba is awesome, but that doesn’t matter. Come on, guys. I’m plenty masculine. Look at this chest hair.” He pulled down his shirt, catching the mid-morning light just right and magnifying it back at his family.

“Ahh! My eyes!” “It burrrns!”

Blushing, Dipper decided that he was getting nowhere with just words. “Fine, oh family of little faith. Get ready to eat those words, with a side of pancakes.”

Dipper hopped down and marched over to the machine, climbing the little staircase on the side to the minizora setting. It had a scaled down handle and everything. Channeling the strength that had defeated gnomes, wax dummies, and a small army of bugs across the years, Dipper grabbed that handle and squeezed with all his might. The bottommost bulb blinked and the machine spat out a card, which Dipper thoughtlessly read aloud. “Cutie patootie?”

Mable screamed, burying her face in her sleeve and banging on the table as tears poured from her eyes.

Manly Dan, in a rare moment of sympathy for the pipsqueak, decided to do the poor kid a favor. After gently setting him down on the ground, careful not to provoke the wrath of the minizora’s rabid guard dog, the man ape pushed his pinkie against the lever. The machine overloaded and pancakes were flung out to every plate in the diner. “Pancakes for everyone!” While everyone cheered at his display, Manly Dan checked on the person he actually wanted to impress.

Mable gestured for him to move along, so he did; but only because it was his decision, dammit!

Dipper just sat on the floor, picking up the pieces of his shattered masculinity, when a red head showed up. She wasn’t the one from the Shack, though. This lady was much older, maybe early thirties. She looked like a super model with an hourglass figure, tremendous tits, and a luscious ass that Dipper wouldn’t mind sitting on him. Who just thought that?

She squatted down closer to Dipper’s level, thankfully wearing pants. “Hey there, sugar. Don’t let yourself get down, none.” Her voice was like honey. “Say, you’re that Dipper kid Wendy told me about,” she inquired, reaching down with her thumb and trigger finger to shake.

Dipper swallowed what felt like a lung and accepted the offer. “Oh, uh, Wendy t-told you about me?”

“She sure did. Mah little girl said you were quite the hero the other night.”

“Oh, so you’re Wendy’s mom.” Dipper forced a smile, remembering that this was the woman with the power to make guys fling themselves out of closed windows.

“Don’t mind mah husband, none. He’s just got his own special way of showin’ he cares.”

“That’s, aha, nice to hear, but doesn’t help much.” Dipper gestured up at the machine. “Even by tiny standards, I’m a wimp.”

Mrs. Corduroy smiled flatly. “You really shouldn’t listen to what some dumb machine has to say. There are lots of ways to be a real man, even for a minizora. You just have to find the one that fits you.”

“I appreciate that. I really do, but I think I just need some alone time to figure things out.”

“Well, suit yourself.” She stood and was about to walk away, but stopped herself. “Just one more thing. If you happen on some still water and see your reflection in it, don’t sing. Only princesses do that, and that’s about as far from manly as anyone can get.”

Dipper laughed, once more thanking the woman for her kindness, and departed.

Grunkle Stan turned to Mable. “You just gonna let him go like that?”

“He’d just tell me not to follow,” Mable sighed. “He’s trying to be more independent and I’m trying to let him. Our therapist said it’d be healthier for both of us.”

“Egh. Head doctors are all quacks if you ask me, though I guess this one’s not totally wrong. A lucky minizora has family that’ll look after them, but things can sometimes go overboard. Ya get overprotective, smothering, and worry yourself sick. A little distance here and there really is for the best for all sides.” Grunkle Stan then took a sip of his coffee.

“Wow. That’s almost exactly what our therapist said.” Mable’s awe then turned to suspicion. “How do you know so much about minizora?”

Stan averted his gaze. “Oh, you know. A guy my age hears things. No big deal.”

“Makes sense to me,” allowed Mable, fully accepting of this explanation.
115211111111111111111.title: Manly Mini

1152111111111111111111.content:
Trudging down the sidewalk in a funk, Dipper had gotten careless and been stepped on quite a bit. Nothing was broken, but what hurt more was how most of the people didn’t even pay him a second glance as they kept on walking. Deciding he needed to be away from people, Dipper ran out into the woods. There he found some suitable twigs to practice bench pressing. He only made it to 4 before calling it quits.

Laying down on his back, he asked of the sky, “Is it physical? Is it mental? What’s the secret?” Figuring that he had nothing better to do than drown his sorrows in food, Dipper pulled out a tiny bag of beef jerky.

Not a second later, the ground began to rumble as a distant creature roared. Animals of all sorts fled as if from a natural disaster and even Manly Dan was there. “For the love of all that’s holy. Ruuun!” And he did, the dumbass not even taking the half second to bring Dipper along.

The minizora tried to flee, but the shaking of the ground somehow caused some trees to fall and block his path. Dipper narrowly avoided being crushed as the thunder of footsteps approached. He smelled the creature before he saw it: a putrid combination of B.O., salt, and dried sex fluids. It was big, maybe ten feet tall, with the horns and face of a bull, the body of a man, muscles for days, a blessed skirt mercifully wrapped around the waist, and enough chest and back hair that he could probably survive a collision with a truck, even without the muscles. And to top it off, the thing grabbed a male deer from a bush and used it’s antlers to scratch his ass before tossing the buck aside. Then the thing looked at Dipper.

“Please don’t eat me,” Dipper begged. “I haven’t showered in a week. And I’m, like, all elbows. Elbows and gristle.”

“You,” the creature boomed, pointing a finger accusingly at the tiny. “Gonna finish that?”

Dipper looked down and saw that he was still holding the bag of jerky and quickly threw it towards the creature. “By all means. Go ahead.”

“Thanks.”

The creature introduced itself as a manotaur named Chutzpar. He then proceeded through a sequence of manly displays by punching trees and head butting rocks. He then demonstrated the ability to smell emotional issues, prompting Dipper to tell his story. Despite first impressions, the manotaur proved to be a very good listener and showed quite a bit of sympathy for Dipper’s struggles with the little guy’s perception of himself as a man. Ultimately, the manotaur agreed to Dipper’s request for pointers on manliness, but only if the minizora climbed his back hair and held on all the way to his lair.

The lair pretty much embodied everything one would expect from a stereotypical man cave, which, coincidently, was the place’s name. There were weights for lifting, foosball, mini-fridges overflowing with beer, and broken controllers piled so high that they reached the ceiling right alongside a game station.

Chutzpar used picked up a bone to ring a gong. “Fellow manotaurs. I bring you a tiny hairless child.”

“S’up,” Dipper squeaked. With all the other manoutaurs having such manly names, he introduced himself as “Dipper the destructor,” which they found adequate.

Chutzpar rang the gong again. “Dipper the destructor wants us to teach him the secrets of our manliness.”

The other manotaurs deliberated on this, which is to say things broke out into a fist fight for no discernable reason. In the end they chose to deny his request. But Dipper, having just seen one of these guys punch himself in the face, decided to exploit their apparent weakness for his own advantage.

“Denied? Okay fine. Obviously you guys think it’d be too tough to train me. Maybe… you’re not man enough to try.”

There came a collective sucking of air that actually pulled Dipper forward just a tad. His tapping into their insecurities had convinced them. And so the training began.

“Being a man is about conquering your fears. So your first test is to stick your hand into the pain hole.” This announcement made the other manotaurs wince. The otherwise innocuous hole in the ground had a little sign and everything.

Unwilling to back down on the first trial, Dipper sucked in a breath, got on his knees, and plunged his fist into the hole. At first, nothing happened. “Um, okay. So is there going to be a-ow! Hey, what the-ow!”

The manotaurs collectively flinched, but quickly came out of it when they noticed the hairless child’s cries weren’t in agony, but annoyance.

“What the hell is in here?” Dipper hissed. “It’s, like, really itchy or something. Was there a time limit?”

Many jaws dropped. “Itchy? The last guy to stick his fist in the pain hole screamed for 3 straight days,” Chutzpar informed in disbelief.

“So I have to stay like this for 3-ow!-days?” Dipper demanded irritably.

“Uh, no that’s fine. You can stop now.”

The remaining trials were just as awkward for all involved. The manotaurs again showed remarkable consideration by scaling everything down for Dipper. Instead of pulling a cart full of manotaurs, it was a tiny cart full of mice. Instead of walking across the heads of crocodiles in a lake, he had to walk across the heads of snakes. And on it went. After a good few hours of montage training, Dipper was allowed to relax in the Man Cave’s natural hot springs. There he beheld the most frightening ordeal yet: naked manotaurs. The less said about what lay under their manly skirts the better, although Dipper was certain he’d be seeing those… things in his nightmares for the rest of his life. Then again, this did prompt his curiosity.

“Thanks a lot for taking me under your wing, guys. Though I’ve been wondering something. Are there, like, fem-o-taurs or something?”

That set them to uproarious laughter. “Of course not, Destructor,” Chutzpar said. “We manotaurs are the greatest force of masculine energy in the known universe. We don’t even have X chromosomes,” he said as though it were obvious.

“Oh. Okay. So then… how do you reproduce?”

“We butt fuck.”

A long and terrible silence followed. Dipper stared up at the ceiling and questioned every life decision that had led him to this awful reality in which he was imagining… that. After spending so much time with the manotaurs, he’d absorbed a bit of their culture. So it seemed like a perfectly sensible idea to punch himself in the face in the hopes of giving himself amnesia. Then he remembered how often the manotaurs liked to hit their heads against things, and suddenly had a lot more sympathy for their awful plight.

Dipper muttered under his breath. “This is proof that there is a god… and that he hates us.”
1152111111111111111111.title: Manly Trials

11521111111111111111111.content:
Despite the 49 trials before, there was still one last challenge, and it was the deadliest of them all. The first step was a ceremony in which Dipper was stripped down to a loincloth and covered in manly removable tattoos. The permanent ones would come later. Dipper was then introduced to Leaderaur, a great black manotaur roughly 40 feet tall whose lower half was smaller than his fists. With those fists he reached into his chest and ripped out one of his own ribs, which had already been fashioned into a spear. Dipper’s task was to do a heroic act. He had to go up to the highest mountain and bring back the head of the manotaurs’ mortal enemy, the Multibear. By conquering him, Dipper’s manformation would be complete.

Once the spear had been trimmed down so that Dipper could actually wield it, the mission was on. After everything he’d already endured, a perilous trek across the wilderness was practically a pleasant stroll through the park in comparison. The burn in his muscles as he ran was amazing. And with the loincloth covering practically nothing while he moved, the breeze across his privates was also refreshing. He moved with confidence, free of fear of being stepped on or carried off by wild animals. Such liberation was exhilarating. When he stopped at a stream for water, he even shared a knowing nod with a wolf. It was the most amazing thing ever!

While he tried to focus on the trial, planning out strategies for taking down a creature that was tough enough to challenge the manotaurs, Dipper’s mind kept wandering back to home. He thought of Mable; cute and well-meaning, but often overbearing. Had she come with him, he’d have never been allowed to make it this far, yet he did. This was his accomplishment. A skinny, noodle armed minizora was actually scaling a literal mountain like it was a jungle gym. Body pumping full of adrenaline, Dipper really hoped that his erection would go down before he made it to the top. Luckily, the sight of so many bones littering the cave’s floor managed to do the trick.

Spear at the ready, Dipper entered into the black abyss. Examining the bones, he discerned that they were mostly deer and other moderate to large sized animals. “So this thing is at least as big as a manotaur. Hmm. I probably should have asked what a Multibear was before coming up-” *Grrr* “-here.”

Then it revealed itself. The beast resembled a chimera, the mythical creature that was a combination of multiple animals, only in this case they were all bears. It was like someone hacked the creature creator in Spore and just kept adding bear parts. It had bear bodies for limbs, heads and regular limbs seemingly for decoration, and three asses in back. Probably best not to think about that.

“Bear heads, silence!” declared the eloquent central head while smacking one of the lesser growling heads. “Child, why have you come here?”

“Multibear, I seek your head,” Dipper declared. “Or, at least one of them. Any chance you could just give me a spare?” Alas, negotiations broke down, and the fight commenced.

It was a harrowing ordeal. Dipper had never before faced that many claws or teeth all at once. Overpowering his foe was out of the question, but Dipper knew he had other strengths. The Multibear was unaccustomed to fighting a foe so tiny, so his blows were awkward. In observing its movements, Dipper further discerned that the many bear heads were not in complete harmony and could be provoked into independent action. Diving into the creatures thickly matted hair, he began a mosquito strategy of stabbing somewhere sensitive, and then running before the Multibear could smack itself. This was repeated everywhere that looked sensitive, driving bear paws to smack several bear heads unconscious. The finishing blow came after the enemy kneed itself in the fourth groin and it fell with a calamitous crash.

Dipper ascended to the central head and took aim at the throat. “A real man shows no mercy!”

The Multibear conceded his defeat with surprising grace. His last request was to die listening to his favorite music. After turning on the old cassette player, it turned out that the song was Disco Girl by Baba, the same one that Dipper had been mocked for liking earlier. The two got to talking. When the manotaurs said that the Multibear was their mortal enemy, they’d actually meant that he was just some guy who kept to himself and listened to music they didn’t like. The truth revealed, Dipper could not bring himself to harm a kindred spirit, and marched his barely covered ass back to the Man Cave and threw down his spear before Leaderaur.

“I’m not gonna do it,” Dipper announced to the shock of the manotaurs.

Leaderaur was angry, or possibly indifferent. He kind of only had the one expression and tone, so it was hard to tell. “You were told the price of manhood is the Multibear’s head.”

“You know, screw that. You keep saying that being a man is all about being tough and agro all the time, but I think that’s bull! I may not have muscles, or hair in certain places, but the Multibear is just a nice guy who doesn’t want to hurt anyone. What about cutting off his head is even remotely heroic?”

Leaderaur hopped down from his stone throne and backhanded it into oblivion. Yup, definitely mad. “Kill the Multibear or never be a man!” he roared in Dipper’s face, but the tiny stood his ground.

“Then I guess I’ll never be a man.” His mind made up, Dipper allowed himself to be booed off the stage and left the Man Cave. After making a pit stop at the Shack to wash off the tattoos and get a new change of clothes, he tracked Mable and Stan back to the diner, where apparently Mable had been trying to ship Grunkle Stan with Lazy Susan.

“Dipper! Bro-bro, where ya been? I-” Mable’s peppiness evaporated as she looked over his bruises and her demeanor turned dark. “Does someone need to die? You can tell me if someone needs to die.”

“No, it’s fine,” Dipper glumly dissuaded.

“Good,” Stan said between bites of pie.

“It’s just these half man half bull humanoids were hanging out with me.”

“Here we go,” Stan added dismissively.

“But then they wanted me to do this really horrible thing, but it just wasn’t right. So I said no.”

His attention primarily on the pie, Grunkle Stan said, “You were your own man and you stood up for yourself.”

“Huh?”

“You did what was right even though no one agreed with ya?” Stan said around his mouthful. “Sounds pretty manly to me, but what do I know.”

Dipper beamed. Maybe there was hope for him yet.

Mable, meanwhile, was studying the minizora more intently. “Is it me, or did you get a little bit of muscle in the last few hours?”

“Well, I did just climb a literal mountain and defeated a composite bear monster, so I’d hope so.”

“Here.” Mable handed Dipper a fork, which he easily lifted over his head. Curious, Mable just kept adding on more silverware, making it six pieces before it was too much and Dipper dropped them. “Oh my gosh, this is amazing! You used to only be able to hold up three. My little brother is so strong now.” She sucked in a gasp and dropped her chin to the table. “What else can you do?” she asked with a breathy undertone.

With a smirk on his face and hands uncaringly in his pockets, Dipper gave Mable a knowing look. “Oh, you know, probably nothing special.”
11521111111111111111111.title: Man Test

choices: See how Mable and Dipper are that night
115211111111111111111111.content:
“Hey Wendy, come and check this out.”

Wendy looked away from the television as her friend Tambry motioned for her to come over and see what she had found on her phone. They were hanging out in Wendy’s room, having a girl’s night which was pretty much just Tambry on her phone and Wendy watching cheesy horror movies as they both ignored each other. In the last few days, Tambry had been really interested in something on her phone, more interested then she normally was, as she blocked out everyone even more than normal. Ever curious, Wendy moved over to her and saw what her friend was watching.

“Is that…a porn video?” It wasn’t that odd that Tambry looked up that kind of stuff or did even more illicit things on her phone. Wendy was pretty sure she had posted a few nudes online for fun. Why she thought everyone seeing her buck naked was funny was beyond Wendy.

“Minizora porn,” Tambry explained pausing the video. On her tiny smartphone, a video with some beach blonde bimbo with fake tits was holding up a dildo with something special attached to it. There was a minizora strapped to the tip of the sex toy, smiling brightly as he got ready to be plunged into her pussy. Wendy gawked at it and then licked her lips slightly as she found them going dry from her mouth hanging open. This was… very interesting.

“After your little friend Dipper saved us back at the Dusk 2 Dawn, I figured he deserved a special thanks for being a pretty brave dude, and you know how I like to thank guys.” Tambry brought her partial open fist to her mouth and started jerking it back and forth as she made sucking noises. Wendy rolled her eyes, knowing exactly what her friend meant. “But I realized that won’t work with someone Dipper’s size, so I’ve been doing some research about the kind of things you can do with minizoras. Turns out there is a lot of kinky stuff that looks totally hot.”

“You skank,” Wendy scoffed with a shake of her head. This was typical Tambry, ready to try anything to kill the time is this boring pissant town. Not that Wendy was much better, she had her share of jumps in the hay that were done more because there was nothing good on tv rather than any real attraction between her and a guy. She wasn't as brazen as Tambry but she was far from being a prude. However, Dipper wasn’t just some random teen to kill some time with, he was a friend, and Wendy couldn’t let her corrupt him.

“You do know he’s only twelve, right?” Wendy pointed out.

“Eew, WTF? I thought he said he was thirteen,” Tambry said, suddenly her resolution to jump the very tiny bones of Wendy’s friend seeming like not that great of an idea. There were some things she just wouldn't do.

“He lied so we’d think he was cool. He’s only twelve years old but he will be turning thirteen next month,” Wendy clarified.

“Well, if he’s only a month away from being thirteen then that’s not a problem. That’s close enough to being a teen for me,” Tambry said with a shrug of her shoulders. She had low standards, but who could blame her with the kind of guys she had to pick from in Gravity Falls. Besides, she wasn’t much older the first time she went down on a dude so who cares. Apparently, Wendy did as she lowered her head and groaned in frustration.

“You skank,” Wendy repeated and got much the same reaction from Tambry who just rolled her eyes and returned to her phone. Crossing her arms over her chest, the redhead bit her lower lip as Tambry’s plans swirled around in her head. She had to protect Dipper’s innocents. At least that’s what she told herself as she refused to admit that maybe it was also jealousy playing a role in her decision to cockblock Dipper. She could at least admit that he was cute, but she was trying desperately not to take it any further or risk doing something really dumb. She really liked Dipper as a friend, the last thing she wanted was to scare him away with her stupid mixed feelings.

“Can you just hold off on the whole ‘thanking’ him thing for a bit? Consider it a favor for me,” Wendy softly pleaded.

“Oh! I get it,” Tambry said as she put down her phone at last and grinned at her female friend. “You want a shot at him and don’t want my sloppy seconds. Okay, you can go first but I want details. I’m going to grab some chips from the kitchen, don’t run off and go fuck the little dude.”

“I don’t want to fuck the little dude!” Wendy called out as Tambry left to grab something to snack on. Growling in annoyance, Wendy wondered if this was even worse because now Tambry was going to nag her every day if she had finally popped her minizora cherry with Dipper. She didn’t get it, it wasn’t like that between her and Dipper. They were just friends.

“Now what’s this I hear about you fucking a little dude.” As if Wendy’s life couldn’t get any worse right now, in walked her mother in tight daisy duke shorts and crop top showing off her very exaggerated figure. Grabbing a pillow and covering her head, Wendy threw herself on her bed and turned away from her entering mom.

“Nothing. It’s nothing, ma. Just forget it.”

“Are ya sure something ain’t bothering you, like maybe a pint-sized new boy that stole your heart?” Wendy just groaned even louder and clutched the pillow around her head harder trying to drown out her mother’s question. She always seemed to know when something was bothering Wendy, whether it was a fight with a boy or some teenage hijinks that had gone too far. Mrs. Corduroy knew when her baby girl needed her and was always there to give some advice, even if Wendy didn’t want it.

“He’s just a friend,” Wendy said, repeating what she’d been saying in her head for days.

“A friend is just a friend until ya’ll get too friendly, Wendy. Don’t be afraid ta put yourself out there for a man. You never know if you got yourself a good catch until you take a risk,” Wendy’s ma said, laying down her usual southern wisdom on her only daughter. Wendy tried to ignore what her mom said, refusing to say anything, but it tugged at her brain and made her wonder if maybe it couldn’t hurt to at least see if Dipper was interested. She had caught him staring at her but that might just be him making sure she wasn’t about to accidentally squish him. Just seeing if there was something couldn’t ruin their friendship, right?

“I mean, if I were you, baby girl, I’d grab that boy and take him home and introduce him to every inch of my naked body. The things I could do with a man that small, hot dang, we would keep going until I passed out or the bed broke. I bet those tiny hands could reach so many places.”

“Oh God, mom, no,” Wendy muttered, curling up as her mother started going about what she’d do with her friend if she had a chance. Mrs. Corduroy was a fountain of wisdom, as well as pent up sexual desires that she felt no shame sharing with her daughter. Wendy just whimpered, for the first time in her life wishing she was not at home but working right now.
115211111111111111111111.title: Night at the Corduroys

1152111111111111111111111.content:
“And so the mighty hunter stalks his prey,” Dipper narrated. He kept a low profile, hand on the ground in search of tracks, wielding a weapon, and was back to only wearing his loincloth. The time was night and there were only a few patches of light to illuminate his way. “The tracks are fresh. I must be getting close.” He ran up ahead a short ways, only to stop and duck behind some cover before scanning the area. “Though focused on his prey, the hunter must also be mindful of his surroundings. For in this vast, untamed wilderness, there could be competition. Or worse… predators.”

“Hehe-he.”

Dipper rolled his eyes and set a hand to his ear. “Hark, what’s that? Could it be the wind, or some foul creature with really bad teeth?”

“Grrr.”

“Regardless, the hunter must be on guard.” Dipper ran out into the open, weapon at the ready, and charged for his next hiding spot. “The hunter feel’s wary. He’s certain that he’s being stalked, but from where?” As he scanned his surroundings, he scratched under his loincloth, turning around so that any potential ‘predators’ could see what he was doing. Again he chose to ignore the giggling. “Hmm. The brave hunter knows of only one type of beast in this area that could be hunting him, but where is it?
