The beast is known for its less-than-graceful movements, big feet, and general lack of any kind of stealth ability, so how could it be hiding?”

“Grrr!”

Dipper smirked at this reaction, though his pulse did race. He heard movement behind him and spun around. “Though the hunter is brave and fierce, being tiny, in the dark, and knowing that some terrible creature is hunting you can make anyone nervous. Ahh! There it is again.” He spun, this time following the movement in the dark for a short ways before losing track. Then it spoke.

“Fee, fi, foe, fum! I smell the flesh of a yummy minizoram,” boomed the beast in a low yet feminine voice.

“Not bad,” Dipper nodded respectfully. “But you’ll have to do better if you wish to best me, monster.”

“Mwahahaha! Tiny fool. You dare come into my territory and think that you’ll walk out alive?”

“That is the general idea. Yes.”

“Well too bad. Cuz I crave minizora flesh, and you, ain’t goin’, no-where. Haha-hahaaa!” She sang in reference to one of her favorite movies.

Dipper was growing more anxious by the minute. The beast was moving more now, hopping from place to dark place. He held his weapon close as his vision could only reach so far, yet he couldn’t keep the smile off his face. “Th-the hunter is not afraid. H-he will best you, vile demon. He will claim what is his and return triumphant to his sister!”

“Oh, a sister?” said the beast, intrigued. “My yummy morsel has a sister? Heheheee. Tell me about her. Is she cute?”

Dipper wobbled his hand uncertainly while wearing a shit-eating-grin. “Eh. She’s alright.” He then felt a mighty thud just behind him, followed by a gust of hot air on his back. Knowing what was coming, he spun around to behold his doom.

“Boo.”

“Gaaah! The giant face of the monstrous Mable!” Chin to the ground, her face was illuminated by one of the few lamps in the room, which casted some extra menacing shadows. Her eyes were wide with anticipation and her grin was fighting against her malicious persona. And Dipper knew, just beyond where he couldn’t see, she most likely wasn’t wearing anything more than underwear.

“Time for din-din.”

The monster opened its mouth and stuck out its tongue, but Dipper wasn’t having it. Spoon at the ready, he swatted the slimy appendage away and took advantage of the distraction to flee. “Not tonight, big head.” But as he turned to face ahead, he saw movement incoming through the darkness. “Oh no!” He knew what it was and tried to duck by rolling underneath. It worked and the hand past right over him. Those agility tests were already paying off.

“Hey, no fair!” whined the monster. “Get in my mouth.” She stood tall and surveyed the area. In the attic, the space between the beds was littered with obstacles like stacks of books, discarded clothes, that one overturned nightstand, and anything else that gave her prey ample places to hide. “Grr. I’ll find you eventually, you little sweetie. Then we’ll see who has the big head.”

“It’ll still be you,” Dipper called from his hiding spot, immediately regretting his decision.

Grinning wide, her braces gleaming in the florescent light, Mable stomped through the obstacles, but not so hard to disturb those down stairs. Breaking character, she casually observed, “It was nice of Grunkle Stan to install that extra insulation. Gives us more privacy.”

“Especially with how cheap he is,” agreed Dipper. “Say, why do you think the Shack is so Minizora accessible, anyway?” He dared peek out of his book tent, finding Mable’s bent over backside wiggling in the air as she investigated somewhere else. Her panties were pink and frilly. And, from experience, he knew this pair to be especially soft.

“Don’t know. You should ask him some time.” She lifted her head high and made a show of sniffing. “I smell *sniff-sniff* minizora sweat.”

Dipper lifted his arm and sniffed under his pit, but didn’t smell anything. He might have said as much, if his cover hadn’t been swiped away.

“Ah-ha!” Mable lunged down for another grab, but a spoon smack to the knuckle made her retreat. “Ee! Ow, not so hard,” she hissed while rubbing herself.

“Oh my gosh, I’m sorry!”

“Well you should be. With how strong you’ve gotten, I might get nerve damage.” She sucked in a shocked breath. “Or maybe I’ll have to get my finger amputated!” With Dipper’s deadpan upon her, she added in even greater distress, “Then how am I gonna poke your tummy like the Burypills Flour Boy?”

“With nine other fingers, I’m sure you’ll get by.”

“Ha! Joke’s on you. I only have seven other fingers. The thumbs don’t count.”

“Mable, that’s pedantic even for me.”

“Wait, so does this mean I’ve out-Dippered Dipper?” she asked elatedly.

Dipper rolled his eyes. “No, but it does mean you-”

“Got’ch’ya!” Again Mable lunged, but this time she succeeded in scooping up the tiny boy. Beaming in triumph, she brought him up to her face.

“Hey, that’s cheating! We were in timeout.”

“Pssh. I never called timeout, so it’s fair play.” Mable waved dismissively as she opened her fingers, allowing Dipper to stand freely on her palm. It also let her more easily admire his barely clothed form.

“You said you were hurt. That’s an automatic timeout.”

“Nuh-uh. That rule is only if you get hurt. I could break all my arms and legs and we’d still be playing.” She sounded almost bragging. “Unless, of course, you chickened out and surrendered.”

Staring up at her in defiance, Dipper’s spoon was propped up by his side like a spear. He looked quite regal, and even a little photogenic. Careful not to disturb him, Mable held her hand steady as she reached for her phone and took a picture. “Oh yeah. Very cool.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “I still say this win is illegitimate.”

“Well, I’ve got you now, so I don’t really care,” Mable giggled cutely. “So then, brave hunter,” she tittered again, “what do you think I should do with you?”

1: Something Sweet
2: Something Fun
1152111111111111111111111.title: The Hunt

11521111111111111111111111.content:
Satisfied that the door was locked so that no one could intrude on their fun, Mable decided to hold off on devouring her prey right away. Once they’d cleaned up enough to avoid any nasty surprises in the morning, Mable leaned back in bed and dropped Dipper on her sternum between her flat breasts, petting him gently as she hummed a soft tune to herself.

“Not that I’m complaining, but this isn’t exactly what I was expecting,” Dipper thought aloud, risking ending this relaxing moment.

“The way I see it, I’m cute, kittens are cute, and since kittens like to play with their food, I figure I should try doing the same. I’ll push you around a little before I’m ready for the real fun. It’s like foreplay, only better because you’re also small and cute.”

“Interesting logic,” Dipper observed as she started poking around his loincloth.

“I still can’t believe you went on that whole big adventure without me. You must’ve been so scared.”

“At first, yeah. The manotaurs made Manly Dan run away screaming. But once you stop and talk to them, they’re really not all that bad.”

“Except with the Multibear,” Mable reminded coldly. In her mind, all bullies were undeserving of any respect.

“Yeah. They were bullies, but other than that, they were alright. Pretty easy to manage once you know how to manipulate them.” Dipper lifted his hand and grabbed Mable’s finger. She stopped immediately, likely expecting him to say he wanted to get up or something. Instead, he just ran his hand along her digit, petting her in return as they both stared up at the ceiling.

“This is nice, just the two of us,” Mable hummed contentedly. “So did you really talk to a wolf?”

“It wasn’t really a talk. More like a moment of shared understanding. I can’t really explain it, though. We just sort of… clicked, and then went our separate ways.”

Mable blew a raspberry. “Boo. I would have pet it.”

“And that’s why I got to go on the big adventure of self-discovery in nature while you got to stay home and ship Stan. Did that actually work out?”

“Don’t think so, but it was still fun.” Then Mable recalled something. “You know, Stan said some things about minizora.”

“Oh yeah?” Dipper asked, bracing himself for something stupid, offensive, or both.

“Yeah. He said that when minizora have loving families, they tend to get overprotective, which just stresses them out a lot. He said that a little distance can be good for both of us, making you feel less stifled and me less worried.”

Dipper craned his neck to look up at Mable, awed by such insightful words from the con man. “And?”

She sighed. “At first I was just doing stuff with Stan to take my mind off you. He kept saying you’d be fine and I believed him. Honestly, it was kind of nice being able to do stuff without you for a change.” It sounded like a hard confession. Mable lifted her head to look down at the boy on her chest, eyes apologetic. “And you?”

“I guess it was kind of the same for me. I don’t think I’ve ever run so far on my own in my life. It was freaky at first, not having you as my safety net, but then it got exciting. I did all that amazing stuff on my own. I proved I could, and now I feel a lot tougher for it.”

Mable then poked under his armpit, making him giggle. “You’re still a scrawny minizora, though.”

After being allowed to push her finger away and getting his laughter under control, Dipper sighed. “I still missed you, though. It was nice doing stuff by myself, but the whole time I kept thinking about you. What you’d say if you saw me doing that stuff. How the manotaurs would try to stop you from stopping me.” He snickered and rested his head back on her chest. “Mable vs. a pack of thirty manotaurs. Seems like an even fight.”

“Yeah, well I’m glad to have you back, too. I’m also glad you kept your new underwear.”

“It’s a loincloth.”

“It’s cute and makes you look like an authentic jungle boy. Now if we could only get you a tan so you’re not so pasty.”

“I’d say that’s your fault. You’re the one always covering me up whenever it gets too hot out.”

“Hey. Old habits are hard to break, especially for a big sister looking after her baby brother.”

“Little,” Dipper asserted flatly. “I tolerate being called little, but I draw the line at baby. I was born first, remember. So technically-”

“Actually,” Mable cut in authoritatively, “I’m the big sister. Always will be. And you’ll always be my adorable itty bitty wittle bwo-bwo.”

“Keep up the baby talk, and I’ll go find the spoon and smack you again.”

Mable laughed. “Sure. Go ahead. I’ll wait, wittle bwo-bwo.”

Dipper rolled his eyes. “Eh, too tired. Bed’s too soft.” He yawned. “Remind me to do it tomorrow.”

Mable yawned as well and flipped off the last light. “Sure thing.”
11521111111111111111111111.title: Bedside Chat

115211111111111111111111111.content:
Grunkle Stan had cleared out the big room over on the side of the Mystery Shack to get things ready for the party. It wasn’t anyone’s birthday or anything. Stan just hoped that presenting himself as a fun loving guy would make him look more trustworthy, which in turn would make it easier for him to con people. Once the old man got sick of the kids just fooling around with silly string, he sent them to his personal copy machine to print out some flyers.

Mable threw the tarp off the old machine. When Stan had said that he’d “fixed it up,” he apparently meant that he’d slapped some duct tape in random places and didn’t even bother to dust.

“Well this is a fire hazard just waiting to happen,” Dipper commented as parts sparked. “Does it even work?” Clambering up to the controls, he tried messing with the buttons while Mable rested her arm on the scanner. The machine roared to life and scanned the arm. And after belching out a cloud of black smoke, a sheet of paper was produced with the arm on it.

“Ha, success,” Mable cheered, holding the paper in one hand and a cup of soda in the other. “Hey, want to copy our butts next?”

Dipper gave his sister a no-nonsense scowl and crossed his arms. “I’m very disappointed with you, Mable.” Then, just as her smile started to fall, he added, “That’s like asking if I want to breathe. Of course we’re copying our butts!”

Mable’s joy was short lived as the paper began to move on its own and crumbled. She dropped it and backed to a safe distance, grabbing Dipper along the way. The paper continued to shimmer, wrinkle, and flatten itself on the floor until the black-and-white image became colored. The arm swelled until it popped right off the paper, now three dimensional and capable of autonomous movement. Reaching out as though in silent pain, it started to crawl towards the twins.

“Ahh, stay back,” cried Dipper, jumping out of Mable’s hand and positioning himself between her and the arm. There was something almost poetic about his enemy being a copy of the very thing that had always brought him such comfort.

“Back you fiend!” Not knowing what else to do, Mable splashed her drink onto the arm. It sizzled, bubbled, and then dissolved completely, leaving nothing behind but a puddle of soda mixed with liquefied paper.

“Oh my gosh! Mable, I think this copier can copy human beings!”

Mable sucked in a breath and got down to her brother’s level. “Do you know what this means?” But before he could answer, she sprayed him with silly string. “He-he, you let your guard down.”

Dipper waved his arms frantically as he dug his way out of the pink substance. “Come on, Mable. This is serious. This is like, like an actual cloning machine. It just did your arm, and it moved on its own. Severed arms aren’t supposed to move on their own.”

“Oh my gosh, you’re right.” Then Mable looked thoughtful; a dangerous expression on such a cute face. “So does this mean we’re not going to copy our butts anymore?”

“I… don’t know.” Dipper admitted. “Hmm. Let’s think about this for a second. This isn’t some wild animal or sapient phenomenon like the last few times. This is just a machine. It can’t do anything without someone to turn it on. It copies people, but since Grunkle Stan’s had it for years and never noticed anything weird, it must also work on paper just fine. And apparently things supernaturally copied can be destroyed with just a bit of soda, so as long as we keep some nearby, we can keep things under control. If this were an SCP, it’d probably be considered safe.”

“I’m not hearing a no~ho,” Mable sang.

“But that brings up the ethical questions,” Dipper continued, starting to hyperventilate. “Are these things alive? Do they feel pain? If I copy my face, is that a person? Did I just create a person without a body? How long could something like that survive? There’s just so much we need to consider before-”

“Too late!” Mable was sitting on the copier, skirt up and panties around her ankles. The machine buzzed to life, but at least produced a copy without any black smoke this time. As before, the paper crumbled and shimmered until the copied part popped right off.

“Yup. That’s your butt alright,” deadpanned Dipper. He’d recognize that thing anywhere, though it was more than just her butt. It was Mable’s cheeks, taint, slit, a couple of flailing stumps where the legs should be, it went up about an inch past her hips, and all encased in her skirt.

“Wow, this is amazing,” Mable awed, picking up her own bottom. *Pfft* “Ew, it farted on me, hehe,” she was having too much fun to be grossed out as she started dancing with her disembodied pelvis. “Oh wait, no. I farted on me, haha. This is great!”

“This is wrong on so many levels. I don’t even know where to start,” Dipper grumbled. “Does that thing even have a stomach? Where did the gas come from for the fart?”

Alas, Mable wasn’t listening. She’d taken to feeling up her clone segment, which was apparently very interesting. “Oooh! I’m so soft and squishy. Hmm. A bit too squishy right here. Dipper, am I fat?”

“After all the running from monsters we’ve done, I don’t think we could be out of shape if we tried.”

“Oh good. But what’s with this smell?” She pressed her nose in between the stumps. “Is that how my kitty always smells? Here, you check.” Whether deliberate or by accident, Mable dropped the clone ass right on top of her tiny brother.

“We just discovered cloning and you want me to smell your clone’s butt?” Dipper asked incredulously as he was pinned down by the familiar set of soft, warm cheeks.

“Not my butt, my kitty. I want to make sure it doesn’t smell weird. You know, for hygiene purposes,” she added bashfully. “You smell me all the time, so you’d know what’s different.”

Dipper rolled his eyes and took a nasal inhale. “It smells fine.”

“Really?”

“Yeah, just like it always does, which I’m pretty sure just raises more questions.”

“Good point,” Mable agreed. “For example: if I wanted to go out and make sure you weren’t kidnapped by crazy bull monsters with weird penises, would this make a good cage?” she asked while patting the clone’s butt.

“First of all, I wasn’t kidnapped. It was voluntary. Secondly, we both know you’d sooner shove me in your own underwear before using… whatever that is.”

“Eh. True.”

“And thirdly, how are you being so calm about this!?”

“Because you overthink things, which leads to stress. While I go with the flow,” Mable bragged, “which leads to sunshine and peace.”

Dipper’s eye began to twitch. He hated when Mable used actual logic against him instead of Mable logic.

Do they continue through the story, or keep playing with the machine?
115211111111111111111111111.title: Party Planning

1152111111111111111111111111.content:
After disposing of the clone, the twins had agreed to a truce regarding the machine. They’d wait until things were less busy around here so that they could ‘experiment’ in peace. In the meantime, Stan was giving out tasks for the party. Soos was the DJ and because Mable wanted to try and make some new friends, Dipper volunteered to man the ticket booth with Wendy. And given that they’d have to stay there, together, all night, it was the best possible scenario.

“You dog, you,” Mable teased when they were back up in the attic, poking Dipper’s shoulder as he straightened his bowtie.

“I have no idea what you’re talking about.”

“Dipper, you obviously have a thing for Wendy. You couldn’t have been more desperate when you agreed to be with her.”

“Yeah, yeah. Whatever. But I’ll have you know that I have a plan to make sure my night with Wendy goes perfect.”

“Plan?” Mable whined her disappointment. “You’re not making one of those overcomplicated listy things, are you?”

“You say overcomplicated, but I say thorough.” Dipper extracted a piece of paper from his vest, unfolding it until it was three times his size. “Step one: get to know each other with playful banter. Banter is like talking, but smarter.”

“So smart it loops right back around to being stupid.”

“Yeah, see, this isn’t banter. This is what I’d like to avoid with Wendy. The last step will be asking her to dance.”

“Dipper, you and me talk like regular people, and that’s what you’re trying to avoid?”

“Well…”

“Oh, little brother.” Mable shook her head, sat down, and gently set him on her knee. “Allow me to impart my wisdom. You see, back before I learned that Gideon was a horrible, horrible monster who deserves to suffer and die alone,” she explained cheerfully, “we would just talk and do things we both liked. I’d say whatever came to mind, he’d comment, and we just went back and forth like that. That’s what I liked about him. He was easy to talk to. And that’s what I’ll be looking for tonight with friend making; people I can talk with. Whatever happens with Wendy, I guarantee the real first step isn’t banter, it’s talking.”

Dipper was speechless. What could he say after a lecture like that?

Pleased by his reaction, Mable touched under his chin to close his jaw. “Remember we agreed to trust each other with our love lives? I’ve done my part and given my opinion. It’s up to you to make the final choice.”

Once the party finally got underway, things went about as well as could be expected. Soos was goofing up picking the right sound effects, Stan was charging an exit fee, Mable was optimistic as ever, Dipper was mortified that his sweaty pits would stain his suit, and Wendy played it cool despite having similar worries.

The ticket stand was surprisingly packed, keeping the two pretty busy. Telling himself that Wendy was less scary than the Multibear, Dipper decided it was on him to break the ice. “So, uh…” His mind blanked. Crap-crap-crap! He had to say something. Anything! “Uh… have you ever heard of a Multibear before?” Why!?

“Oh, did my dad tell you that one?”

“Huh?”

“Yeah. He’s got all kinds of stories about the stuff he claims to see out in the woods.” Wendy tapped her fingers as she listed them off. “The Multibear, gnomes, tiny deer, a magic mailbox… Oh, my favorite is the Hide Behind.”

Dipper touched his chin in thought. “That sounds familiar.”

“Yeah. It’s this thing dad’s never actually seen. No one has, because it always hides behind stuff whenever people look its way. The only proof that it’s even there is this buzzing sound it makes as it follows you,” Wendy laughed. “Can you believe that? It’s a monster that just trolls people, following them and freaking them out. Man, if I were a monster, that’s what I’d want to be.”

“Oh, that’s interesting. You wouldn’t want to be, like, a mermaid or something?”

“No way, dude. Mermaids live in the ocean, which is, like, half fish piss. That’s gross,” she snickered as Dipper did the same. “Besides, the only thing they wear is seashell bikinis, and I don’t really have the figure for that.”

“I think you do,” blurted the tiny before he could stop himself.

“Huh?”

“What?”

“What’d you say?”

“Nothing.”

“Oh-ho, no. You’re not getting out of this that easily.” Her attention fully on Dipper, Wendy still managed to trade tickets for money and count the change. “You definitely said something.”

“You can’t prove that.”

Wendy glowered, trying to look menacing as she loomed over the puny child. With Dipper unflinching, her façade lasted a whopping couple of seconds before she descended into giggles. “Wow, dude. You’re really something, ya know that.”

“I am?”

“Yeah. I mean, if I were your size, and someone this big was trying to push me around,” she gestured to herself, “I’d probably start squealing inside an hour.”

“No way. You’re way tougher than that.”

“Aww, you think so?”

“Yeah. You could easily go an hour and a half.”

Never one to let such impudence stand, Wendy set her fingers in prime flicking position right beside Dipper. She waited, giving him a chance to tell her that this wasn’t okay. With is defiance holding fast she carefully delivered a flick to the back of Dipper’s head, which he laughed off. “Watch that mouth of yours, little man. You never know what kind of mess it might get you into.” She got back to work, not hating it nearly as much as she’d expected.

With her attention back on the customers, Dipper allowed his eyes to crawl up and down the red head’s body, focusing on a couple potential messes he wouldn’t mind getting into.

Meanwhile, inside the party hall, Mable was taking a break after shaking what her momma gave her. Upon seeing something interesting, she took her own advice and said the first thing that came to mind. “Wow, you’ve got an animal on your body! I’m Mable.”

Grenda was a big girl. Not fat, as it was clearly all muscle. Her arms were about as thick as Mable’s torso and she was about a head and a half taller to boot. She was also a bit more developed chest wise. Her voice was pretty deep, but Mable found it cute. Beside her was Candy. She was tiny, Korean, and had an even cuter voice, which for some reason Mable pictured coming out of an elongated rainbow horse thingy. She had a bunch of forks strapped to her fingers which she used to eat popcorn. “Improvement of human being,” she’d called it. And just like that, Mable knew she’d found her people.

When Soos made an announcement of a party crown award, for some reason bad girl music started playing. Coincidentally, a blonde girl and her cohorts approached the stage. She wore hoop earrings and mostly purple attire, hair was teen pageant huge, and Mable’s eye twitched when she saw the size of her chest.

“Who’s that?”

“The most popular girl in town, Pacifica Northwest,” informed Candy.

“I always feel bad about myself around her,” Grenda added.

Pacifica was demanding that the crown simply be given to her, but Soos insisted that it be a competition. “Ha, who’s going to compete against me, Pacifica?” she asked, taking a microphone and gesturing into the audience. “Fork girl? Thunder thighs?” She and her cronies laughed, although they were the only ones. Everyone else just stood by, looking helpless.

“Hey, I’ll compete!” Mable exclaimed, ever the picture of glee, although internally was a different matter. She’d just decided to like Candy and Grenda, which made Pacifica’s comments unacceptable. However, she was still willing to give the bleach blonde a chance and offered the hand of friendship. “Hi, I’m Mable.”

Pacifica looked at the offered hand like it had just come out of the sewer. “Ha, that sounds like a fat old lady’s name.”

“I choose to take that as a compliment.”

Pacifica’s grin grew smug. She knew she had this in the bag. “May the best partier win.” Then she and her cronies danced a retreat into the shadows.

Mable waved goodbye. “Nice meeting you… dead girl,” she added under her breath, much to the approval of her new friends.
1152111111111111111111111111.title: Let's Party!

11521111111111111111111111111.content:
“No way. You’re full of it,” Wendy waved dismissively, showing excellent multitasking by taking people’s money while finding the time to talk to Dipper.

“I am not. I could totally take the Multibear,” asserted the minizora. At his size, he had to run around the table to get the tickets and the money where it needed to go. This was probably a job one big person could do by themselves, but he was content just being on support if it meant talking to Wendy.

“Yeah, right. Dad said he once saw the thing use deer antlers to pick its teeth. How would you deal with something like that?”

Dipper smirked. “Easy. See, the Multibear’s weakness is its many heads.”

“What, like a hydra?”

“Not exactly. See, all the heads share control over all the limbs. Normally they’re mostly in harmony, but distract them with enough pain, like by kicking it in the balls, and you can trick the lesser heads into beating themselves up for you.”

“Oh man!” Wendy laughed, wiping tears from her eyes. “You are too much, little man.”

“Really? I’ve always thought of myself as just the right amount.”

Unlike Dipper, Wendy’s filter was working perfectly fine, which she used to stop herself from making an age inappropriate joke. Not for his sake, but there were some little kids and their parents buying tickets, and she’d have preferred to avoid a lecture. She couldn’t remember the last time she had this much fun while on the clock and not ditching. All in all, everything was going perfectly fine, which was why things had to go wrong.

Robbie showed up. With his usual aloof attitude, he said, “Hey Wendy. So there’s this lame dance going on. Care to join me?”

“Oh gee, Robbie, I’d love to, but I’ve kinda got a job to do out here.”

Robbie scoffed. “Since when do you care about work?”

“I… don’t know.” It was a fair question.

“Come on, babe.” He extended his hand. “Shorty here can take on ghosts. I’m sure he’ll be fine by himself.”

“Uh, I don’t know. Dipper?” She turned to the minizora, eyes full of concern.

It would have been the easiest thing in the world. Easier than failing to fly. Dipper need only say that he needed Wendy’s help, or that he wanted her to stay. Both were good, though the former was less embarrassing. He just had to give some indicator that he didn’t want Wendy to go, and she wouldn’t. Easiest thing ever. “Nah, I’m good. If you want to dance, then go for it.” In his head, Dipper proceeded to scream every expletive in the English language.

“Well, if you’re sure.”

“Oh he’s sure,” assured Robbie before pulling Wendy inside.

As Dipper swore at himself, he paused in selling tickets long enough to climb up the wall and peek through the window. Wendy looked to be having fun, dancing with Robbie. The minizora returned down to the table about a second before Wendy turned a concerned look back towards the window, her dance moves less energetic than usual. Had their eyes met, maybe they’d have realized a thing or two. But since that didn’t happen, things inevitably got crazy.

It didn’t take Dipper long to reach the (il)logical conclusion. Grunkle Stan wouldn’t allow him to back out on his promise, but he was allowed bathroom breaks. He took advantage of this loophole to make for the copier and laid himself on the scanner. The clone was almost completely identical in both behavior and appearance. The only obvious difference was that his colors seemed slightly muted and his hat lacked a pine tree. They even thought alike, agreeing to the name Tyrone after Dipper drew a 2 on the clone’s hat.

It was only after agreeing to the plan that Dipper remembered that he’d seen this cliché before and how it always went sideways. “Hey, we’re not gonna get jealous and turn on each other like the clones in the movies, are we?” But Tyrone assured him that Dipper could trust himself, and also that he could just be disintegrated with soda, demonstrating a terrifying lack of self-preservation.

Whatever. With Tyrone manning the ticket stand, Dipper was free to enter the dance floor. He was immediately reminded why he generally hated dancing. The music was so loud that it drowned his voice out and people were so focused on wild movements that they ignored anything or anyone that might be underfoot. In under a minute, he’d suffered 17 encounters with shoes, scuffing his vest. He only barely made it to the chairs for cover when his phone rang.

“Hey buddy. It’s me, you,” Tyrone said. “I just now remembered why we hate dancing.”

“I know, it’s terrible. I can’t even get near Wendy and Robbie’s showing off his guitar. Ahh! Now they’re sitting on the couch. We’ve got to do something.” That’s when he noticed a bicycle. “I just got an idea.”

“I got the same one, but we’re gonna need help.”

“Also, how are you calling me?” Dipper asked. “It’s the same phone, so shouldn’t it have the same number?”

“No idea, man. Might want to tell Grunkle Stan about it, though. Selling clone machines for cheap could bring in some extra money, so long as he’s honest about them dissolving.”

While Dipper was spiraling with the clones, Mable was dealing with her own challenge. It had come to the singing part of the competition and Pacifica had just delivered a beautiful solo. Mable might have been moved to tears, if the blonde bitch hadn’t just said more mean things about her new friends. Her counterattack involved the eightiesest, crowd pleasingest, rock balladest song at Soos’ disposal. And with the passion she put into those words, the crowd had no choice but to love it.

That’s when Dipper set his plan in motion, having several of his clones steal Robbie’s bike and having the stupid emo wannabe give chase.

“Oh wow, that sucks.”

“Dipper!?” Wendy asked in alarm of the minizora on the couch arm. She couldn’t see too well in the dim light, but it looked like his vest had been scuffed. Did he seriously risk getting stepped on just to bail on selling tickets? More so, Wendy felt a knot form deep down in her gut. She’d just left the little guy alone with all those strangers. Who knows what could have happened. “What are you doing here?”

“Don’t worry. I got someone to cover me. It’s cool.”

“Uh, okay,” she agreed uncertainly. Wendy chose to trust Dipper’s judgement. He knew more about being a minizora than her, so if he thought he was alright in here, then she had no room to argue. The music then shifted to something soft and smooth, perfect for romantic dancing. “Oh man, I love this song.” Still sitting, Wendy swayed to the beat, trying to focus on relaxing.

“Hey, goofus,” Mable greeted. The competition was on hold, so she decided that her services as a big sister were needed. “Now’s your chance to ask-mmm.”

Dipper needed to use both hands to seal his sister’s lips shut. He then allowed himself to be carried out of earshot before releasing his grip.

“Who’s responsible for this?” Tone dangerous, Mable pointed to the scuff marks around his clothes.

“No one. I, uh, didn’t see their faces.” Dipper waved his hand, wanting to hurry things along. “There’s no need to make a scene.”

“Fine, whatever. But this is your chance to ask Wendy to dance. Come on. Gooo!” Whisper cheering, Mable set her brother back down on the floor.

“R-right,” Dipper agreed. Being set back down, he started marching forward like a malfunctioning robot. What happened to the easy talking he’d been doing earlier? Dammit! Fortunately, the teeny actually managed to make it back to the couch. Unfortunately, thinking that he was still with Mable, Wendy got up and went elsewhere. Double dammit!

With his plans falling apart all around him, Dipper proceeded to spiral further out of control with his clones. There were clones to manage the music, to keep an eye out for Robbie, and in general take control of all factors on the dance floor to ensure optimal dancing conditions. And as the old saying goes, the more complicated something is, the easier it is to break.
11521111111111111111111111111.title: Double Dipper

115211111111111111111111111111.content:
The first break in Dipper’s plan was in cloning himself. The first break he actually noticed came much later. With everything set exactly as he believed it should be, Dipper headed for his own position, only to run into…

“Wendy? Wh-what are you doing here?”

“Just waiting for the bathroom, dude.” Leaning casually against the wall, she then got a wicked idea and adopted a playful smirk. “You’re not going to try sneaking a peek under the door, are you?”

“Wh-wh-what!? N-no! No, I would never do anything like that to you!”

“Not to me, huh? So other girls, then? Am I not good enough for you?”

Hands balled into fists, Dipper’s whole body began to shake as he turned redder than a tomato.

“Hey, hey. Chill, little dude.” She knelt down on one knee and began stroking his back as she’d seen Mable do. “I was just kidding around.”

Dipper’s breathing evened out and he returned to his regular color. “You know I’d never do that though, right?”

“Yeah, man. I know you’re better than that.”

As good as that was to hear, Dipper still found himself staring at his feet.

Wendy’s smile also fell as it finally clicked. “Someone told lies about you, didn’t they?”

Dipper adjusted his hat so that his face was hidden.

Heaving a sigh, Wendy sat herself down beside the little man. “Mom always told me to never listen to what dumb-asses had to say. If they can’t see how great you are, then just let ‘em stew in their own misery, because that’s all they’ve got. They’re just a bunch of miserable losers with nothing going for ‘em except bringing others down to their level. Don’t let ‘em, dude.”

“And what would you know about it?” Dipper grumbled, suddenly not so enthused about dancing.

Wendy was a little upset by his tone, but decided to let it slide. “I know what it’s like to have my head shoved in a toilet, for one. I also know what it’s like to have a bunch of scum bags talk behind my back.”

After rubbing his arm against his eyes, Dipper finally lifted his hat to look up at Wendy. “You?”

“Yeah,” she laughed uncomfortably. “Believe it or not, grade school was pretty much hell for me. Every day it was some new rumor, pushing in the hallway, stealing my homework, you name it.”

“But… your parents.”

“Yeah, I know. My dad could beat up any other dad in town and mom could… Uh, the point is that I didn’t want to bother them. My folks were my heroes and I didn’t want to let them down by looking weak.” As Wendy explained, indulging in memories she’d tried to bury, she felt her own eyes start to water.

“So, what did you do?”

“The only thing I could do.” Windy downed half of her drink. “I found someone weaker than me, and then I beat the shit out of the shits who were beating him.”

Dipper’s cheeks swelled like a frog’s as he contained his surprised laugh.

“Yeah, it was the damndest thing. For some reason I could never stand up for myself, but it turned out a lot easier to stand up for others. I started fighting back and, of course, only then did the school take notice. My folks were called, but I never got it too bad. Pretty sure they suspected what was going on, but were letting me handle things my way.” Wendy chuckled quietly to herself. “So I kept getting into fights until the bullies got the message and backed off. That’s actually how I met the crew. We were all getting pushed around, but together we were able to start pushing back.”

“Wendy, you’re… amazing,” Dipper said in awe.

“Nah, dude. You’re amazing. You stood up to a pair of ghosts while I was cowering in a soda machine. You really think those shitty people who lied about you could do better?”

Averting his gaze, Dipper started to chuckle.

“So keep that in mind the next time people start talking shit about ya.” With her fist, Wendy gently pushed against Dipper’s side. “Don’t let the bullies bring you down to their level, man. It’s the only way you’ll really lose.”

At long last the bathroom door opened and out stomped a very irate blonde girl in purple.

“Yeesh, finally! Been holding it in for ages.” Wendy set down her drink, stood, and entered, but paused before closing the door. “Oh, and Dipper. Just so we’re clear, if I catch you peeking, I’m flushing you.” They shared one more laugh before she departed. In truth, she had no idea what she’d do. Would she just pretend not to notice? If she did catch him… She’d overheard Mable talk about punishing him more than once. Maybe, with Mable’s permission, she could-No! Nope! Bad brain. Don’t go there!

Outside, Dipper felt like a great weight had been lifted off his shoulders. He and Wendy had just made a real connection. Nothing could ruin this moment.

“Hey, Dipper,” snapped Tyrone. He was being flanked by several other clones, all looking most displeased. “What are you doing here? We’re already 42 seconds behind schedule.”

“Guys, the most amazing thing happened. I ran into Wendy by accident and we… we made a connection!”

“That’s nice, but not the plan,” Tyrone dismissed, pulling out the list and reciting the steps.

“Wow, is that what I sound like? Uh, guys, maybe we don’t need the plan anymore. Maybe I can just talk to Wendy like a normal person.”

“You shut your whore mouth!” accused 6.

“Well, if you’re not going to stick to the plan, then maybe you shouldn’t be the Dipper who dances with Wendy,” 5 suggested to the agreement of the others.

“Guys, we said we weren’t going to turn on each other,” Dipper intoned, bracing himself to run.

“I think we all knew we were lying.”

Dipper held out his hands. “Hold on a second. Before this gets nasty, can I just say one thing?” The clones seemed reluctant, but gave their permission. Dipper urgently pointed behind them and shouted, “Oh my god, a naked manotaur!” As the clones screamed in horror, Dipper tried to make a break for it, but the others quickly caught up and overpowered him, dragging him off to be detained.

The alliance between the clones inevitably broke down as they began fighting for dominance. No one knew what to do anymore and some clones along the outskirts were still doing their jobs. Dipper, meanwhile, was able to take advantage of the confusion and herd almost all of the clones back to the bathroom hall. There he found and spilled Wendy’s discarded drink, finally putting an end to 90% of his mess… by watching himself melt and cry out in mildly bummed pain.

“I am going to make my therapist a fortune.”
115211111111111111111111111111.title: Don't Let Them Pull You Down

1152111111111111111111111111111.content:
The final break came as Mable and Pacifica were awaiting the final song before the judging.
“Pacifica, I just want to say that whoever wins, it’s been a super fun party.” Again Mable offered the hand of friendship.
“Aww, it thinks it’s gonna win,” condescended Pacifica. “Hey, you hear people clapping for the weird girl? Yeah, me neither.” And she walked away, strutting like she owned the place, right out of Mable’s reach.
Having just made some new friends, Mable was in an extra good mood. She didn’t even really care about winning. What mattered was watching her friends smile as she stood up for them. Speaking of support, she just spied her oldest and most favoritest supporter of all time on the dance floor. “Hey! Hey, Dipper,” she called, cup of soda in one hand and the other waving frantically as she ran over. Something looked weird about him. He seemed unusually stressed and maybe a bit off color. Did he bomb with Wendy? And why was he putting himself in needless danger out in the middle of the dance floor. “What are you doing here without W-whoop!”
The taller twin tripped and fell with a low thud. No big deal. Dipper wasn’t the only tough twin around and she’d dealt with worse in just the last few weeks. Except down here on the ground, she was given front row seats to where her soda spilled. Her eyes went wide as the thing’s form lost its cohesion quickly; its cries were more annoyed than pained. It was all over in just a few seconds and no one else saw a thing. Someone distracted by dancing even callously stepped in the puddle of remains like it was nothing. The thing that used to look like Dipper had been reduced to goop. Then there came a snapping sound as Mable felt her smile grow wide. It was so big that it threatened to split her face in half. If it weren’t for her eye twitching, Mable would have looked like the happiest girl in the world.
She picked herself up and brushed herself off. No big deal. She turned bodily towards the copier. There was something important that she needed to deal with, but no big deal. Mable maneuvered her way through the crowd, not offering her usual words of encouragement as her eyes never strayed from her target. It was no big deal. Then, as music and general noise blared all around her, someone stepped right in her path. Okay, possible big deal.
“Hey, where do you think you’re going, weirdy?” demanded Pacifica haughtily.
“Just got something to take care of. It’s no big deal,” Mable answered, sounding distant. She tried to move around, but her path was blocked yet again.
“Ha, I knew it. Weird girl knows she can’t win, so she’s chickening out before she can suffer a humiliating defeat. I don’t blame you, really,” Pacifica said while examining her nails. “It’s to be expected when you go up against… Hey, get back here!”
“Just gotta take care of something,” Mable said, still smiling and distant. “It’s no big deal.”
Pacifica snapped her fingers and her cronies blocked Mable’s path. “No one turns their back on Pacifica. Do you have any idea who I am?” Then something extra unsettling happened. “Hey, why are you laughing?” Mable was chuckling under her breath. It was a low and sinister sound. The cronies could see her face, and so backed away. With her allies beating a slow retreat, the rich girl started to think that she’d made a mistake.
“No,” Mable giggled. “I have no idea. Before today, I’d never even heard your name. But let me tell you something about me.” Mable spun around, turning the full force of her glower on Pacifica, making the blonde pee a little. “My second week here, I killed, like, ten people. I threw a fire poker through a man’s eye and tossed another man’s sonnet spewing head into the fire. And as I watched him burn, you want to know what I felt? Nothing!” Mable’s laugh was growing just a bit maniacal. “I was content, because I cared nothing for those people. They got in my way and threatened my happiness, so I gave them what they deserved.” She stepped into Pacifica’s personal space; almost nose-to-nose and forcing the other girl to lean back. “Guess who’s standing in my way now.”
“Me,” Pacifica squeaked like her lungs were full of helium.
“There’s a smart bitch. And they say blondes are stupid. Hehe. So what do you think you should do now?”
Pacifica’s answer was to fall backwards with a suspiciously heavy thud, eyes open but otherwise unconscious.
“Good choice.” And Mable turned back around. Except instead of resuming her mission, she looked into her new friends’ eyes and felt her conviction waver. She’d just shown the ugliest side of herself. Would they hate her for it? That was about the second or third most awful thing that could happen right now.
“Oh. My. Gosh! That was amazing!” Grenda boomed.
“You are everything I want to beee,” Candy added.
Mable’s smiled remained, but softened a bit as she felt 20 lbs. lighter. “Thanks guys. I really needed to hear that right now. Now if you’ll excuse me, there’s a thing I need to do.”
“Oh hey, can we come with you?”
“Yes. Share with us your secrets,” Candy begged.
“I’d be delighted. It’s always better to do things with friends.”
Later, Dipper was feeling a little down on himself. In all the commotion with the clones, he’d lost track of Wendy. When he’d found her again, she was talking and laughing with Robbie, seemingly having a really nice time. But as down as he felt, there was still a spark of hope deep down. He hadn’t actually lost Wendy. She was still very much his friend. They’d had a real talk, just as Mable had said, and right now that was enough to satisfy him. Dipper decided that it would probably be a good idea to unplug the copier to avoid any future temptation. When he arrived, he was greeted with the most interesting sight.
“Die! Die! Die!” Mable was standing on top of the machine, going nuts with a golf club.
“Whaaa!” Some big girl was absolutely waling on the poor contraption with her bare fists, ripping it to pieces.
“He-hehehe!” A Korean girl had burst out from one of the side compartments like a gleeful chest burster, miscellaneous wires in hand and laughing hysterically.
Then, even more frighteningly, all three girls came to a dead silence after Dipper sneezed. They all froze and stared at one another for a good long while. Dipper blinked and, in classic Weeping Angel fashion, all three girls manifested directly before him, chins on the ground, rears in the air, and staring transfixed at his tiny form. Their collective breath was hot and smelly.
Mable broke the silence and pulled out a cup of soda. “Dipper, I swear to god, if you melt, I’m gonna kill you.”
“Wait, wha-ahh!” The contents of the cup were dumped on the mini. “Hey, what was that for?”
“You know what,” Mable replied, eyes narrowing dangerously. Dipper didn’t need to inquire further.
“Oh. My. Gosh. He’s so cute!” Grenda gushed.
“I just want to pick him up and keep him in my purse like a celebrity dog,” Candy added.
“First things first, girls. Dipper, these are my new girlfriends. Candy and Grenda.” Mable gestured to each of them. “Second things first. Are there anymore?” Her tone grew low and dark.
“What? Uh, no. No I got them all. At least… hold on.” Dipper counted on his hands.
“Dipperrr,” Mable growled.
“Okay, there’s only one I can’t account for. Wait, you didn’t happen to-?”
“Yeah, I took care of it. Not by choice, but it’s gone now.”
“What are you two talking about?” asked Grenda.
“That copy machine can copy people,” Mable blurted without a second thought. “Doofus here said that we should be careful with it, and then made a bunch of clones behind my back.”
“Ohhh, that sounds fun,” whined Candy. “Why did we destroy it? I could have used a study buddy.”
“Because somebody broke his own rule, and now the game isn’t fun anymore.”
“Aww. Too bad,” Candy said, not pressing further. “Wait. You hear that?”
All four listened. There was quite the commotion coming from the main room, including the voice of Soos. “And the winner is Pacifica!”
“The competition. I missed it!” bemoaned Mable.
“There, there,” Candy soothed, petting the larger twin’s hair. “It is fine.”
“Yeah. You totally would have won if we didn’t destroy this machine.” Grenda gestured to the smoking hunk of metal. “But that was also pretty great. You’re pretty great Mable.”
“Aww, you guys.” Still on the floor, Mable pulled the other two into a hug and they all laughed.
Feeling like a third wheel, Dipper cleared his throat. With his eyes he asked if he was allowed to leave.
“No way, bro-bro.” Mable grabbed him and stood, the others following. “I’m not letting you out of my sight for the rest of the night. It’s the only way to make sure you don’t try any more stupid stuff.” There came a small explosion from the machine.
“You sure? Because I think it’s-”
“Don’t care!” Mable stuffed him into her shirt collar and led the charge back to the dance floor. “Come on girls. This thing’s going all night!”
And it did. For a good many hours. Wendy eventually joined the other girls on the mostly cleared floor, feeling so much livelier than before. Mable was even gracious enough to donate a few strands of her hair to wrap around Dipper’s waist as a kind of lifeline while he boogied on her shoulder. So, in a way, Dipper and Wendy did get their dance.
1152111111111111111111111111111.title: Mable Smiles

11521111111111111111111111111111.content:
There was an unusually heavy amount of traffic as Stan drove the twins through town. Mable was keeping herself entertained with nacho earrings and Stan was fighting the urge to road rage. However, the old man’s anger turned into fear when he finally noticed all the horses and covered wagons. “Oh no. Not today!” He started driving like a maniac, spouting a bunch of nonsense about getting away. As Mable slipped and slid in her seatbelt, she pulled Dipper from his minizora car seat and pressed him tightly to her chest where he’d surely be safer. When Stan finally stopped, encircled by some wagons, Mable looked out the window and saw an adorable baby cow with a bell around its neck.

“I’ve got a good feeling about today.”

It was Pioneer Day. No longer fighting it, Grunkle stan got out of the car and explained. “Every year these yahoos dress up like idiots to celebrate the day Gravity Falls was founded.” He then threatened to break Toby for talking with an accent.

The twins, however, were enthralled by the many attractions on display. Candle dipping, gold panning, and a marriage between a man and a woodpecker were the closest. As the twins got ready to enjoy the festivities, Grunkle Stan sent them off with a warning. “If you two come back talking like these people, you’re dead to me.”

Then, with a couple of preteens being forbidden from doing something even moderately fun, the unexpected happened.

“There’s a carpetbagger in the turnip cellar.” “Well hornswaggle my habbersack.” They then spat on the ground and Mable carried her brother off for fun and adventure.

“Dead to meee!” Stan shouted after them.

Sheriff Blubs was on a stage, welcoming everyone to the opening ceremony. Behind him and the deputy sat four people dressed in period appropriate attire. There was Pacifica, a little brunette girl half her age, and presumably their parents, all wearing self-satisfied grins. That’s when Pacifica took the mic. “Howdy, everyone. You all know me, Pacifica Northwest, great-great granddaughter of town founder Nathaniel Northwest.” She gestured to the regal statue behind her. The audience applauded. “Now if you’ve got the pioneer spirit, we ask you to come on up and introduce yourself.”

Mable gasped. “I get participation!”

From her shoulder, Dipper frowned. “I don’t know, Mable. Isn’t that girl kind of like your arch enemy?”

“That’s water under the bridge,” Mable laughed. But as she ran up on stage, she stowed Dipper in her sweater collar where he couldn’t be seen.

Pacifica held out her hand in welcome before looking. “Our first newcomer is M-Mable!?” she squeaked and stepped back. “Wh-what are you-?”

“Yeah, let’s get this pioneer day started,” Mable cheered, turning the mic around for this next part. She whispered, “Look Pacifica, I just want to apologize for what I said the other night.”

Pacifica remained frozen, barely even breathing.

“You caught me at a bad time and I said some things that were 100% true, but shouldn’t have said out loud, so I’ll make a deal. Whatever this thing is between us, it stays between us. Friends and family are off limits. Break that rule, and I’ll mess you up worse than infamous axe murder Lizzie Borden, got it?” Her smile was the very picture of chipper the entire time, leaving not even Pacifica’s family to suspect what was really being said. Then Mable turned the mic back and started cheering “USA! USA!” to the audience’s delight.

Finally regaining her composure, and not wanting to look weak in front of her family, Pacifica scoffed. She convinced herself that this weird girl was just blowing hot air, though her terms seemed reasonable enough. No need to bring outsiders into their feud. “I’m sorry to break it to you, but Pioneer Day is for serious people, and you look and act ridiculous,” she carefully mocked. She pointed to Mable’s sweater. “I mean, a puppy playing basketball? Are you always this silly?”

“Hey, I can be serious.”

“You do have nachos hanging from your ears, hun.”

Suddenly feeling self-conscious – an unusual sensation for the taller twin – Mable departed the stage, hand on her collar to keep her passenger from moving too much.

“Don’t tell me you’re actually listening to her,” Dipper chided once they were out of earshot. “You’re Mable. You run through self-important twerps like her like copy paper.” When Mable sighed despondently, Dipper considered a new approach. “Hey, let’s get you some old timey butterscotch.”

Grunkle Stan, meanwhile, had gotten into a bit of a mess. After losing his temper, he’d been thrown into the stocks. There he met up with Gideon, who’d finally felt well enough to walk around without a limp. The tiny troll hadn’t yet perfected his next diabolical scheme and was just out to unwind and enjoy the day like everyone else. And with Stan helpless before him, Gideon decided that the best way to do so was to pelt the man with tomatoes.

While that was happening, Mable was sitting at the base of the statue, petting the little boy in her lap while scarfing down candy. “Dipper, can I ask you something. Do you think I’m… silly?”

Dipper wasn’t sure what the right answer was, but decided to go with his gut. “I know that you’re caring, friendly, and can tough it out against people ten times your size.”

“That’s nice of you to say, but you’re my brother,” she sighed and slumped in her seat. “Ugh, I knew it. The nacho earrings. The sweater. I thought I was being charming, but I guess people see me as a big joke.” She then discarded the nachos, pulled off her sweater so that only her pink undershirt was left, and tied the purple fabric around her waist like a belt.

“Come on, Mable. You love that sweater.”

“I did before Pacifica ruined it for me. Grr, she ruins everything!”

“So kick her butt.”

“That wouldn’t change the fact that she’s right, though.”

Dipper shook his fists with brotherly rage. “Pacifica! Why does she think being related to the town founder means she gets to treat everyone else like garbage?” Looking up at the statue, Dipper’s memory was jogged and he pulled out the journal to flip through its pages. “Wait, I think I remember reading something about Nathaniel Northwest. Of course, this is perfect!” He held up the journal for Mable to read the tiny print with him. The author speculated that Nathaniel wasn’t the real founder of Gravity Falls and that the secret lay within a document taped to the page. However, the author had never been able to crack the code.

Dipper gawked after unfurling the paper and beheld its many strange glyphs. “Oh man! If this cover-up is true, then it means Pacifica’s whole family’s a fraud. This could be a major conspiracy.”

Mable’s eyes went wide. “Wait, conspiracies are super serious, right?”

“Oh yeah, definitely.”

“Then if I help you crack the code, then no one will ever call me silly again.”

Dipper smirked up at her. “Yeah, duh. Like there was a chance you wouldn’t want to get involved in something like this.”

“Very true. Plus you’d need someone to reach the high shelves, anyway.”

“Mystery twins?” Dipper extended his fist for a bump.

“I thought you hated that.”

“Eh. I’m starting to accept it.”

Mable bumped his tiny fist and the pair were off, utterly oblivious to the eyes upon them as they went.
11521111111111111111111111111111.title: Pioneer Day

115211111111111111111111111111111.content:
Dipper decided that the logical first step for their investigation was at the local library. All the records were old and almost nothing had been uploaded online, there was even an old timey projector, so they had to research the old fashioned way. Dipper was gung-ho with this plan, but Mable struggled almost from the start. This kind of book learning had never been her strong suit. While he cross-referenced the symbols on the parchment to other old texts, she was trying to figure out if reading upside-down would help her focus.

Then Dipper thought he’d made a discovery. “Hmm. Maybe if we use fire, it might light up some hidden message!”

“It’s so obvious. Also, I made a hat,” she bragged, pointing at the parchment now folded into a paper hat. Her sense of pride quickly fell after she’d realized what happened. “Ugh, I just did something silly again.”

“Hey, wait. Mable, you folded it into a map.”

“I did?” she took the hat off to examine it. Sure enough, there was a dotted line and an x and everything. “Wow, how lucky is that.”

“Not luck. It must be part of the code the author never figured out. Mable, if we-” But before Dipper could explore further, they were alerted to the ringing bell of the sheriff and deputy. Apparently they were looking for a couple of kids for ‘secret reasons,’ which they proudly boasted about.

Going into stealth mode, the kids snuck out of the library and made for the destination on the map, the Gravity Falls Museum of History. It was easy enough to get in. Pioneer Day was their busiest day of the year, and they even gave out complimentary balloons. As best as Dipper could interpret, the next clue lay within some abstract triangular painting.

“We’ve got to figure this out quick. I don’t think those cops were at the library to check out books.”

“I don’t think the one with the bell can read,” agreed Mable.

Not knowing what else to do, the twins just stared at the painting in search of some elusive pattern. Sure enough, Mable once more cracked the code by lying upside down on a bench, prompting Dipper to do the same.

“You figured it out again, Mable. You’re on a roll!”

“Hehe, thanks. I think I’ve seen that somewhere in the cemetary.”

“Hmm. Are you noticing a pattern here?”

“What do you mean?”

“Well, looking at things upside down isn’t that big a deal. I would’ve gotten here too eventually,” he explained defensively. “More importantly, you folded the paper into a hat. And you did so in precisely the way that everything lined up to send us here. What kind of mad genius are we dealing with?”

Mable sucked in a breath. “Does this mean I’m a mad genius, too?”

“If it does, then dad owes me $50,” Dipper muttered. “At the very least it means that whoever wrote this document, you guys might be on similar wavelengths or something.”

The two got right side up, but did so too quickly and suffered a momentary head rush. Mable, ever the clumsy one, landed with Dipper squished beneath her butt. “Hehe.” She then wiggled her rump around, feeling him squirm helplessly between her skirt-clad cheeks. “You alright, bro-bro?”

Before Dipper could deliver a scathing retort, the cops showed up. In a panic, Mable clenched her butt cheeks together to hold Dipper in place as she ducked out of sight. Eavesdropping, she confirmed that the two were definitely after a pair of kids. She waited until their backs were turned and made a break for it; brother now in hand because running like that would have just been ridiculous. Luckily, the cops got stuck in the doorway and she made her escape.

Meanwhile, Pacifica decided to skirt the rules just a tad when she saw Stan still locked up. She offered to free him in exchange for him admitting that the Northwest family was the best in town. It’d be like doing Mable a favor, but in such a way that would surely piss her off. It was the perfect crime. Unfortunately, when she offered him paper so that she’d have this confession in writing, Stan refused to cooperate and wrote something highly inappropriate. And with Mable not around, Pacifica felt safe with plausible deniability as she set the tomato armed populace on the guy.

Out in the cemetery, the twins stopped by the statue of an angel with her hand extended and pointing at something.

“Alright Mable. Have at it.” Dipper gestured up.

“Say what now?”

“You’ve figured out all the other clues so far, so let’s see if third time’s the charm. I think the statue is pointing at the next clue, but how would Mable solve this mystery?”

“Hmm. That’s a good question. How would Mable solve this mystery?” Mable nodded, attempting to look serious as she studied the finger. Her reputation was on the line and Dipper trusted her to figure things out on her own. She’d hate to disappoint him. Then she got a funny idea, scaled an adjacent statue, and stuck the finger up her nose. “Ahh! She’s picking my nose. Haha.”

There came a crack as the finger bent and the headstone beneath opened up to reveal a secret passage.

Staring down into the deep dark cavern, Dipper blinked. “That was somehow not at all what I expected, but also exactly what I expected. Good job, Mable.”

“Ha! Who’s silly now, Pacifica?” she challenged as she carefully extricated her nose.

“That would be you,” Dipper stated flatly as he awaited to be picked up and set on her shoulder.

“What? You’re on her side now?” she asked, depositing him where he belonged.

“No, Mable. Don’t you see? Paper hat, upside down, picking your nose,” he listed. “Those were all silly things that were exactly what we needed. Your silliness is solving this mystery.”

“Whoa! In that case, double take that, Pacifica!”

“Just watch your step. A place like this is bound to have booby traps.”

Mable snickered. “Hehe. You said booby.” She then glanced down at her chest. “Speaking of, do you think Pacifica’s are bigger than mine?”

“Mable, history changing conspiracy hunting isn’t the time for that sort of thing.”

“Exactly. It’s silly, and I thought silly was solving the mystery.”

Dipper threw back his head and groaned as his words were turned against him. “Mable, some girls get lucky and develop early. Most of them get addicted to the attention and become haggard prostitutes by age 20. Your body will develop at its own pace, and you can laugh at Pacifica when you’re still cute and she’s half plastic.”

“Aww. That’s so sweet of-” Mable stepped on a switch that made a loud click and sunk into the floor. “Uh oh!”

One daring escape from some poison darts in the wall later, and the pair found themselves in a dusty old hall that might have been someone’s study. There were shelves lined with books, all kinds of old documents, and even an old projector like they’d seen back in the library. Mable gravitated towards a folder labeled ‘Classified: Do Not Read’ in big red letters, and quickly got to reading, learning all sorts of secrets about America’s (apparently) freaky leadership.

“Hey, Ben Franklin secretly was a woman!”

“Then that would also make him a lesbian,” Dipper added. “Dude was a notorious whore monger, ya know. I always liked to think he – or I guess she – reincarnated as Winston Churchill.”

Eventually they found what they came here for. Nathaniel Northwest wasn’t some great pioneer turned town founder, but a waste shoveling village idiot. Whoever wrote that line must have been pretty vindictive. Regardless, the true founder was Sir Lord. Quentin Trembley, III, Esq. But before the twins could investigate further, the coppers finally showed up, the tall one half covered in darts.
115211111111111111111111111111111.title: Mystery Twins

1152111111111111111111111111111111.content:
With nowhere to run, it didn’t take much to convince the cops to spill everything they knew, especially after revealing that they’d only found this place by following the trail of candy Mable left behind. Blubs even had a film reel in his hat that conveniently explained everything, despite this apparently being a matter of national security. Quentin Trembley was the 8th and a half president. Despite winning the 1837 election in a landslide, he quickly gained a reputation as America’s silliest president for declaring war on pancakes, appointing 6 babies to the Supreme Court, and banning pants, among his more mild activities. He was booted out of office and disappeared into the valley that would one day be known as Gravity Falls. All records of him were erased with Harrison replacing him as president and Northwest as the town founder. Trembley’s body was never found…

“Until today,” Blubs finished, pointing to a large orange block containing the man from the film.

“Hey, that’s pretty - *Thwonk* - hey!” Mable cried. Her wrists and ankles had been handcuffed while she wasn’t looking.

“The fool thought he could live forever by encasing himself in peanut brittle,” Blubs explained mockingly.

“Yeah, that’s great and all, but why did you cuff me?” Mable demanded.

“One, because finding Trembley has been our special mission. Two, you two are under arrest for learning the secret. And three, because everyone has seen that video of you with Manly Dan, and that’s just not something we feel like dealing with.”

“So I cuffed ya while you was distracted by the film,” bragged deputy Durland. “We-hehe!”

As upset as Mable was, she had to shrug her acceptance at that last one. “Okay, fair enough. So what are you gonna do with us?”

“Nothing bad. Just gonna escort you and all this stuff back to Washington. You ain’t comin’ back by the way,” Blubs informed frankly. “Say, where’d the little guy g-Ow!” Blubs looked behind to find a dart sticking out of his behind. “Now how did-?”

“Youch!”

“Durland!?”

“He got me in the nose.”

“Well find him. He can’t have run far.”

“Who says I’m running?” Dipper intoned threateningly. On a table near the wall, he’d found himself a mini catapult. Beside it was a pile of darts that had fallen off of Durland. “Let us go, or the next one’s going right for the eye.”

“Yeah, Dipper! Show no mercy!”

“Gladly,” Blubs answered. The short fat guy grabbed a book and threw it towards Dipper, smashing the catapult. But just as the minizora jumped down in preparation for his next move, he’d landed right in Durland’s hand.

“You let my brother go right now, or I swear I’ll go Black Knight and bite your legs off!” snarled Mable. Alas, her captors were not appreciative of the joke. It took several chains and a long stick with a hook before the cops felt safe enough to transport the little girl and her brother onto the train for their journey.

Dipper and Mable were stowed away in a large wooden crate, along with the entrapped former president. Fortunately, Dipper had some old tools in his vest pocket and was able to unlock Mable. Unfortunately, the box was sealed tight and the only hole in the wood was too small even for him.

“I can’t believe I left a trail of candy wrappers,” Mable bemoaned, back to the wall as she slid down to the floor. “This is all my fault. Pacifica had me pegged all along. I’m just a failure like that-”

“Enough!” Dipper shouted, stomping his foot down. “I’m sick of you talking about yourself like this. Why do you let her get to you?”

“I-I don’t know. She just has this… way of getting under my skin.”

“Well stop it. You’re Mable Pines, remember. Your silliness got us into this mess, maybe it can get us out.”

“How would that work?” Mable demanded, staring down at her tiny brother as she absentmindedly ripped a chunk off of the presidential block, trying to drown her misery in sweets. In so doing, she set off a chain reaction that set the whole thing to crumble. With the block now in shambles, the perfectly preserved man inside finally spoke.

“‘Tis I, Quintin Trembley!” And then he ripped off his pants in an impressive show of strength, leaving only his pantaloons.

“Ha! Told you,” Dipper declared his vindication, once more reciting all the silly things Mable had done to get them this far. “You’re not silly. You’re brilliant! Just like this guy with no pants.”

“I’m as smart as a pantsless president!”

From there, the two brilliantly silly people contrived an exquisitely silly plan of fitting through the tiny hole. It didn’t work, but somehow it did cause the crate to collapse around them, which was also good. Afterwards, following a brief chase on the top of the train, Dipper managed to convince the cops that Quentin Trembley was still technically the president, who then ordered them to forget that any of this ever happened. Dipper then amended that the cops should actually report that the kids were a false alarm and Blubs was the one who really solved the case. Unfortunately, Trembley had been reduced to dust and there wasn’t anything to send back. Most of the papers, however, would have to continue on their journey, though Dipper did snag a few of the juicier secrets for himself on the way out.

The three returned to Gravity Falls, chatting the whole way as Trembley revealed a few more embarrassing secrets about the other presidents. But as a reward for their services, Mable was appointed as a congressman, complete with a fancy top hat. Dipper was offered some supportive words for his efforts in uncovering the deeper secrets of the town, along with a limited edition negative 12 dollar bill and the Presidential Key.

Upon seeing Pacifica, Mable gave the girl a low-key heart attack when she ran over. Luckily, it was just so that she could brag about her amazingly implausible adventures and not because she was going to take revenge for her Grunkle. Alas, Pacifica wasn’t buying it and promptly dismissed Mable, sparing a brief glance towards Dipper as she huffed away.

Dipper was not amused. “Aren’t you going to tell her about her great-great grandpa?”

“You know what, Dipper. I’ve got nothing to prove. With your help, I’ve learned that being silly is awesome.” And she slipped her sweater back onto its rightful place.

“Well I haven’t learned anything,” Dipper huffed. Pulling out his smartphone, he quickly logged into his favorite conspiracy website and uploaded photos he’d taken regarding the Northwests. It took the internet practically no time to go viral with the story. “Hey Pacifica!” He whistled for her car to stop. “Check SecretConspiracies.com. Nathaniel didn’t found Gravity Falls and your whole family’s a sham. Deal with it!”

It took only a second for the blonde girl to check her own phone and cry out in alarm. “What!? Mom, dad!”

Dipper, meanwhile, was in awe of what he’d just done. “Man, revenge is underrated. That felt awesome!”

“Thanks for looking out for me, bro-bro.” Mable picked up the minizora and planted a big wet kiss on his cheek. “I can always trust you to have my back.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111.title: Irrational Treasure

11521111111111111111111111111111111.content:
With the dance being such a financial success, Grunkle Stan decided to take things to the next level. It was, in his proud words, the cheapest fair money could rent. While he oversaw most of the work, including the rigging of certain attractions, he tasked the twins with slapping fake safety certificates on anything that looked too dangerous.

12 o’ clock rolled around and Stan was living it up in the dunk tank. He was shouting at everyone who got near, pointing out their various physical flaws and making himself nice and hateable. Everyone bought balls to try and dunk the jerk, but the target was rigged to be effectively immovable, barring some supernatural phenomenon. Still, Stan was making a considerable profit from hurling insults and people, at couldn’t be happier for it.

Dipper, meanwhile, had graduated to hand holding with Wendy… sort of. They were now comfortable enough for her to carry him around in her hand. It was nice.

“And then he threw the book at me.”

Wendy snickered, holding her question mark shaped treat in the other hand. “What, like locked you up?”

“No. First he threw an actual book at me. I was too dangerous with that catapult,” Dipper boasted. “That’s when they caught me, and then I was locked up.”

Wendy shook her head and wiped away a couple tears. “You’re a riot, little man. You know, you should write all this down. It’d make a great story.”

“You think so?”

“Yeah, totally. Going on all these adventures with all the supernatural stuff in town. I know I’d get a kick out of it. Just one thing, though.” Wendy’s smile shrunk a tad. “For real, though. Did all this stuff really happen, or are you just weavin’ a yarn?” she asked in imitation of her mother’s accent.

Dipper shrugged nonchalantly. “Eh, who can say? Multibears and presidents encased in peanut brittle? That stuff’s about as silly as ghosts in a convenience store, and who’d ever believe that?”

Wendy’s eyes widened and she laughed nervously. “Heh-heh, sure.” Suddenly feeling awkward, she was actually relieved when her snack dripped on her shirt sleeve. “Ah, boo. I’ll be right back.” She set him down and went to get cleaned up. Once she found the wipes, she took a bit too long as she thought things over. “He can’t be serious, can he?” she muttered to herself. “I mean, dad always had those stories, but they’re just stories, right? They can’t be real. Then again, I did see ghosts with my own two eyes, so if they’re real, then…” She slapped herself. “No, stop it, Wendy! You can’t think about it like that. He’s just a nice guy telling stories to make you laugh.” She blinked upon recalling an awful truth. “… exactly how dad started with mom.”

Wendy’s mom never got tired of telling the story of how she met up with her husband. He was as much a muscle head back in high school as today and she’d initially dismissed him as beneath her. She’d only gone out with him on a dare, but then he saved her after an unfortunate encounter with a mugger; unfortunate for the mugger, who was hospitalized for six months after having a whole car engine surgically removed. She gave him a real chance after that and started listening to what he had to say. The more she listened, the more she wanted to hear. And when he proved just as good a listener, it was inevitable that things got physical.

Wendy usually tuned her mother out around that point, or at least tried to, but none of that was relevant now. “Me and Dipper are just friends who liked to talk. I talk with all my friends. It’s no big deal,” she rationalized. “Except, is he being serious when he talks about all these adventures? Did he really face down monsters, showing off the same machismo that dad-” *Fwack* “Nope!” She slapped herself again. “Don’t go there, brain.”

Over at the concession stand, Mable had moseyed up to her little brother with two hands full of cotton candy. “Look at you two, being all romantic at the fair.”

“I know. Isn’t’ this amazing. I just dove in. I said ‘Hey, want to hang out at the fair?’ and she was like, ‘Sure.’ It totally worked. All your advice about just going for it. It’s finally paying off.”

Mable shook her head with a self-satisfied smirk. “When are you going to learn, Dipper? I’m always right about everything.” Then she frowned. “Hey, do you smell a gallon of body spray?”

Robbie showed up, looking as forcefully indifferent as ever. “Hey, you dorks seen Wendy? I got some super tight jeans and thought she’d wanna check ‘em out.” He planted his foot on a box and started flexing to the disgust of the preteens.

“Hey, yeah. I think I saw her in the Bottomless Pit. You should really go jump in there,” Dipper offered helpfully.

“Maybe I will, smart guy,” Robbie sneered. The teen looked like he was about to step on the minizora, but one look at Mable’s death glower made him realize that he liked living too much and he turned away.

“That guys a jerk.”

“Yeah, but he’s a jerk with tight pants and a guitar. I need to keep him away from Wendy at all costs,” Dipper reasoned.

Mable nodded. “Yeah. All you’ve got are smarts, cutes, body odor that can’t be smelled a mile away, and a loincloth. You don’t stand a chance,” she teased.

“Mable!”

“Take it easy there, bro-bro. Whatever happens, I’ll be right here. Supporting you every step of the-Oh my gosh a pig!” And just like that, the little girl ran off to the booth that was giving out pigs, leaving her littler brother alone.

Dipper was fine, though. He hooked back up with Wendy shortly after as she carried him past one of the prize booths.

“Whoa, check it out. I don’t know if it’s a duck or a pig, but I want one.”

“Then I’ll win it for you.”

“That’s really sweet, dude, but these things aren’t exactly minizora friendly.” Wendy gestured to the balls that were bigger than him.”

“Don’t worry. My uncle taught me the secret to these things. You aim for the carny’s head and then take the prize when he’s unconscious.”

“Hehe. Nice. Alright then.” She set him on the counter. “Give it a shot.” She didn’t think he could actually do it, but it seemed too mean to deny him the chance.

What Wendy didn’t know was that there was this trick for minizora that Dipper had found online and been practicing ever since he heard about the fair. By stretching his muscles in just the right way, he could create a bungie effect that could easily meet carny standards. He just had to get his aim down. However, what Dipper didn’t know was that this was a fixed point in the timeline. Specifically, this was the point that causality decided to dick around with him and Wendy. So when he threw the ball, it ricocheted back and smacked her right in the face.

“Agh! My eye!” It had swollen to an awful shade of purple.

Mortified beyond rational thought, Dipper ran off to fetch some ice. On the way back, some bald fat guy in a gray jumpsuit tripped over the ice and about crushed the minizora beneath his big fat butt. By the time the jerk regained enough sense to flee the scene; it was already too late as Dipper beheld the horror.

“Robbie, thanks. That’s really sweet. The gesture and the flavored syrup,” Wendy said as he pressed the frozen treat against her eye. But when he popped the question and asked her to go out, she answered far quicker than she’d ever done before. She’d had a number of boyfriends and liked Robbie fine, but deep down this seemed like the perfect out. If she had an actual boyfriend, then maybe her mind would stop drifting to those fantasies about tiny people.

Mable came up to Dipper, overflowing with joy at the chance to show off her new pet Waddles. When Dipper gave no response, it didn’t take a rocket scientist to figure out what had gone wrong. “Oh,” she said while watching the teens run off together.
11521111111111111111111111111111111.title: At the Fair

115211111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The rest of the fair day was spent with mournful sighs as Dipper hardly even moved. Mable tried everything from tickling, to funny sounds, and even dressing Waddles up in cute costumes that she already owned for some reason.

“Mable, do you ever wish you could go back and undo just one mistake?”

“Come on, bro. We could solve this in ten seconds flat if you just let me break the guy’s legs,” Mable stated frankly as she played with Waddles. Alas, she was being ignored.
