“I mean Wendy only went out with Robbie because he had the ice,” rambled the minizora, “and she only needed ice because of the baseball, and I would have had the ice if it weren’t for… That guy!” Dipper pointed at the fat guy in the gray jumpsuit. “Hey you, tool belt. You ruined my life!” accused Dipper as he marched up to the oblivious man with Mable close behind. “Hey, I’ve seen you before. Have you been following us around?”

Wanting to get in on this, Mable added, “And why are you bald? What’s that all about?”

Stuttering something about a compromised position, the bald man fiddled with his watch and made his suit run through all kinds of bizarre colors and backgrounds. “Come on, stealth mode. Aw, dang it!” And he brought out a screwdriver to perform some adjustments.

“Wow, that’s amazing,” awed Mable. “Are you from the future or something?”

The fat guy was starting to sweat. “Wh-what? No. Who told you that? Uh, memory wipe!” He threw a blue cloth at Mable’s face.

“Did you just throw a baby wipe at me?” Mable asked, more surprised by the absurdity than angered.

The man finally caved and spilled all his secrets. His name was Blendin Blandin, a time traveler from the year twenty shneventy twelve. His mission was to stop a number of time anomalies that were centered around this time and place, but he’d yet to find any. When the twins professed skepticism, he demonstrated how to use his time traveling measuring tape by disappearing and reappearing in a completely new set of clothes. Ultimately, the poor guy seemed awful tired, so Dipper suggested that he take a break and enjoy some rides at the fair. Mable even gave him her remaining tickets. The twins shared a knowing look as Blendin stripped off his belt and got onto a ride.

“Grunkle Stan would be proud of us,” Mable snickered as she pilfered the tape.

Back in the Shack’s dining room, the pair awed at the item that sat on the table before them.

“This is it, Mable, our ticket to any moment in history.”

“Let’s go get two dodos and force them to make out.”

“What? No.”

“Then let’s go get some cute and tiny dinosaurs just before they die, force them to make out, and then we can have an army of adorable ancient lizards!”

“Nnn-maybe,” Dipper allowed. “Let’s just do something small for starters. Like, for example, going back and fixing my baseball throw.”

“Great idea! Oh, and I can come too. That way I can relive the greatest moment of my life. Winning Waddles.” She kissed the pig on the head and shot Dipper a coy look. “Jealous?”

The minizora rolled his eyes. “Let’s just get this over with.”

The time was rolled back by six hours. Perfect. Mable re-won Waddles in no time flat and, just for kicks, admitted to the carny that she was a witch before he could even ask. Dipper, however, wasn’t so lucky. The ball hit Wendy in the eye all over again and Robbie appeared to comfort her. Although he wondered if time might conspire to undo new outcomes, Dipper reasoned that all he really needed was to try again. So he did, and hit her in the eye. He tried again and again, changing every variable he could think of. Half the time he hit the milk bottles, a few times he hit the carny, but the end result was always the same with Wendy taking a baseball to the face; except for that one time where time decided to be extra dickish and pelt her with a whole basket full of balls. One time the ball knocked him into Wendy’s cleavage, which was almost the best possible outcome, if it didn’t somehow hit her eye a split second later.

As Dipper ran through the math, he realized that what he was missing was help. If he could just enlist Mable to be in the right place at the right time, then he’d be golden. In a good mood after more than a dozen wins with Waddles, she was fully onboard, confident that another win was in the stars for her. It worked! Dipper finally won the stuffed creature of indeterminate species without injuring Wendy. Granted, also ending up in her cleavage would have been a nice bonus, but this was still acceptable, especially now that Robbie lost his chance to ask Wendy out.

Dipper went on a few rides with Wendy, just enjoying himself as he sat in her hand, when Mable came up screaming. “Hey, what’s-?”

“Ahh!”

“Uh-”

“Ahh!”

“Are you-?”

“Ahhhhh!”

Dipper and Wendy waited until Mable finally calmed before trying again. “What’s wrong?”

“We messed up the timeline. Pacifica saw the flyer and won Waddles before I could. She took Waddles, Dipper!”

“Timeline?” questioned Wendy.

“Oh that’s, uh nothing.” Dipper motioned for Wendy to set him on Mable’s shoulder. “Hey, I’m real sorry about that.”

“It’s okay.” Mable then took the time tape out of Dipper’s vest pocket. “We just have to go back in time and do things-”

“Mable, no!” Dipper took the tape back.

“Uh, does someone want to catch me up here, cuz I think I missed a step,” admitted Wendy. “Timeline? Going back? And who’s Waddles?”

“He’s my new pet pig,” Mable cried, too distressed to think as Dipper urged her to hush. “Or at least he was supposed to be. We keep redoing the day and I’ve won him, like, twenty times. But now he’s gone and I gotta get him back.”

Wendy blinked and then fixed her gaze on the measuring tape. “Okay. Maybe there was something in the food I ate, cuz it sounds like you guys are talking about time travel.”

Dipper laughed nervously. “Wh-what? That-that’s silly. Don’t be silly, Wendy. Heh-heh.”

“Okay, my bullshit meter is going off like crazy. You two better start talking sense or… or else I’ll find Pacifica and take this pig for myself,” she threatened, shaking a fist for emphasis.

Mable blinked. “Uh, yeah. I’d be fine with that. So long as you bring him right back to me.”

“Mable, why didn’t you just beat up Pacifica and take Waddles yourself?” Dipper demanded.

“She had guards. Guards with tasers. You know I hate tasers. But with Wendy’s help…”

“What? Oh no, man. I’m not getting tased again. Not after last time. Ugh. Can you please just tell me what’s going on here?”

“Uh, can you give us a moment, please?” Dipper requested.

“Fine. One minute. But if I don’t get a straight answer, I’m chucking you both at the carny,” Wendy growled and stomped off.

“Why didn’t you just tell her we’ve got a time machine?” Mable asked.

“Yeah? And tell her what? That I went back in time a bunch just to stop her from dating Robbie? Mable, listen to me. I’ve done the math. In any other timeline, Wendy ends up going out with Robbie. I can’t mess this up.”

“But if we don’t go, then I’ll lose Waddles forever!”
115211111111111111111111111111111111.title: Retry

1152111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
As expected of two siblings when tensions were running high, they started to quarrel. Dipper could be an evasive little scamp when he really put his mind to it. And in the scuffle, the tape was pulled out too far, sending the twins hurling through time. When everything stopped tasting purple, it appeared that they were on some dirt road in an unfamiliar wilderness.

“When are we?” Dipper asked, brushing himself off.

Mabel beamed at the chance to smart off. “The real question is ‘when’ are w-oh. Oh you already said it.”

“Yeah, same thing. Hey, do you hear that?”

“I feel that.” The twins turned to see an incoming stampede of buffalo. Screaming, Mabel grabbed Dipper and started running as fast as she could. She wasn’t watching where she was going and ended up off a cliff, and luckily right into a covered wagon full of settlers dressed like they were ready for Pioneer Day. In this case, a pregnant looking woman with a half dozen kids of varying ages.

“You sent us back 150 years, genius!” Dipper snapped, calming as he pinched the bridge of his nose.

Then one of the dirty children in the wagon approached and pointed. “Hey look, ma. She’s got one of them there tiny wingless fairies like what they got up in the cities.”

“Oh goodness!” said the woman, cheeks flushed. “I’ve heard about the… skills of you tiny folk. Might I interest you in staying a while?”

Dipper blushed, too paralyzed to speak. While the other boys in the wagon looked curious, all of the ladies looked curious. Mabel’s grip on her brother grew possessively tight.

“Hey look, ma,” said that same kid. “That girl’s got silver in her mouth.”

“These are called braces.”

“Mabel, no! You can’t go messing with the past.”

Then Mabel remembered her wrath. “Oh, says the guy who’s spent all day messing with the past and cost me my pig? I’ll mess with whatever I want.” She pulled out a calculator and handed it to the dirty kid. “Check it out. A magic button machine. Shoes that blink.” She stomped on the floor, making them light up to the awe of the settlers. And after promising the women they could vote in the future, she even taught them to high five.

Dipper tried to steal the tape back, but mistyped a button and sent them too far back. Before they could get eaten by a dinosaur, Mabel pressed buttons wildly until they were sent (presumably) too far forward. The setting could only be described as post-apocalyptic with cities in ruins, twin moons, an eerie green hue over everything, laser blasts everywhere, and a giant floating baby with an hourglass on his head shooting eye beams and laughing at those who stood in his way. Dipper managed to get them back to the right century at least, but Mabel was on the run. Their connection to the time tape meant that they were always the same relative distance apart, no matter where or when they ended up. They ran past the day at the lake with the Gobblewonker, past the wax museum reopening, past the gnome incident, and several more events they didn’t recognize before ending up back at the Shack in a winter before the sign had gone up. The tape overheated and the pair disappeared in a flash of light, mere seconds before a man with a familiar face poked his head out the door to check on the noise.

When everything stopped spinning, the two stumbled their way out of a portapotty, gasping for fresh air. They were back in the ‘present’, specifically the one where Wendy got the prize and Pacifica got the pig. Dipper then immediately scaled up the potty out of his sister’s reach.

“Mabel, give it up. It’s over. I’ve worked too hard for this.”

“But what about Waddles?” she cried actual tears.

“What about me and Wendy? I thought you said you supported us.”

“I… I don’t know.” Head hung low and heart in tatters, Mabel went over to the totem and started thumping her head to it, mumbling Waddles every now and then.

“You’re not guilt tripping me, Mabel,” Dipper intoned, though truthfully it tore him up to see her like this. “Come on, Mabel. You’re gonna forget about this in a day. In fact, I’ll prove it.” He pulled out the tape and traveled a day forward, finding most of the fair taken down but Mabel in the exact same spot. “Okay, maybe in a week.” He tried again to identical results. This was distressingly familiar. So he tried a month, finding her looking filthy with roots climbing up her legs. But then he saw something else. “Hey, Wendy.” He ran towards her, hoping to salvage this otherwise horrible outcome.

The red head was heading for the Shack, likely to begin her shift, only for her mood to instantly sour when she saw who’d called her. “Oh, it’s you.”

The disgust in her tone killed Dipper’s momentum instantly. “Uh, hey Wendy. H-how’s it going?”

“You’re a real piece of work, you know that.”

“Huh?”

“Don’t you huh, me. You flake on me all summer and now you expect to talk like we’re friends again?”

“Again? You mean we’re… not, anymore?”

Wendy shook her head with a sneer. “Dude, just look at your sister. You honestly think I’d ever want to hang out with someone who’s that crappy to their own family?” She turned away in a huff. “I thought you were supposed to be better than that, but I guess I was wrong.”

“I…” Dipper tried to speak, tried to deny it, but she was already out of earshot. Sniffling and rubbing his eyes dry, he knew that there was only one choice to make. Pulling out the tape one last time, he returned to that fateful moment.

“Wendy, I just wanted to say that people make mistakes. And when they do, you should forgive them. Also that tight pants are overrated.”

“Dude, you lost me.”

“I know,” Dipper conceded. Once more he went through the motions, barely even paying attention as he trusted the ball to find its mark. It did, and Robbie showed up to do his part as well. “It is done.” The minizora was then swiped off the table and pulled into a bone breaking embrace.

“Dipper! Thank-you-thank-you-thank-you!” Mabel cheered as she swung him around, dancing in joy. When Waddles made pig noises, she added, “He’s saying ‘thank you’ in pig.”

“I couldn’t break your heart, Mabel,” Dipper assured, patting her cheek. “Plus it’s not like Robbie can date Wendy all summer, right?”

Then Blendin returned to swipe the tape back. “You two!” he accused. “Do you have any idea how many laws you just broke? I-I’m asking. I wasn’t there with you, but it was probably a lot,” he finished uncertainly.

That’s when a couple of jacked up dudes in future armor appeared. They listed off the repercussions of the twins’ actions and set the blame squarely on Blendin, given that his machine had been used to travel to all affected time periods. They were deaf to Blendin’s rambling stuttering excuses, trying to pin the blame on Waddles of all people as he was dragged off to be arrested. Why they didn’t just flash away was anyone’s guess. They did, however, stick around long enough to be offended by Grunkle Stan, leading to the old man finally getting dunked after the target was incinerated. Everyone cheered.

The twins got an ice cream to split with Dipper riding on Mabel’s wrist and Waddles being carried beneath her other arm. After realizing that they might have caused the anomalies that Blendin had originally been sent to stop, Dipper’s mood was once more soured by the sight of Robbie sharing a caramel apple with Wendy. It didn’t take Mabel long to realize that this was a prime chance to be a good big sister and sick Waddles on the smelly emo. Waddles only got the apple, but purely by coincidence and not at all planned, Robbie backed up into a pot of hot water that spilled onto his tight pants, making them extra tight and constricting his sensitive bits. Once more, everyone laughed. Wendy even tried to cover her snickering at her new boyfriend’s expense.

Feeling just a bit better, Dipper went over to Waddles while he nibbled on the apple and scratched him behind the ears. “That’ll do, pig. That’ll do.”

Waddles squealed happily and leaned appreciatively into the scratching.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Time Traveler's Pig

11521111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
After all the money he’d just made, Stan was in a good mood and so was easily swayed into keeping Waddles. The porker was already house trained, but still had to stay in the laundry room at night. And while Mabel had every intention of sneaking him up to her room now and then, tonight would not be one of those nights.

“So, bro-bro. Like what you see?” Having deposited Dipper onto her bed, Mabel had stripped down to just her undies with her legs spread wide, leaving nothing to the imagination.

Still fully dressed, Dipper swallowed.

“You did a really great thing today, so I figured you earned some big sis lovin’, which is where I come in,” Mabel explained giddily. “Tonight, it’s anything you want.”

“Anything?”

“Anything. Come on. What’s your biggest fantasy? I’ll make it happen.”

Dipper smirked, accepting the challenge. “You and Wendy making out and using me as a double dildo.”

Mabel blinked. “Okay, what’s your second biggest fantasy… that I can actually make happen?”

Dipper laughed. “Sorry, not trying to be difficult or anything, but that’s kind of it.”

“Really?” Mabel asked in disappointment. “Nothing else?”

“Yeah. I mean, we kind of do everything else already. What, is there something more you’ve always wanted to try?”

“Of course. I always had this fantasy about you hooking up with a cute minizora girl and totally going at it while inside me.” Leaning back, she pushed her underwear aside and parted her pussy lips to reveal the glistening pink insides. “Mmph! Just thinking about it gets me hot.”

“Okay, yeah.” Dipper took off his shirt and shimmied out of his boxers. “That’s pretty hot, though I’m not sure which of our fantasies is less plausible.”

“Don’t ruin the moment with your stupid overthinking,” groaned Mabel. “Just pick something and get started already. I’m dyin’ over here,” she whined while swirling her fingers over her clit.

“Hey, now there’s an idea.” Dipper finally approached and gently pushed Mabel’s fingers aside. Staring into her glistening snatch, Dipper smirked confidently as he made his decision. “We’re doing the no-hands thing again.”

“Aww, really?” Mabel whined. She didn’t hate giving the reigns to Dipper, but it had been so frustrating not being able to do anything herself last time.

“Yeah, but with one difference. You can’t touch me or anything near me, but everything not near me is free game.”

“Oh-hoho,” Mabel chuckled. “Me likey so far. What’re you gonna do?”

Dipper said nothing as he pushed the panties aside like a tarp and stepped into the frilly confines. Mabel pulled back the band to watch from above while he got to work. The minizora started by touching along the girl’s slit. She shuddered and almost lost her grip on the band. Hands that small had no business being that powerful, but the evidence spoke for itself. His touch was gentle and exploratory at first, easing her into things so as to not overwhelm her. He was a considerate lover like that.

Biting her lower lip, Mabel used her free hand to start rubbing at her right breast. She kneaded the flesh while trying to mirror Dipper’s actions. She tried imagining that her hand was his, that it was him at regular size doing the groping. When that didn’t seem to work as well as hoped, she imagined his hands as tiny as they’d always been and that really got her blood pumping. “Eeep!”

Dipper had just touched Mabel’s clit, sending volts of electricity through her body. Smirking sadistically, Dipper tried for more prolonged contact with a brief kiss.

“Eep!” Mabel’s back arched and she lost her grip on her panties. Her climax had jumped out at her like a snake and her mouth opened in a silent scream. One hand had dug into her developing boob and the other fumbled for anything it could reach, digging its fingers into her twat and its devious teaser. Mabel’s vision slowly started to clear as her breathing evened. “I need to start getting ice water before bed,” she panted. Her attention was then called to some muffled shouts between her legs. Looking down, she could feel her brother moving about, along with some moisture on her fingers and released her grip.

Dipper poked his head out from her panties, smirking despite being covered in her juices. “You seriously came from just a kiss?” he asked of his flushed sister. “I barely even got to do anything.”

“Hey, I ain’t stopping you. I’m a girl, which means I can orgasm all I want,” she boasted.

“Oh yeah? Well I’ve got minizora endurance, so I can pretty much do the same.”

“Challenge accepted!”

Brimming with confidence, Dipper dove back into the musky fabric and got back to work, this time less concerned with tenderness. With his own hand he teased the area around Mabel’s sex. It was already soaked, but he cared not for the smelly stickiness. All that mattered were the sexy sounds his sister made as he played her like a piano. “God, you sound hot,” he thought aloud as he pressed himself against the slit.

Mabel bit her bottom lip again, but extra hard this time. Somehow, she was able to feel the distinct protrusion of her brother’s prick as it probed her flower. It was so small, but somehow her brain was lit a fire with the knowledge of what it was, where it was, and how it felt like a burning hot coal against her sensitive nether lips. “Oh!” She reflexively slapped her hand over her mouth to subdue her screams; a skill she’d honed to near perfection over the years of keeping these trysts from their parents.

“Yeah, you like that, don’t you?” Whole body pressed against the gooey line, Dipper began pumping his little dipper in and out. He knew Mabel appreciated it, but what really drove her crazy was what he did with the rest of himself. His hands never stopped moving, massaging the area around her lips in the way that made his sister go crazy. Bracing himself, he kissed her clit again. Her body shook and she came again, though not as hard as before. Ignoring the way her viscous fluids oozed around him, Dipper kissed her again, but this time more passionately. He imagined himself making out with another girl his size, just like Mabel’s fantasy. She was hot, soft, and very welcoming.

Cursing her fate for not having more hands, Mabel made do with groping her breasts and suckling her own fingers. Again she imagined them to be Dipper; not his penis at regular sized, but his whole tiny body. Nothing got her hotter than imagining all the wonderful things she could do with his tiny form, except for maybe the things his tiny form could do with her.

Dipper had to press his hands around her lips to simulate the kind of tightness he needed to get off. He could just dive right in and get off that way, but that wasn’t the point. He was trying to make love with Mabel’s kitty like it was its own person. Losing himself in the rich aromas and scorching heat, it seemed to be working. Finally Dipper felt himself on the brink. “Coming!” he called, and released into his sister.

Mabel felt it, that injection of new fluids that weren’t her own, and climaxed as well. “H-how,” she panted breathlessly, body a burning sticky mess and smile so wide that it hurt. “H-how can you-you do that to me, ev-every time?”

Climbing out from her underwear, body glistening with her love juices, Dipper began to stretch. “Hey, some people just got it.”

Even in her orgasmic hi, Mabel was lucid enough to take offense at Dipper’s movements. Here she was, barely able to lift a finger. And there he was, looking like he was warming up for a marathon. “C-curse your minizora endurance.”

Dipper snickered. “Yeah, well, it turns out I might have overestimated myself just a bit.” He gestured down to his limp noodle. “Gonna need a few minutes before I’m ready to go again. Hey, can I get you some water?”

Swallowing her envy, Mabel nodded and Dipper went to the sink to fetch her a cup, which he brought back on a skateboard. It wasn’t the coldest or the tastiest, but the liquid flowing down her throat was refreshing beyond words.

“Thanks, bro-bro.”

“Any time, sis,” he said with a salute.
11521111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Gratitude

115211111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
With today being notoriously slow in years past, Grunkle Stan agreed to close up shop early, as well as to be dragged off to the arcade. The old man found no amusement in the games and resented them for taking other people’s money. That was his job. He also didn’t care for how many games had different variations of some one-eyed triangle guy that seemed to follow his movements wherever he went. Creepy. The kids, however, were having much more fun.

Dipper and Wendy had found this really old game in the back called Fight Fighters. It was a standard fighting game where each player picked a character and commenced an honorable fight to the death. Just standard kid stuff.

“Hey, stop doing that,” Wendy griped.

“What, winning?”

“Yeah. How are you doing that?” To her, it appeared that Dipper was running around like a one-man bee hive, dividing his time perfectly between the levers and the buttons. Then he won and they got to enjoy another cheesy cut-scene. “Whaaat? You cheated.”

“You take that baaack!” Dipper deepened his voice in imitation of the game characters.

But while they were having fun, who should turn up but Robbie. After once again reminding them about his band, the greasy teen was able to weasel his way into the game and push Dipper aside, doing so in such a way that didn’t look forceful enough to offend Wendy. It was infuriating. Once Wendy set him down, Dipper was forced to stand off to the side while she told Robbie about her family camping trip tomorrow, but he didn’t appear to listen. And when Robbie put his arm around Wendy, that’s when the game said something relevant.

“Opponent sighted. Fight!”

The next day, back at the Shack, Stan was trying to teach the kids how to play cards. Mabel, inexplicably, kept winning and taking everyone’s spare change. The game was interrupted by really desperate rock music accompanied by even more desperate lyrics.

Dipper groaned. “Ugh, sounds like Robbie.”

“Robbie? Is he that jerky twerp I see making googoo eyes at Wendy all the time?” asked Stan, succinctly summarizing everything about the gross emo in his old man lingo.

“Should I sick Waddles on him again?” Mabel asked, petting the pig’s head. “I’ve been working on this new suit of battle armor for him. I don’t want to spoil it, but there’ll be spikes. Extra sharp spikes.”

“I’ll handle it.” Dipper hopped down to the floor as the others oohed him on. He marched out the front door to where Robbie was playing terribly and calling Wendy out like she was a dog or something. “You realize she’s not here, right?”

“Pssh. Yes… what?”

“She’s out camping with her family today.” He then added under his breath, “Maybe if you’d listened for once, you’d know that.”

“What was that, short stuff?” Robbie asked imposingly.

Dipper, however, was unimpressed. “I just said she wasn’t here. Are you actually deaf on top of being tone deaf?”

“Oh, you want to get into it, huh? Well let’s get into it. You think I don’t know what’s going on, huh? It’s obvious you’ve got a thing for my girlfriend. Don’t you. Don’t you!” As Robbie stepped forward, Dipper pulled back, finally on the defensive at the implicit threat of his secret being revealed.

“What? No. Come on, man.”

“Yeah. I’m sure she’s just dying to ask out an itsy bitsy twerp the size of her finger. Not like you could ever satisfy her at that size, anyway. Hey, here’s an idea.” He pulled out his phone. “Why don’t I call her right now and see if she wants to date you.”

“Hey, don’t! Y-you don’t have to.”

But Robbie was having none of it and hit the call button. Then, just as Wendy’s voice was heard, Dipper found a pebble and chucked it at Robbie’s thumb, startling him into dropping the phone. The thing might have been okay, if it weren’t super cheap and landed in the worst possible way on a rock.

“My phone!”

“I-I’ll buy you a new one.”

“Oh, you’re not getting off that easy.” Robbie made to grab for Dipper, only to notice a red dot on his hand. The dot quickly climbed up his arm and somewhere onto his forehead. The dot came from a laser pointer tied to a grappling hook, which was currently being pointed right at the emo’s face by a very irate little girl.

“By all means. Give me an excuse,” Mabel warned.

Robbie pulled back, but turned a sneer back to Dipper. “You. Me. Circle Park. 3 o’ clock. If you’re man enough to come without your sister, we’ll finish this.” And he stomped away.

Mabel, after checking Dipper over to make sure he wasn’t hurt, brought him back in with the others.

“Ugh, what was I thinking?” asked the minizora pacing in a panic. “I can’t fight. I’ve never been in a fight before!”

“Except for the gnomes, wax people, and that Multibear thingy,” reminded Mabel.

“Does the Gobblewonker count?” Soos asked.

Grunkle Stan rolled his eyes like he didn’t believe any of this, but he also bit his lip uncomfortably. “Kid, you’re a minizora, so your options are pretty limited. I say climb up his pants and go for the balls. After that hot water incident, those things are probably dead anyway.”

“Boys, why can’t you learn to hate each other in secret, like girls do?” Mabel asked with an innocent smile while everyone else gave her a deadpan stare. “What?”

“Mabel, since when did you ever hate anyone in secret?” Dipper asked. “You’re, like, the most violent person I know.”

“I don’t know, dude. Mabel might have a point,” offered Soos. “Teens are crazy dangerous. You’re probably better off just not showing up.”

“Hey, yeah. Maybe he’ll just forget about it? Maybe this whole thing’ll just blow over.”

“Look kid, you’ve got yourself a choice here,” groused Stan. “You can either face him like a man, or hide like a wimp and let your sister fight your battles for you.” He then turned a serious, knowing gaze upon the little girl, silencing her. “What’ll it be?”

While Dipper decided to go hang out with Soos at the arcade and totally not hide, Mabel caught up with Grunkle Stan.

“Why’d you say all that dumb stuff to Dipper? Now he’s being all dumb and won’t let me help.”

“Remember that talk about distance?” Stan reminded while gluing antlers to a stuffed gopher. “Well this is the same principle. It ain’t healthy to be overly dependent on others, especially for minizora. It gives ‘em all kinds of complexes. Ya gotta let him stand up for himself and make his own mistakes.”

“But-”

“Look, someday he’s going to be in trouble and you’re not gonna be there for him. I know it’s tough to think about, but that’s life. If he doesn’t learn to deal with stuff on his own now, he’ll never be ready later. It’s like learning to ride a bike. Falling and getting scrapes is part of the experience. Builds character and makes you tough. Tough enough to handle whatever life throws at you.” When the silence went on for too long, he glanced at Mabel. “Close your mouth, kid. You’ll swallow a fly like that.”

“Wow, Grunkle Stan. If you weren’t so old, I’d say you were wise beyond your years.”

The corner of Stan’s mouth curled up. “Thanks, kid. And don’t worry too much about Dipper. Even for a minizora, that shrimp’s tougher than he looks. I doubt that Robbie kid could even do anything. This’ll be like a training wheels experience.”
115211111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Fight!

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Where Mabel had her comfort food, Dipper was trying to drown out his misery with video games. The world of Fight Fighters was so simple compared to real life. Checking his watch and watching the minutes tick away at glacial speed, he dropped the coin meant for the machine. He tracked it down to the back corner where someone had carved some secret cheat code. Curiosity peaked, and eager for a distraction, Dipper entered the code.

At first it looked like the machine shut down. Then it blared to life with a blinding light. “Choose your character!” it demanded.

“Uh, Rumble McSkirmish?” He was the only character Dipper knew off the top of his head.

The game’s light flickered enough to be a risk for epilepsy before the screen spat out, who else, but Rumble McSkirmish in all his eight bit glory.

“Rumble. You’re… alive?” They exchanged a high five. “Ow! Agh! Your pixels are really sharp.” Dipper rubbed the hand covered in tiny cuts.

“Greetings, tiny child boy!” Rumble said, his words stilted and voice sounding like he was speaking into a bad mic. “I am Rumble McSkirmish from the USA.” He delivered a flurry of kicks and punches into the air, making Dipper reflexively flinch back. The game character then punched a change machine to pieces in the hopes of turning into a wolf man.

“Cool! With Rumble around, Robbie will be so scared I won’t even need to fight him. I’ve got the world’s strongest fighter as my bodyguard.” Dipper turned back to face the game machine. “Shame about the pixels, though. There were some cute lady characters on that roster.”

Dipper brought Rumble back to the Shack and fed him a taco, which he ate by stepping on. Rumble wanted to face the world’s greatest Fight Fighters in the Soviet Union, but Dipper convinced him that there was a pretty tough fighter here in Gravity Falls. He explained that Robbie was his arch enemy, and noncommittally affirmed that the guy killed his father. Rumble then delivered another flurry of attacks in what might have been cheer, damaging the room.

“Challenge accepted. Press start.”

A big red start button appeared before Dipper, which he pushed without a second thought. “Uh oh. I think I hear my uncle. Stay perfectly still.” As Rumble continued his odd swaying, Dipper stressed, “I said stay still.”

“This is as still as I can stay.”

Dipper reasoned that he’d better hide Rumble until the fight, and so brought him up to the attic where his sister looked to be in deep thought. “Hey Mabel. Have you met Rumble yet? He’s my new bodyguard,” he bragged.

“The child gave me a taco.”

“Wow! He’s got a crazy voice! Wait… bodyguard?”

“Yeah. He’s a fighting machine. I’m going to get him to defend me from Robbie.”

Mabel’s eyes narrowed. “So you won’t let me protect you, but this guy with a mullet and headband is okay?”

“This headband belonged to my dead father!”

“Come on, Mabel. It’s nothing like that. He’s more like a summon, like in a JRPG. They summon all kinds of crazy creatures, but it’s still them who get the credit for winning the day.”

“Seems like a bit of a stretch,” Mabel said uncertainly. “Though I’m surprised you picked this beefcake and didn’t get any,” she snickered, “cheesecake.”

“Yeah, it was a spur of the moment thing. Also, his pixels are sharp, so what you’re thinking wouldn’t work anyway.”

“Yeesh. I don’t even want to know how you figured that out.”

“It was just a high five, Mabel. Get your head out of the gutter.”

“This cut-scene is taking too long,” Rumble observed. “When does the fighting begin?”

Dipper checked his watch. “In just a few minutes, actually. Well, we’re off to beat up an emo.”

“Wait, before you go, do you have any ideas how you might cure someone of a fear of heights?”

Not really paying much attention, Dipper answered, “Hmm, I don’t know. Exposure therapy maybe. Bye Mabel.”

On the way to the park, while Dipper briefed him on what to expect, Rumble picked up a large quantity of dangerous litter. This included a large pipe, a sword, an axe, a crossbow, and what looked distressingly like a laser gun. Spying old man McGucket dancing off to the side, Dipper was able to convince Rumble to discard all of it, as it would be more honorable to fight with just fists.

Down in Circle Park, which was overdue for a mowing, Robbie looked to be deciding on which ‘cool’ pose he should go with. The clock chimed and Dipper came out in the open before the teen could settle.

“Well, well, well. Look who decided to show up. I thought you’d chicken out, or maybe got stuck to the gum on someone’s shoe. So, you ready to settle this like men?”

“Says the fifteen year old to the twelve year old minizora,” Dipper shot back. “Look dude, I don’t think you want to fight me. Let’s just call this whole thing off before someone gets hurt.”

Robbie warily scanned his surroundings. “Your sister’s not here, is she?”

“Nope. Left her at home.”

His confidence returned, Robbie laughed in mockery. “Ha, then I guess you’re just being scared.”

Dipper shrugged his acceptance. “Okay dude. You asked for it.” He snapped his fingers and Rumble marched out from behind a tree, his foot falls ominously heavy.

Robbie pulled back, but still maintained a tough-guy act. “Who’s your friend? And why is he so blurry?”

“This happens to be the greatest warrior that ever lived,” bragged Dipper.

Robbie laughed. “Yeah right. Hey, eyepatch. What did the kid promise you? More tape for your arms? Hahaha.”

“How can you laugh when you killed this boy’s father?” Rumble demanded with dramatic hand gestures.

“Wait, what?”

“I’m giving you one last chance, man. Back down now or this guy’s gonna go nuts. Seriously, he’s got abbs you could grate cheese on. I fought the Multibear and this guy looks even tougher… even tougher…” Dipper trailed off, staring into the distance as the hamster wheel in his brain finally kicked in. “I might have overthought this.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Fighters

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“Enough of your stupid tiny nonsense. This ends now!” Robbie lifted his foot high, only to barely dodge when Rumble took this as the signal to begin.

Things got out of control almost immediately as Rumble delivered blows that could bend steel upon the poor emo. Even grabbing Robbie’s hoodie caused it to tear from the sharpness of the pixels. When the fireballs started flying, Robbie did the smart thing and made a run for it. Dipper tried to argue reason and restraint, but Rumble just punched everything with the misfortune of being in range as he gave pursuit.

Dipper quickly lost sight of them, but was able to follow the trail of rampant destruction to the Barrels and Crates store house. “Somehow I knew we’d end up here.”

Robbie fled down a ladder on the side of the building. He demonstrated some of the remarkable feats humans were capable of when pumped full of adrenaline as he effortlessly dodged every barrel Rumble threw his way. If this weren’t a life-or-death situation, Dipper might have commented that the emo was almost as good as a minizora, but that would have to wait.

Dipper was able to follow with relative ease, even going as fast as his little legs could move. The manotaurs might have been jerks, but their training was the real deal. Even so, the minizora’s legs were tiny, and it was only thanks to Rumble’s insistence on stopping to punch everything in sight that Dipper was able to keep up. The cops eventually showed up to do their jobs for a change, only for their car to be deposited upside down on a nearby roof. Soos finally returned from wherever he’d been, immediately recognizing Rumble as a video game character, and offered to be Dipper’s sidekick and drive the little guy to stop this menace.

Meanwhile, up high on the water tower, Grunkle Stan was suffering a terrible internal conflict. On the one hand, he was proud of Mabel for conning him to climb up here blindfolded. She’d learned well. On the other hand, he was questioning his own sanity for coming all the way up here despite knowing the little gremlin was up to something. The arrival of that stupid emo in a smelly sweating panic was barely a blip on the petrified old man’s radar.

“Challenger sighted!” Despite being unable to look up, Rumble had found his opponent/victim.

Soos drove up. “Alright dude. Go save the day. I’d totally run over him, but, you know, he’s impervious to cars."

Dipper again tried pleading, but Rumble was deaf to his words as he pummeled one of the tower’s legs. Stan and Mabel managed to keep a grip, but Robbie fell, only to be caught by the eight bit menace. With no other choice, the little boy tossed a coin at Rumble’s head, finally getting his attention.

“Rumble, I have something to tell you. Robbie didn’t kill my father. No one did. I lied to you.”

“Hyuuuk? Then that means you’re a… bad guy!”

“I guess I am,” Dipper conceded.

After hanging Robbie up on a low branch like a sack of rubbish, Rumble commenced a mournful pose, accompanied by wind to blow his hair and a very audible inner monologue. “If Robbie is not the last stage, then it must be… yooou!”

Another start button appeard before Dipper.

Soos ran up, panting. “Dude, don’t fight him. He’s got, like, a black belt wrapped around his black belt. You could get killed.”

“I have to, Soos. I started this, so it’s my responsibility to stop it. Besides, I’ve got a plan.” He punched the button.

Health bars and scores appeared over both opponents. Dipper tried mimicking Rumble’s swaying in the hopes of building energy, or whatever. Rumble’s first few blows missed, all designed to aim for someone regular sized. Dipper seized on this advantage by punching the big guy’s toe, doing a fraction of a percent’s worth of damage. “Uh oh.” Rumble then switched to low kicks that sent the minizora flying.

Demonstrating unexpected cunning, Soos tried messing with the health bars, but his hands passed right through. “Eh, it was worth a shot.”

Dipper thought he could hide high up, but rather than just punching the tree down, Rumble brought out his special skill and summoned his Fist Punch Rain, which was a literal rain of fists that made the area look like a warzone. Then, just as the big guy was getting ready to deliver his finishing move, Dipper saw his chance. “Soos, kick me!”

“What?”

“Just do it! Hurry, before it’s too late.”

“Uh, alright dude. Just don’t tell your sister.” Feeling downright awful about this, Soos put his faith in the little guy, ran up, and delivered a kick that Charlie Brown could only dream of.

At first, Rumble was confused. Then Dipper’s health bar went to zero.

“Rumble wins!” announced the bodiless narrator.

Rumble struck a victory pose and declared, “Winners don’t lose!”

“Wanna bet,” taunted Dipper.

“Game over!”

As Rumble’s pixels dissolved into nothing, he gave one final cry of “Nooo!”

Dipper stood and brushed himself off. His clothes were in shambles and probably beyond salvage, and the myriad of bruises made it painful to breathe, but at least he was alive. “Thanks a lot for that, Soos. If you hadn’t kicked me, Rumble might have actually killed me with his combo attack.”

“Dude, I’m happy for you, but please don’t make me do that again. You’re my little buddy, and buddies aren’t supposed to hurt each other.”

Dipper’s smile fell. “I wish I could make that promise, Soos. But with all the craziness we’ve seen in just the last few weeks, I need to keep my options open.” As Soos’ head fell, the minizora added, “But you have my word that you’ll be safe from Mabel.”

“Thanks, dude.”

“Ugh, what happened?” demanded Robbie, finally getting down from the tree. “Who was that guy? How come every time you’re around there’s always ghosts or monsters or whatever?”

“I don’t know. Just lucky I guess.”

“You’re joking after that guy almost broke my neck?”

Dipper sighed. “If you still want to fight, go ahead. I just want this day over with.” He held out his arms in welcome for whatever the emo had to offer.

At first, Robbie was all too happy to finally put the shrimp in his place, but when it became apparent that Dipper wouldn’t run, the emo got cold feet. Punching a tiny child was just too low, even for him. “Pssh! Probably not even worth it. I play lead guitar so I need to save my hands,” he grumbled.

Then Wendy came back. “Hey guys. Wow, what happened here? Freak tornado or something?”

“Or something,” Dipper answered.

“And why are your faces all jacked up? You guys weren’t fighting, were you? I hate it when guys fight.”

Backed into a corner, Robbie stammered incoherently, unsure of how to get out of this.

That’s when Dipper stepped in with a plan. “Actually, there was this super strong guy who went on a rampage through the town. Ask anyone. They all saw him punching powerlines and flipping cars. Right Robbie?”

“Huh? Oh, yeah. Yeah totally. It was the, um, strong guy. Had a mullet and no shirt.”

“That would explain why dad’s acting weird. Mom says he’s sensed a rival alpha male on his turf and now his primal instincts are going nuts.”

Sure enough, Manly Dan was throwing a very manly – and surprisingly helpful – tantrum. Screaming at the sky, he punched stop signs back into alignment, flipped cars upright, and overall tried to undo everything that Rumble had touched. Some things just couldn’t be fixed with punches, but Manly Dan was definitely saving the repair crews a lot of work.

“Yeah, well, we lured him out here and tricked him into beating us up. The eight bits gave away that he was a video game character, so once he thought he won,” Dipper snapped, “it was game over. Right, Robbie?”

“Uh… sure?”

Wendy blinked like a deer in the headlights. “Dude, that’s amazing! I’m happy to see you guys getting along, but also terrified of video games coming to life,” she added nervously. “Well, I still got some unpacking to do. You’ve got to tell me the whole story later,” she said as she left.

When she was out of earshot, Dipper leveled with Robbie. If they kept fighting, they’d both lose, so they had to agree to a cold war pact and just hate one another in silence, like girls other than Mabel did.

Speaking of Mabel, Grunkle Stan was having a hard time getting her off the tower after his fear of heights had seemingly transferred to her. All in all, an eventful day for everyone.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Fight Fighters!

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It was just another lazy day at the Shack when the doorbell rang. Stan answered and was greeted by a man telling him that he’d won some contest no one had even heard of. It looked mighty official though, what with the camera guy and the beautiful women holding an oversized check. With everyone excited, Stan was told that he need only sign on the dotted line, and all this money would be his. So he did.

“Ah ha!” proclaimed Gideon as he burst out into the open. “Stanford, you fool. You just signed over the Mystery Shack to li’l ol’ me!” He then tapped out a condescending victory dance.

But while the twins were horrified, Stan grinned like the cat who’d swallowed the canary. “Might wanna take another look there.”

Confused, Gideon read back through the document, all the way down to the signature. “Suck a lemon little man!?” He tore up the contract as Stan mocked him. “How dare you! Ah am not a threat to be taken lightly. Ah’ll get you, Stanford Pines. Ah’ll get you-” A throat clearing caused Gideon to spin around. Mabel was there, smiling that radiant smile of hers that he just adored. “W-why Mabel. W-what a surprise seein’ you here.”

Mabel slapped a hand on Gideon’s shoulder and dug her fingers in deep. “Gideon, are you aware that these people you brought with you are witnesses?”

He gulped audibly. “That w-was the plan, yes.”

Mabel tilted her head, her smile growing to terrifying lengths. “So you’re aware that the only reason you’re still breathing is because I don’t want to go to jail for murder, right?”

He squeaked and nodded. Sweat was staining his suit and her grip was growing more painful by the second.

“Let this be your last warning. If I catch you anywhere near my family again, I might not be bothered to care about any witnesses. Get me?”

“Ah got’ch’ya.”

“Good. Then get!” Mabel then picked up the fat boy, hurling him out the door and across the lawn. He skipped like a stone and scuffed his suit. The little girl shot a death glare at the troll’s cohorts, giving them the cue that they weren’t welcome. When the intruders finally left, Mabel looked down to see Dipper waiting to be picked up. She obliged and held him close. “Thank you, Grunkle Stan,” she whispered tiredly.

His name called, Stan regained his composure after nearly being scared pissless by the little girl. “Eh, it was no biggy. Little freak show needs to get up extra early if he wants to pull one over on Stan. Now who wants to watch some TV while their favorite Grunkle gets them an ice cream?”

Mabel raised her hand, but Stan was already off. She sat against the chair, rocking herself while Dipper’s tiny hand stroked her fingers.

“It’s alright, Mabel. He can’t hurt us anymore. The amulet’s gone, remember.”

“He’s still trying though,” Mabel growled darkly. “Is there a way to break someone’s legs so that they can never heal right? I might need to-”

“Mabel, no!” Dipper asserted. “I know that look. You can’t go around picking fights like that anymore.”

“I’m not the one picking. He came into our house, Dipper! This is supposed to be a safe place where we can just relax.” She turned to look down at the floor where Gideon had stood. “Now his shoe prints are in the carpet.”

With her grip too tight to wiggle free, Dipper tapped Mabel’s knuckle and she brought him close to her face. For his sister, Dipper gave his most endearing smile, reached out, and hugged her chin. “You’re the strongest person I know, Mabel. I know you won’t let anything happen to me.”

Mabel sniffled, unable to wipe away the tears before they could stain her cheeks. “I don’t ever want to see you like that again,” she whimpered, recalling that horrid night in the abandoned building. Just remembering Dipper being so close to those scissors made her want to vomit. The idea that Gideon was still out there, still scheming, and still pining for her, made her feel even worse. “I’ve never hated anyone as much as Gideon,” she confessed. “He’s worse than any bully. He’s a monster. And if I catch him here again, then I don’t care what happens to me.”

“But I do,” Dipper called, interrupting her confession. “I do, Mabel. You can’t throw your life away like that; especially not for Gideon. I can’t lose you to him.”

“I can’t lose you either, bro-bro.” Mabel’s hands tenderly cupped behind Dipper, holding him where she needed him to be. I just need to stay like this for a while. That okay?”

“Always.”

Some hours later, Mabel had calmed enough to play chess with Dipper. He won, like always. But in response to him being a sore winner, Mabel saw fit to rub her height in his face when Soos asked her to fetch something off a shelf. It was all in good fun, though. Dipper was basically numb to short jokes at this point and it was just nice to see Mabel smile again. However, this did get the minizora to thinking.

Dipper went flipping through the journal and found something interesting. The author described a kind of crystal in the forest with height altering properties. After making sure that Mabel was fine with him leaving, he ventured forth, promising that he hoped to return with a special surprise for his sister. As he went, following the directions in the pages, Dipper’s heart began to race even more than his battle with Rumble. If what the journal said was accurate, then this could be a dream come true. And as much as Dipper hated when people called being a minizora a birth defect and treated it like a handicap, the crystals in this book could do something that could only be described as a cure.

After taking a brief tumble down a hill, Dipper came nose-to-nose with a deer. Not just any deer, but a deer less than twice his size. There was a whole herd of them taking shelter beneath some mushrooms. “Whoa.” Dipper ventured further into this shadowed part of the forest and spotted several more animals of unusual size. That tiny mountain lion gave him a scare. However, being shrunk didn’t turn it into a minizora, so Dipper was able to fend it off with relative ease.

Finally Dipper’s journey led him to a giant crystal, surrounded by hundreds of other crystals. Light from the sun shined down and seemed to refract through the crystal, resulting in different beams of light with different size changing properties. Pink for shrinking and blue for enlarging. So excited that he might pass out, Dipper quickly snatched up one of the crystals and took it back to the Shack. With a bit of finagling, Dipper managed to cobble together a specialized flashlight able to shrink and grow things at will. From here, he knew there could be only one course.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Little Dipper

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“Mabel,” Dipper called from the attic. “Can you come here? I’ve got that surprise for you.” Hearing rapid footsteps ascend the stairs, a very giddy Dipper dove into the closet and shut the door just as Mabel entered.

“Surprise? Surprise? Where’s the surprise?” Mabel asked like a dog who’d just heard someone say ‘walk’.

“You need to get on the bed first,” instructed Dipper, the closet door muffling his voice.

“Oh? Mabel is intrigued,” she said while rubbing her chin. “What’s so special about the bed? And why are you hiding?”

“It’s where I’ll give you the surprise, also that’s a secret. You really want me to spoil it before you can be surprised?”

“If you tell me, I’ll still act surprised,” Mabel said in a singsong voice.

“Just sit on the bed and close your eyes. Trust me. You’ll love it.”

“Oh fine, mister bossy pants.” Mabel huffed and hopped up on the bed. “Okay. I’m waiting.”

“Are your eyes closed?”

“Yeah.”

“Are they really, though?”

“Yeaaah!” griped Mabel, starting to get annoyed.

“If they’re open, the surprise won’t be as good.”

“Ugh! Fine.” Finally she closed her eyes. “They’re closed. This had better be worth it.”

“Oh, it will be.” Dipper pushed the door open, tentatively poking his head around to see Mabel with her eyes closed. In his new state, she looked so very different. She was still the same as this morning, but his new perspective made everything seem so much… smaller. Dipper stepped out of the closet, his steps careful so as to minimize noise. He didn’t want her getting any hints before she could be surprised. It was actually kind of exhilarating how loud the floor creaks were under his shoes. He’d never made this much noise before. And all that junk that was left out on the floor. He had to step over it rather than walk around it. Okay, forget the wolf by the stream. This was the new greatest experience in Dipper’s life. And he knew things were about to get better.

“Can I open my eyes, yet?” Mabel whined impatiently.

“Not yet,” Dipper whispered, almost there. “Just a little longer.”

“Can I at least get a hint?” huffed the little girl.

“Did I ever tell you how pretty you look?”

Eyes still closed, Mabel turned a confused look down to where she thought Dipper was, not realizing she was only facing his feet. “What brought this on all of a sudden?”

“Don’t know. You just live with something every day and it just fades into the background. Then there’s a tiny change, and it’s like you’re seeing it for the first time all over again. And you realize just how pretty it is.”

“I’m warning you, Dipper,” Mabel said, wagging her finger. “Don’t you get all lovey-dovey with me. Not unless you’re prepared to deal with the consequences.”

“Oh, I’m prepared. I’m prepared like I’ve never been before,” Dipper said, brimming with excitement.

“S-sounds like you’ve got something extra special going on.” Something about Dipper’s voice was getting her all hot and bothered. “You almost never initiate like this. I always have to nag you, or you just let me pick you up and have my fun. Why so assertive?”

“Oh, you know. Just feeling like a new me.” Unable to restrain himself any longer, Dipper took the final step forward. “And here’s your surprise.” Dipper pressed his lips into Mabel’s. He’d kissed her more times than he could remember, even on the lips, but this wasn’t like those other times. Before, he’d been tiny. A kiss from him was like the kiss of a mouse, and a return kiss from her would engulf most of his head. This time, his lips aligned evenly with hers. Their noses poked one another.

With a start, Mabel’s eyes shot open and beheld a mirror pair of brown orbs staring right back at her. It was like a low key funhouse mirror, only significantly less twisted. The noses were identical, but the cheeks lacked her natural blush. The chin was a bit more angular and the hair was just flat out wrong. That’s when it finally clicked for Mabel where she’d seen this face before. It wasn’t a mirror. It was her brother, only not tiny anymore.

Dipper finally broke the kiss and pulled back with his winningest smile. Standing at his full height, he was maybe an inch or two taller than Mabel sitting down. They were still on each other’s level, though. For the first time ever, they were truly looking eye-to-eye. “‘Sup, sis?”

It took Mabel a hot minute to fully process what she was looking at. But even when the simplest explanation asserted itself as the truth, it still didn’t quite click with her. “Is… is there a magnifying glass here or something?”

Dipper chuckled indulgently, reached out, and took Mabel’s hand. Her skin erupted in goosebumps at his touch, but he was not dissuaded from carefully interlocking his fingers with hers. “You know, somehow it’s even softer like this.”

Shaking from a hurricane of emotions, Mabel looked down at her brother’s hand. It was definitely his. Bigger, but still his. He was holding hers as an equal instead of just doing the best minizora equivalent. If they could do this, then surely there’d be other… For the first time since opening her eyes, Mabel remembered to breathe and sucked in a lungful. At long last, the stunned surprise finally faded from her face, replaced by shimmering eyes and a twisted mouth.

“Uh, Mabel?”

“Wha-ha!” Mabel lunged forward, knocking Dipper to the ground as she wrapped her arms around him. Not just her hands, but her whole arms. It took all of her to hold all of him as she started bawling. She pressed her face into his chest to muffle her cries, flipping the script from how things usually went. His chest was broad and well-defined for his age, rigid with muscles and an inner strength neither of them were fully aware of just yet.

Having not expected this reaction, Dipper did what any minizora would do and rolled with the punches. His arms wrapped around Mabel. Not just her cheek, her hand, or even her foot. He wrapped his arms around her back until his fingers touched. It was the most amazing thing. Mabel’s weight was fully upon him, but she was so light. He could probably pull her off if he wanted, not that he would. Someone his own size was atop him and holding him close. Feeling his own eyes start to water, he had no choice but to reciprocate.

For a while the twins just lay there on the floor, basking in the sensations of holding one another like never before. It was amazing, exhilarating, terrifying, and somewhat stomach turning all at once. But amidst their tumultuous feelings, one question weighed heavy on both siblings’ minds. What would come next?
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Big Dipper

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Mabel had gone through a whole box of tissues before she was finally ready to face this new situation. Sitting across from one another on the floor, it started with her poking Dipper in the face. She watched as his skin compressed against her touch, marveling at the level of detail she’d never noticed before. Mabel moved on to poking Dipper in the shoulder, the chest, under the chin, and under his armpit. He flinched, laughing at being tickled, but Mabel just frowned. “Huh, that’s weird.”

“What’s weird?” Dipper asked. “I might be big, but I’m still ticklish.”

“Yeah, but… I don’t want to do it again,” she said, not fully understanding her own words.

“What does that mean?”

“I don’t know. Usually when I tickle you, it’s super cute and I just want to keep at it. But right now, I don’t really want to.”

“Well, you’ve probably got a lot on your mind right now,” reasoned Dipper. “After all, you’re not the big sister anymore.”

Shivering like she’d been thrown out naked in a snowstorm, Mabel wrapped her arms around herself. “It feels like someone just walked over my grave.”

“C’mon Mabel. You’re exaggerating.”

“No I’m not, Dipper. What you said… there was something seriously wrong with it.”

“What? It’s the truth. Now that we’re the same size, technically I’m older, so now I’m the-”

Mabel sprang forward and slapped both hands over Dipper’s mouth. “Don’t say it!”

Rolling his eyes, Dipper tapped at Mabel’s hands. He’d intended only to signal her to stop like he always did, but underestimated his own strength and pushed her hands aside instead. His eyes met hers and they shared a moment of silent understanding. “I think I’m still a minizora.”

“How’s that possible, though? You’re so big and minizora are supposed to be, you know, mini.”

“It must be the crystal. It can change size, but everything else is as it should be. I’ve still got my minizora physiology!” he beamed. “Mabel, this means I’m not just regular sized. I’m minizora tough! When I went to get the crystal, I wrestled with a shrunken mountain lion and won! Now… now I can do the same with a regular mountain lion! Hey, think we can go pay Manly Dan a visit? I wanna arm wrestle him.”

“Dipper… Wait, crystal?”

“Yeah. I made a size changer using a crystal I found out in the woods. Just press a button and pfft. Big or small. The sky’s the limit. Though we probably shouldn’t test that.”

Mabel blinked. “Then… this is reversible?” she asked, sounding hopeful.

Dipper frowned. “Why would I ever want to reverse it?”

“Oh, I don’t know. Why would you want to shoot yourself with some weird magicy size changing ray, or whatever it is?”

“You can’t be serious right now. Mabel, did you actually ask me, a minizora, why I’d jump at the chance to finally be regular sized?” he asked incredulously, and somewhat offended. “I thought that would have been obvious, especially to you of all people. You’re the one person in the world more worried about me getting stepped on, kicked around, or just swept aside and ignored than I am. All those times we talked… You were the one person who really understood.”

“I do, Dipper,” Mabel insisted, gesturing at him. “But this? This isn’t regular sized. This isn’t natural.”

Straightening up, Dipper took a calming breath. While the world was chaos around him, inside he had inner peace. A few carefully measured breaths later and he was ready to start again. “Mabel, I think you might be missing the big picture here.”

Mabel’s shoulders relaxed. That was Dipper’s calming technique. It was something they’d learned together, but only he really practiced. Seeing him calm down like he always did was a welcomingly familiar sight. Maybe not everything was so different? “Okay. What’s the big picture?”

“Mabel, if I’m big, I’ll never be stepped on again. And since I’m big and minizora strong, Gideon can never hurt me again. I don’t know if you heard me the first time, but I beat back a mountain lion. If Gideon comes at me with scissors again, I can just kick his balls up his throat; or at least give it a good try. Mabel, while I’m like this, you never have to worry about me again.”

Mabel’s jaw about hit the floor. On the one hand, this was objectively terrific news. So much time had been devoted to worrying about Dipper that she frequently suffered bouts of constipation and other stress induced afflictions. Living without that would be a dream come true. But more important than herself was him. Dipper being impervious to scissors and safe from general harm was her oldest wish, since back before she could remember. It’s what she always put on the top of her wish list to Santa. Surely she should be happy at finally having her heart’s most coveted desire, so why did she feel so awful?

“And there’s one more thing you’re missing,” Dipper added, shooting Mabel a lascivious smirk. He leaned back on one hand, pulled up his shirt, and unzipped his fly. Mabel fixated on his pants, her eyes swelling to the size of dinner plates. Dipper reached into his pants like he was going to extract something, but instead started caressing himself to hardness. “I’m bigger, Mabel. Wanna see just how big I can get?”

Mabel just kept staring, but gave no signs of confirmation. Why, though? Dipper was initiating. His newfound size had made him bold, and now he was teasing her without any prompting on her part. This was also something she’d fantasized about, if to a lesser extent. By all accounts, she should have lunged for him again, or at least nodded until her neck hurt, yet all she did was stare. It was like she felt something really bad was coming, but couldn’t tear her eyes away.

Dipper noticed Mabel acting off, but tried to ignore it, rationalizing that she was still processing the new him. That would change momentarily, however. When she saw the next part of his gift for her, her worries would be forgotten like a snap. She’d be the old Mabel, he’d be the new Dipper, and things would make sense just like they used to. Finally at full hardness, Dipper whipped out his cock in all its glory. To him, it looked the same as always. But to Mabel, she was pretty sure that this thing was proportionally bigger than it used to be, on top of being objectively larger. That thing could fill up her whole hand, or even mouth.

His grin turned expectant and anticipatory. Any minute now, Mabel would react. She’d jump him, licking him and pulling him inter her mouth like she always did. Granted, he was a bit more than a mouthful these days, but Mabel had always been a determined optimist; a dangerous combination when she got horny. Any minute now, her craving for his body would take control and he might finally enjoy a regular person blowjob, hopefully followed by more.

Mabel’s eyes practically sparkled as she beheld the tower of meat. It was the tallest she’d ever seen up close. She’d had it in her mouth before, tasting it and everything around it more times than she could count. Its flavor was rich and never failed to put her in a good mood, yet something was off. This new thing looked a lot like the old thing. Every detail was exactly as she remembered, save one. Did they really compare, though? Mabel finally looked away from Dipper’s enlarged penis, trailing the considerable distance up his body until finally she met his eyes as well. “Dipper.”

“Yes, Mabel?”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Does Size Matter?

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“I… I can’t.”

“I’m sorry, what?”

“I just… I don’t know. This is wrong, Dipper. You’re wrong.”

“So… what? Is that it, then?” he asked irritably. “You don’t want to do it with me anymore?”

“No, I mean yes. Grr! I want to do it with you, but with the real you.”

“This is the real me, Mabel. The new and improved me. Why can’t you be happy about this?”

“I…”

“Isn’t this everything we’ve both wanted? Me safe and finally able to hold someone like myself?”

“M-maybe this is all happening too fast for both of us,” Mabel reasoned, her scheme forming. “This is still reversible, right? Maybe I’ll feel better if I can hold you like I normally do.”

“Alright,” Dipper conceded. It was a fair request. Standing, he went back into the closet and pulled out the flashlight. He double checked the settings to make sure they were in alignment, and prepared to press the button.

“Yoink!”

“What?”

“It’s mine now!” declared Mabel, running out the door with Dipper in hot pursuit.

She’d made it a short distance across the lawn before he’d caught up with her, tackling her to the ground. The flashlight went off, turning a caterpillar to the size of a bus. The two continued their struggle over the delicate machine, aiming at the other’s bodies but only able to shrink or grow certain parts. In all the commotion, just when everything was proportional again, the flashlight went flying, stopping before a familiar pair of suede shoes.

Gideon was in rough shape. His latest plan had just failed and he was just about to leave the property when he noticed the device. “My, my. What delightful manner of dohickery is this?” He looked up, spying the Pines twins. Particularly he spied how one of them had grown a couple of shoe sizes, to say the least. He looked at the device, then back to the twins, and again at the device. His grin grew sinister and Grinch-like as he took aim, flipped the switch, and watched the magic happen.

Rapidly shrinking was a lot like going down on a roller coaster. For Dipper, everything was back to normal. Gideon was the same ugly troll he’d always been; only now he had a power that rivaled the amulet. Mabel wasn’t taking things nearly as well, however. Everything had become gigantic and terrifying. Spying a bird overhead, Mabel felt the same apprehension of it coming for Dipper, only exponentially worse. It could come for her, and there’d be no one to stop it. Even worse, from her angle she was staring straight up at giant Gideon’s giant crotch. As always, she held close to Dipper for comfort.

As Gideon laughed at his impending victory, he used the jar that once held magic termites to scoop up the tiny twins. The pale boy’s walk wasn’t exactly even as he carried the jar under his arm, reasonably confident that no one would notice or confront him about its contents. Inside, Dipper held onto Mabel as the jar jostled and tossed them around. He tried to protect her from as many hits as possible. After all, he was a minizora. He was born to handle this kind of treatment, but she wasn’t. Finally in his room, Gideon locked the door and dumped the twins onto his desk.

“You two,” he accused.

“Wh-what are you gonna do with us?” asked Mabel, refusing to let this hateful person see her cry.

“Why Mabel, Ah wouldn’t hurt a hair on yer pretty little head,” Gideon laughed, only to switch to a threatening tone so fast that it almost gave him whiplash. “If you agree to be my queen.”

“Yeah, okay,” she replied quickly and evenly, startling both boys.

“Wait, really?” asked Gideon.

“I mean, yeah. Doy.” Mabel stood and approached the edge of the desk, smiling sweetly. “I realize that I’ve been acting silly. After all, you’re li’l Gideon the fortune teller. You’re the most amazing person in Gravity Falls. I’d l-love to be your queen,” she strained to say without throwing up.

Gideon’s eyes narrowed. “Do you really think Ah’m stupid enough ta fall fer that?”

“Eh. Worth a shot.” Mabel let her instincts take hold and lunged at Gideon, only for him to catch her mid-leap.

“Maybe you’ll change yer mind after this.”

“You leave her alone you creep!” Dipper snarled, looking around for anything he could use as a weapon. He’d always been wary of what other people might do if they caught him, but worrying about Mabel in the hands of Gideon was far worse. Luckily, Gideon only dropped the girl in a bag of gummy koalas to keep her pacified with sugar.

“As fer you, boy,” Gideon intoned sinisterly and shined a lamp light down on Dipper. “Tell me! How exactly did you come upon this magic item? Did somebody tell you about it? Did you read about it?”

The way Gideon said that word told Dipper all he needed to know. The troll knew of the journals and possibly even had one. Dipper reflexively glanced down at his vest, but luckily his captor didn’t notice. He smirked. “Lean closer and I’ll tell you.”

Confident in the power of his size, Gideon giggled and obliged. “Well, don’t mind if Ah do.”

Dipper pushed the button on the air horn right into Gideon’s ear, making him scream. The minizora took advantage of the distraction and ran for Mabel, who was still stress eating. Unfortunately, an arm slammed down and blocked his path. Gideon had recovered, and was pissed.

“Ah should squash you right now!” Gideon bellowed, his fist held high at the ready. Dipper, infuriatingly so, scowled and held out his arms in defiant invitation. Then the troll got to thinking and pulled his fist down. “Steel yourself, Gideon. You can use them. You can use them.”

While Gideon was on the phone, trying to ransom the twins to Stan, Dipper had run over to the candy bag. The plastic was ridiculously strong for such a cheap product and resisted his efforts to tear it open. Pushing worked a lot better and he ran inside to hug Mabel, only for her to pull away in pain. Horrified, Dipper checked her body over and found numerous bruises. He’d failed to protect her back in the jar. He’d failed to protect her from Gideon.

When Gideon’s ransom plot failed, the twerp descended into maniacal laughter as the obvious struck him. “What am Ah doin’? Ah don’t need ransom! Ah have this,” he boasted, holding up the flashlight. “Ah’ll shrink Stan ‘n’ take the Shack fer mahself.” Then he looked back at the twins. “You’ll be helpless ta stop me.”

“Why do you want the Shack so much anyway?” demanded Dipper, using his body to block Gideon’s view of Mabel. “Is all of this just revenge for Mabel dumping you? You know that’s never gonna win her back.”

“Well, that’s mah li’l ol’ secret, boy. But now that Ah have this,” Gideon eyed up the flashlight, “Ah might have ta accelerate mah plans. Imagine it, boy. An army of mah loyal followers grown ta giant size. Or perhaps Ah’ll try the covert rout ‘n’ mass produce these babies ta sell. It’ll be a new age of warfare with cities crushed beneath the feet of giants, ‘n’ all while Ah rake in the dough, bidin’ mah time ta take over once the ashes settle. Either way works.” His dastardly plan delivered, there was another moment of tonal whiplash after Gideon was distracted by the call of the ice cream truck, followed by uncaging his hamster to guard the twins and closing the door on his way out.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Big Boy

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“Jesus Christ, he really is insane!” exclaimed Dipper. “We’ve got to stop him and get that flashlight back.”

“But how?” Mabel whimpered, stuffing half a koala into her sweater pouch. “He’s so big! Wh-what if he uses the light on us again and shrinks us down to nothing? And how will we even make it to the Shack like this?”

Dipper nodded thoughtfully and peeked over the edge of the desk. “The carpet down there looks soft enough. I could handle the fall, but you can’t.”

Mabel’s expression fell. “We have no choice. You might as well lea-”

“No chance in hell,” Dipper said flatly. “I’d sooner die before leaving you alone to be some pervert albino’s sex toy. You’re coming and-and I’ll protect you.”

Mabel looked hesitant and rubbed a bruise on her arm. “Can you, though?”

“Mabel, we’ll figure out a way.” He took her hands in his, shuddering at the feeling. Having someone his own size was still exhilarating, but he pushed those feelings aside. “We’re the mystery twins. We always find a way.”

Mabel finally smiled as her eyes watered. “Now there’s the real Dipper I know and love.” Both were taken aback by her words. “I… I don’t know why I said that.”

Dipper frowned. “We can talk this out later. Right now we need to get out of here.” His eyes fell upon Gideon’s comb. “And I think I have a plan.”

Tying the hairs into a rope, the twins descended the side of the desk. They snuck their way into the living room and witnessed Gideon throwing a screaming tantrum over being tickled, terrifying his father before knocking over a vase and storming out. The mother, who’s hair had turned prematurely gray from stress, kept her head down and muttered, “Just keep vacumin’,” like it was a meditation mantra. Reasoning that neither adult could be trusted to help thwart Gideon, the twins carefully maneuvered their way through the obstacles of furniture. Dipper pulled Mabel along, but she was only able to make it ¾ of the way to the doggie door before her sides ached from the strain.

“You do this every day?” she breathlessly gasped. “How?”

Dipper face palmed. “Cuz I’m a minizora,” he said through gritted teeth, shooting Mabel a look of warning before she could say something stupid. “We’re leaving together and that’s that.”

“But how?” she wheezed. “I just ran, like, three football fields and my sides hurt. I can’t stop Gideon like this.”

“Stop Gideon?”

The twins snapped up to face Mrs. Gleeful. At somepoint she’d turned the vacuum off and switched to a brush and scoop for the glass from the vase Gideon broke. Tools in hand, now she stared at the tiny children like a prisoner who’d just seen their first sliver of daylight in years.

“Somethin’ wrong, sugar lumps?” Bud asked distractedly.

“Uh, nothin’ sweetie.” Mrs. Gleeful squatted down, stared directly at the kids, and carefully said, “Ah see nothin’ at all.” She then set the scoop down to the ground and motioned for the kids to get on. They decided to take a chance and trust her, allowing her to ferry them away from Bud. “Hey, you’re that girl Gideon likes.”

“I’m the girl Gideon stalks after I kicked his-”

Dipper covered his sister’s mouth. “Why are you helping us?”

Mrs. Gleeful’s eye twitched. “Y-you don’t belong here. You live at the M-Mystery Shack, r-right? That’s where you s-should be.”

Dipper frowned skeptically. “Uh, yeah. Yeah, the Shack is definitely the place we should be. Um, can you take us?”

“The Shack. I take you… away. Away from… place. This place,” she muttered as she carried the scoop out to the lot and found one of Bud’s test models with the keys still in the ignition. “Take you away. I take… away. S-stop… him. Stop… him.” With the kids dumped into her lap, the stressed frown slowly began to twist as she turned the key and started laughing. “Stop… him. I stop him. Istophim! Hehe, haha! I stop him!”

For the first time since being shrunk, Mabel was glad to be unable to see what was happening around her. Despite their best efforts to keep steady, Mrs. Gleeful’s driving was even worse than Stan’s. She kept making wild swerves, horns blared all around her, and the twins even heard a few crashes. She never stopped laughing; lost in her own little world in a joke that she’d never told to anyone. The joke that was her life.

Eventually she stopped, finally getting her laughing under control and opened the car door. They were back at the Shack and Gideon was walking across the lawn. With one hand over her mouth to suppress her chortles, the other set the twins down on the ground. There was so much more she could have done to help, if she only had the nerve. But rather than doing something effective but illegal, Mrs. Gleeful spied the partially melted gummy in Mabel’s pouch. She took it, and with skills that amazingly hadn’t rusted in years of neglect, flicked the candy straight into Gideon’s hair, sending him into another fit as he dropped the light. She drove off while he was distracted, laughing hysterically at the greatest triumph she’d experienced in years.

The twins ran to the flashlight, but Dipper was the first to reach the front.

“Quick, regrow me and I can stop Gideon.”

“What? No way. I can stop Gideon just fine on my own.”

“Your own? So you’re not going to grow me back to regular size?”

“You’re already regular size! I’m not, so I should grow. Why can’t you just accept that I’m the big sister?”

“Oh, I see how it is. You want me to stay small so you can lord it over me. You can’t stand the idea of a Dipper who can stand up for himself.”

“That’s not true!” cried Mabel.

“Makes sense ta me,” Gideon patronized, snatching up the twins before they could react. Holding them up to his face, he continued his taunt. “Ah dare say you would’ve defeated me, if it wasn’t fer yer siblin’ bickerin’.” Gideon’s imaginings with what he could do with the twins must have reflected in his expression, because the both of them pulled away in revulsion. That was fine. They were right to be afraid. Tired of stalling, Gideon stormed into the Shack, spied the fez, and shrunk its wearer. “The Shack is mine now, Stan!”

However, when Gideon went over to pick up the fez and gloat, all were surprised to find Soos. The three tiny people were then tossed in a jar and stuffed in Gideon’s pocket as he began his hunt through the Shack. “Stanford, Ah’m comin’ fer ya!”

The three tinies huddled together in the jar, unable to break free, as Mabel started crying. “I’m sorry.”

“Sorry for what?” asked Dipper. “I’m the one who made that stupid device. This is all my fault.”

“Of course you made it. You’re a minizora,” Mabel countered. “Like any of you wouldn’t do that if given the chance! This is my fault because… because I couldn’t accept you being bigger.”

“Mabel…?”

Curled up, she buried her face in her knees. “You were right about me. I didn’t want to accept it, but it’s true. I love being the big sister. I love looking out for you and you looking up to me. We relied on each other and got through the hard times as a team. But if you’re big, then you don’t need me.”

Dipper lunged forward and, as carefully as he could, pulled Mabel into an embrace, all while Soos had plugged his fingers into his ears, closed his eyes, and hummed to himself. “Mabel, you’ll always be my big sister, and I’ll always need you.
