Being big wouldn’t change that,” he assured as she cried into his shoulder. “But, now that I think about it, this wouldn’t be something we could hide,” he sighed. “People would find out about a minizora turning up big. Questions would be asked and people would inevitably find the crystals. Then it’d be just like Gideon said: a new arms race.” Dipper pulled away and showed Mabel his most committed expression. “We’ll stop Gideon, get everything back to normal, and… and destroy it.”

Mabel cried all the louder and babbled incoherently. Only Dipper was able to decipher her gibberish. Karen just looked at the other woman in a perpetual sneer. “What are you ta-?”

A thunderous roar shook through the isles. It was like an earthquake, shaking merchandise right off the shelves and causing most shoppers to fall. Karen only barely held her footing when she saw the beast charging for her, mouth open in a lust for blood.

Sheela, deciding to be merciful, turned Dipper away from the carnage. She smiled sweetly down at him, petting his tiny shivering body. “Well howdy there, cutie. Havin’ a rough Summerween?”

“Uh, a little,” Dipper said distractedly, fighting with all his might not to stare at the woman’s perfect boobs.

“Well don’t you worry none. Ya’ll’ve been in Gravity Falls long enough that folks recognize ya as one of our own. We ain’t like them entitled twats.”

Dipper snickered, once more getting sucked into the black hole that was Sheela’s fantastic chest. “Yeah. You guys are… nice.”

“You ain’t half bad yerself, sweetie. Ohh, Ah could jus’ eat ya’ll up.”

There came a throat clearing. Down below, Mabel was looking up with her hand held out expectantly. Her rage state had passed, but her vacant expression showed that she was still very stressed and needed her comfort object returned. As for Karen, well, Mabel was just a kid who’d acted in self-defense. It was probably fine.

Being the good and lovely neighbor she was, Sheela returned Dipper to his sister, making her spring back with light and life. Cordial greetings were exchanged and, in gratitude for her service, Mabel agreed to loan Dipper out to Sheela whenever she asked.

***

“Okay, I was sensing some bullshit for a while, but I draw the line at that last part,” asserted Wendy. “Ain’t no way Mabel would ever agree to that.”

Sheela giggled at her daughter’s reaction as she arranged the decorations for the house. “Yer free ta think what ya want, but Ah’m telling ya, that’s exactly how it happened.” She faced her daughter and pushed her boobs up. “Boy couldn’t tear his eyes off me.”

Wendy turned away with a blush.

“Aww, don’t be down. There’s no need to be jealous. After all, with yer genes, you’ll look at least this good in a few more years.”

“Maaa!”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Costume Shopping

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Mabel was having a blast preparing for Summerween, though she still wasn’t ready to let go of Dipper just yet. The less said about that incident at the store, the better, but suffice to say that everyone got exactly what they deserved. “I’m so excited!”

“We’re gonna have the best costumes, get the most candy,” Dipper listed.

“And have the biggest stomach aches ever!”

“Dude, I’ve never seen you guys so pumped,” commented Soos in his luchador costume.

“Well, back home, me and Dipper were kind of the kings of trick or treating,” Mabel humbly bragged and pulled out a photo album to show Soos. “Twins in costumes. The people eat it up.”

Soos, however, was wary. After turning off the lights and shining a flashlight under his chin for atmosphere, he told the kids about the Summerween Trickster. It was the local legend of a creature that eats children who lack the Summerween spirit.

“Is that true?” Mabel asked of her shoulder boy.

Dipper pulled out the journal. “Hmm. I’m not seeing anything here, but this is number 3. The author could have wrote about it in one of the first two, but I don’t think we should worry.”

“Yeah! We’ve got spirit out the wazoo! Whatever that is.” After popping a sweet in her mouth, Mabel unwrapped one for Dipper and he started coughing.

“Ugh! What is this stuff? I’ve never even heard of these brands. Gummy chairs?”

“Huh. I never thought anything gummy could ever not be appetizing, but there it is,” Mabel observed. “This is all cheapo loser candy.”

“Quiet your discontent, children,” Soos warned. “Lest the Trickster overhear.”

“Oh right. Um, wow, this candy is sooo good,” Dipper loudly called. Sitting on Mabel’s shoulder, he tapped at her neck.

“Huh? Oh. Yeah. I just love-love-love it!” Smiling, she stood and carried the bowl to the outside trash.

“Yup. It’s sooo good, we’re gonna be extra nice and share it with the raccoons. Because that’s the spirited thing to do,” announced Dipper as he watched the bowl be dumped of its undesirable contents. “There,” he said in a more regular voice. “That should keep the Trickster satisfied.”

“Whoa, dudes. Most kids I tell this story to just laugh it off. You dudes are pretty serious.”

“Soos, after the stuff we’ve seen in just the last month, I’m starting to disbelieve in the concept of fiction.”

“Huh?”

“It means he thinks all fantasy stories are actually real.”

“At least in Gravity Falls,” Dipper amended.

The twins went back to work putting the finishing touches on the Shack while the TV played in the background. It was some fluff piece about the latest celebrity gossip. Specifically, well-endowed actress Britney Javelin was walking around with her minizora boyfriend, Timothy Corvette, wedged between her boobs. The little guy was smiling and waving to the paparazzi, looking very snug and comfortable. His transport was absolutely eating up all the attention, posing for the cameras and even messing with Timothy by playing with her boobs. It was like she was sending a message to all the women of the world, saying: ‘Look at me. I’ve got perfect tits that can please a minizora. What do you have?’ Mabel tried to keep busy with her work, but her eyes kept returning to the screen as her thoughts ran wild.

The doorbell rang and Stan instructed whoever to give them the terrible candy.

“Think I can do this on my own?”

Mabel frowned. “Well, okay, but I’m taking a sniper position on the roof.”

“Whatever makes you happy, sis.” Dipper patted her cheek and was let down. The bowl was placed on the skateboard for easy transport and a minizora button by the door opened it for Dipper’s convenience. “Happy Summerw-whoa!”

“‘Sup, squirt,” Robbie grumbled, having traded his usual broken heart hoodie for a skeleton one.

“Hey, Dipper,” Wendy greeted more warmly. Her hair was braided and she wore a tie-dye shirt and skirt, looking right out of Woodstock. “Like my costume. Mom picked it out for me.”

Dipper’s insides clenched. “Oh, heh-heh, yeah. She’s, uh, g-got good taste.”

“Wanna guess what I am?” invited Wendy. “A lazy, good-for-nothing leech on society with terrible taste in music.”

“Oh. I was going to say hippy, but I guess your way is more accurate.”

Wendy laughed. “Yeah. We just came by cuz I forgot my jacket, again,” she added in annoyance.

“What’s with the candy?” asked a resentful Robbie. “You going trick or treating or something?”

Dipper frowned. “Uh, it’s in a bowl, like the kind you give out to trick or treaters.”

“Yeah, Robbie. Of course he’s not going out trick or treating,” Wendy added after retrieving her jacket.

Dipper felt his insides clench and his pits grow sweaty. “Um, yeah. T-trick or treating is for babies,” he agreed with a nervous laugh.

“You should come to this party with us. Tambry’s parents are out of town and it’s gonna be off the chain!” Wendy deepened her voice for that last part.

“Not surprised you didn’t hear about it,” Robbie said, dropping the flyer haphazardly over Dipper.

By the time the minizora pulled himself free, the couple had left. He quickly read through all the details, pausing briefly on the provocatively posed witch stickers, and found that the party began at nine. He carried the flyer and raced out to catch up with the pair. “Hey, uh, maybe I’ll see you there.”

“Yeah, if your sister’ll let you,” Robbie grumbled, earning an elbow to the shoulder.

“It’s at nine,” Wendy called as they drove off. “Don’t forget.”

As Dipper turned back to the flyer, studying its suggestive implications and contemplating his choice, a shadow eclipsed him.

“What’s at nine?” Mabel asked innocently.

“M-Mabel!” Dipper jumped. “What are you doing here?”

Casually she scooped her brother up in her open palm, carrying the flyer along for the ride. “I couldn’t get a good shot at Robbie with Wendy in the way, but it sounded like something was going on at nine.” When Dipper seemed reluctant to answer, Mabel finally took notice of the flyer and read. “This looks like a party.” She leveled a flat stare on him. “Did you agree to go to a party?”

“Maybe!” Dipper stressed. “I said maybe. You know, maybe, after we do our trick or treating, we could swing by the party.”

Still holding her brother in her open palm, Mabel folded her arms and tapped her foot impatiently. “Dipper.”

“Sorry! I’m sorry. It’s just Wendy was there, and Robbie, and she said of course I wasn’t trick or treating, and then-mmh!”

Mabel pressed her thumb to Dipper’s mouth. He could pull away whenever he wanted, but he took the cue to shut up. The big sister sighed her disappointment and then fixed her brother with a firm look. “Trick or treating first. Party second.”

Dipper’s expression lit up. “Y-yes! Yes, of course!” He hugged Mabel’s thumb. “Thank-you-thank-you-thank-you. You’re the best sister ever!”

Mabel giggled. “Yeah, I know. Now let’s get changed. It’s gonna be a looong night.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Tricks and Treats

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Candy and Grenda arrived shortly after the teens left, dressed as a piece of candy and a weight lifting witch respectively. Mabel, dressed as an ice cream sundae with sprinkles and a chocolate syrup hat, cheerfully introduced the rest. “It’s a shame Waddles can’t come with us. I’m afraid he’s got some,” she snickered, “important meetings to attend.” On cue, the pig walked in with a little business suit hanging around his neck. The other girls laughed at how adorable he looked.

“What about your brother?” inquired Grenda, looking around.

Mabel squealed. “You guys are gonna love Dipper’s costume. It’s literally the sweetest thing ever.”

Candy scoffed. “Sweeter than me? I doubt it.”

“Wanna bet.” When the others looked around, unable to spot him, Dipper whistled to call their attention to Mabel’s head. There he climbed out from his hiding spot and stood tall, dressed as a big old cherry and striking a proud pose. “Feast your eyes, ladies.”

Candy and Grenda were not prepared for such adorableness and each suffered an explosion of estrogen. Candy grabbed at her chest, seized up, and fell backwards. Grenda, meanwhile, started moaning like a zombie and reached out for Dipper. “Must. Have. Cherry.”

“Hey, back off sister.” Mabel pushed Grenda back. “No touchy my Dippy.”

Grenda shook her head and started looking around like she’d just woken up. “Where’d I go just now?”

“Mabel, I think we might’ve gone overboard this year,” Dipper said in worry. “Twins as an ice cream sundae with a cherry on top? This is not a power man was meant to wield.” He silently congratulated himself for saying all that with a straight face.

“Help,” wheezed Candy.

“Pssh. Screw that. I’m no man, and I say we use this power to conquer Summerween and take all the candy for ourselves! Mwahahaha!”

Then there came a knock at the door.

“I got it.” Dipper got down and prepared the candy bowl while Mabel ran defense against the girls and Waddles. Upon opening the door, Dipper beheld a freakishly tall man in rags, a pointed hat, a creepy smiling mask, skin so dark it was almost purple, and a disgustingly sweet smell.

“Trick… or treat,” intoned the wheezing man ominously.

“Oh shit!” Dipper couldn’t press the door button fast enough, causing it to slam shut. For what it was worth, he even put his hands on the door to keep it closed. “Grenda, help me!”

“On it, cutie,” agreed the big girl as she helped block the door, not questioning why.

“Dipper, what’s gotten into you?”

“The Trickster, Mabel! That was the Summerween Trickster. We can’t let him in!”

The local girls all looked worried at the mention of the legend and even Candy finally got up. “The Trickster is real?”

“Everything’s real in Gravity Falls!” Dipper stressed. “How do you people not-” He was cut off by a more urgent knocking at the door. “Ahh! He’s found us! Maybe he operates on vampire rules and can’t come in unless he’s invited.”

“Dipper, calm down,” assured Mabel. “Soos said he only eats kids who lack the Summerween spirit, and look at us. We’re all in costume, minutes away from a fun night on the town, and you’re so scared you look like you might pee your cherry. How much more Summerweeny could we get?”

The others exchanged looks, slowly surrendering to Mabel’s reasoning.

“Look, just step aside and I’ll deal with it.” Mabel shooed the others aside and threw the door open wide with her biggest and happiest grin. “Hello, friend. Me and my homies were just about to have a night of fun with-”

“SILENCE!” boomed the Trickster. “You have insulted me. And for this you must pay… with your lives.”

Mabel blinked and tried shifting to a happier face. “Oh, I get it. You’re joking. Obviously we’re already at peak Summerween spirit. You’re a funny guy, Mr. Trickster.”

“Funny, am I?” the Trickster wheezed, stepping inside and voiding Dipper’s vampire theory. Then, just to prove that he was a mean spirited dick with no concern for even his own rules, the Trickster gobbled up some random kid in a pirate costume who’d just walked up. “There’s only one way for you to avoid his fate,” intoned the Trickster as he reached out with his creepy long fingers and made the children back up. “I neeed a treat. If you can collect 500 pieces of candy, and bring them to me before the last jackomellon goes out,” he produced one from his shirt, lit a flame within with his thumb, and blew it out, “I will let you live.”

“Why are you doing this?” Dipper demanded, stepping forward. “We’re in costume. We were going to trick or treat just fine on our own. What’s your deal?”

“Aside from your rudeness, which is reason enough, one of you lacks the Summerween spirit.” Through his mask he looked upon the guilty child, making their stomach sink in dread. “Though at this point, it hardly matters. You have a choice, children. You must trick or treat… or die.” He jumped high in the air, crawling like a squirrel over the roof before disappearing into the night.

“What-do-we-do!?” Grenda screamed.

“Hey guys, what’s goin’ on out here?” asked Soos. “I heard a ruckus. Haha. That’s a funny word.”

“Soos, I don’t know what we did wrong, but we pissed off the Trickster, and now he’s making us trick or treat or he’s gonna eat us,” summarized Dipper.

“I got a picture.” Candy showed Soos with her flip phone.

“Oh man, dude. You guys are in crazy bonkers trouble.”

“Wait, let’s think this through rationally,” Dipper began. “He just wants the candy, right? There’s still a bunch in the bowl. If we also get some from your parents,” he gestured between Candy and Grenda, “then that’ll give us enough of a head start to-”

*Quessh*

“Ahh!” Dipper jumped back from the impact sight.

“Dipper!” Mabel picked him up, holding him tight as they all examined what had almost squished him. “Is that… a jackomellon?”

“Looks like the Trickster’s picky about where he gets his candy from,” deduced Soos as they all looked around for where the projectile might have come from. “Sorry dudes, but you’re playing on hard mode.”

Mabel clapped to draw all eyes back on her. “Listen up, people. Now some might say that being cursed by a bloodthirsty holiday monster is a bad thing.”

“I wet myself,” affirmed Grenda.

“But that monster messed with the wrong crew. With Candy’s spirit, Grenda’s strength, Dipper’s smarts, and… Soos, we’ll get 500 pieces of candy and have fun doing it too, even if it takes us all night!” Everyone cheered as Mabel led the charge to Soos’ truck.

Dipper, however, was less enthusiastic. “All night? Are you sure?”

“Of course I’m sure. Why wouldn’t I be?” Then Mabel’s smile flipped. “You’re not seriously thinking about the party, are you?”

“What? Me? No, of course not. I mean, obviously trick or treat or die takes priority. Can’t go to the party if I’m dead,” Dipper laughed nervously and rubbed his elbow. “But, you know, if there’s time…”

Mabel waved dismissively. “Yeah, yeah, whatever. Maybe. Now let’s go!” She threw her fist up to signal the charge. “For candy!”

With the youngsters gone, Stan was left to entertain himself by scaring the piss out of any who dared approach the Shack.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Tricksters

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Out in town, kids and a handful of parents were having a night of demanding sweets from strangers. Manly Dan looked to be having a lot of fun dressed as a Viking and leading his sons into ‘battle’. Even the cops had dressed up as each other. But there was one group who were especially motivated to get them some candy.

The first house was Lazy Susan. She was dressed as a ball of yarn and covered in cats, but oblivious to the self-deprecating joke. She went down the line to make sure everyone was in costume. “Chimney sweep, elephant man, squeegee, a pile of snot,” Mabel’s eye twitched, “and… what are you supposed to be?”

Dipper frowned. “I’m a cherry. You know, like the kind that goes on an ice cream sundae.”

“And I’m the sundae. Just so we’re clear.”

“Looks more like snot with a zit to me, but whatever.” Lazy Susan then gave each of them a single piece of what they all agreed to be loser candy.

“Great. Our first house of the night is the sucky kind,” groused Mabel. She turned to the girls. “You guys live here, so you lead the way. Take us to the best houses with the best candy. I’m talking chocolate bars the size of semis.”

“Uh, Mabel, I think quantity might matter more than quality tonight,” Dipper gently reminded.

“No way, bro-say. Mabel is the co-king of Halloween, which means she settles for nothing less than the biggest and the best.”

“Oh really?” asked the Trickster. He was sitting up on a flickering street light before planting his long, spindly feet down on Soos’ shoulders. Down at their level, the creature reached into the shaking man’s bag and pulled out his single candy to scrutinize. “Hmm. I’ve seen better.” He then absconded with the candy, along with Susan’s jackomellon, hopped onto a nearby house, and blew out the candle. “Tick tock.” And once more he vanished into the night.

“Mmmaybe quantity isn’t so bad,” Mabel conceded.

So they changed up their strategy. As it turned out, folks were willing to give out more candy to single kids rather than groups. Mabel and Dipper stuck together, laying it on thick with cute dances and poses. One man even cried a single tear of joy. With Soos pushing the wheel barrel, the gang was making excellent progress. Though they did almost suffer a collective heart attack at the sight of Toby. Something about the night made his face exponentially more frightening.

Only one other house stood out as particularly interesting. It was almost completely encased in spooky decorations, meaning that they most likely had the candy to match. Mabel rang the doorbell and got into prime dancing position. But when the door opened, she tripped on her own feet. “M-Mrs. Corduroy?”

“Well hi, sugar pie,” she beamed her elation. Sheela was dressed as a sexy vampire with heavy eyeshadow, hair dyed violet, and a dress that was so form fitting it was like someone had stuck in a vacuum and sucked out all the air until it hugged every contour of her body. The front of her dress was open, showing off a heart-stopping amount of cleavage and stretching dangerously south of her navel. She squeaked in glee. “Oh, goodness! Don’t ya’ll jus’ look like the sweetest treats Ah ever did see.”

Mabel had to punch her chest to make sure she was still breathing. “Erhem. Yes. Um, thanks again for earlier.” Her eyes kept being drawn down to the lovely woman’s chest, filling the little girl with an internal turmoil she didn’t fully understand.

“Weren’t nothin’, sugar. Ah’m jus’ sorry ya had ta go through with that in the first place. Must be tough bein’ so desirable.” She shot a playful wink at Dipper and tittered when his heart restarted. Then her nose crinkled and she turned a suspicious eye on the twins. “Ya’ll didn’t happen ta cross paths with a tall smelly fella, did ya?”

“If you mean the Summerween Trickster, then yes,” Dipper blurted, unable to keep anything from this woman.

Sheela rolled her eyes and clenched her fist. “That old fogey’s still kickin’? Bleh. This is why Ah wanna start an HOA. One second, kids. Ah’ll be right back.” She turned around, swaying her bootylicious rump as she went back inside.

“You’re staring,” growled Mabel.

“Hmm? Wha?”

“Don’t you ‘wha’, me. You were totally just staring at her boobs.”

“And you weren’t?”

“… That’s not the point. Grr! What is with guys and boobs? It’s just stupid chest fat and suddenly you go totally gaga.”

“Yeah? Well at least I’m not so gaga that I missed what she said about the Trickster. Mabel, she talked like she knew him.”

“Stop trying to change the subject! Right now we’re talking about you and your stupid obsession with boobs.”

“My obsession? Mabel, I think you might be projecting a little, here.”

“No I’m not!” she stomped her foot to the ground, plucked her brother off her head and brought him up to her face in closed fingers. She held him close, squeezing to the point that it was hard to breathe, but didn’t actually hurt. In the dim, flickering lights of the jackomellons, it almost looked like her eyes were shimmering.

“Mabel…?”

Sheela cleared her throat, bringing all eyes back to her and her nonplussed expression. “Ya’ll are obviously under a lot ‘f stress right now. Ah won’t pry, but Ah can make things a bit easier.” She dropped a large sack in front of the twins. “The deal is fer 500 pieces ‘f candy, right? Well that’s 312, every piece in the house. Ah want ya’ll ta give that creeper what he wants ‘n’ try ta have a nice Summerween. Ya’ll kids deserve it. Also, when ya give ‘im the candy, tell that sugar golem Sheela Corduroy wants him out of Gravity Falls by sunup.” Her expression softened and she bent down low, somehow showing off even more cleavage. “Think ya’ll can do that fer me?” The twins nodded. “Good. Well, have a happy Summerween,” she waved goodbye before closing the door.

Dipper pointed. “See! She knows something. Quick, ring the doorbell again so we can-”

“No.”

“I’m sorry, what?”

“I said no!” Mabel grabbed the bag, huffing and stomping her way back to the street. “Why are we even bothering? This night is ruined.”

“Hey, Mabel.” Dipper patted her fingers. “Mabel, talk to me. What’s wrong?”

“You. You’re what’s wrong. First you try to ditch me to a stupid party cuz of Wendy’s boobs, Lazy Susan called me snot, then Sheela shook her big tits at you, and all night I’ve seen everyone else laughing and having fun while I’m not!”

“MABEL!” Dipper shouted with show stopping force. He quickly lowered his volume to something softer. “Mabel, you were so gung-ho about trick or treating, even with ‘die’ at the end.”

“Well I wasn’t, okay,” she sniffled, wiping her face on her sleeve. “I was just acting like people expect cuz I didn’t want to ruin everyone’s special night.”

“But… why didn’t you tell me?”

Mabel looked like she was about to answer, but then the others showed up, so she got cleaned up and put her happy face back on. In total they’d collected over 700 pieces of candy, enough to satisfy the Trickster and hopefully have plenty leftover. Dipper, however, convinced the others to give him and Mabel some space so they could keep talking. Grenda and Candy went to do a little more trick or treating, Soos went to fetch his truck, and the twins stayed back to guard the candy.

Dipper now stood in Mabel’s open palm. “Talk to me, sis. What’s the matter?”

“D-do you think Wendy’s prettier than me?”

Dipper pursed his lips. “That’s like comparing gummy candy to chocolate.”

“And which do you like more?”

“Mabel, you’re my sister. I’ve been with you since before I can even remember, and I probably loved you longer. No one is going to change that.”

“Then why were you going to ditch me for the party?”

“I wasn’t. I told you, like, the minute Wendy left.”

“Only cuz I forced you. You were totally planning on ditching me,” she accused with rising ire.

“What? No. Okay, maybe I was tempted at first, but-”

“Ah-ha! You admit it.”

“But I didn’t. I chose the both of you. Isn’t that what all of this is supposed to be about?”

Then, when tensions were at their highest, Robbie drove up with Wendy in shotgun.

“Hey Dipper. Mabel. Those are… some…” The red head went bug-eyed. “That is the most adorable thing I’ve ever seen in my life.”

Robbie was unimpressed. “You two losers aren’t going to the party like that ar-yahahow!” he cried as Wendy administered a purple nurple.

“You guys are comin’ though, right?”

Dipper looked between the two women of his life. One was biting her lip while seemingly hypnotized by something, and the other looked ready to blow her top any moment. “Uy, I’m gonna have to take a raincheck on that.” Swallowing his nerve, he added, “Mabel and I still have some heavy trick or treating to do.”

“You sure?” Wendy sounded hurt.

“Yeah, definitely.”

“Well, okay.” Wendy stopped hurting Robbie and slumped in her seat as the pair drove off.

“See, Mabel. In the end, you needed me more. Besides, there’ll be other parties. Plenty of chances to hang out with Wendy and-and I shouldn’t have said that.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Treating

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
In a fury, Mabel screamed up at the night’s sky. Then, taking the bag that Sheela had given her, she blindly swung it around and hit the wheel barrel, sending them both into the bushes.

“Mabel, what are you doing?”

“I don’t know, okay!” She dropped down, brought her knees in, and started crying. “I don’t know what’s wrong with me.”

Having hopped onto her knee, Dipper put aside all other concerns and sat down as well. The candy could wait. Summerween could wait. Wendy could wait. Right now, there was only Mabel. He touched her face and smiled softly when she looked up.

“I’m angry, Dipper,” she sniffled. “I’m angry even when I’m happy and I don’t know why. At first I thought I was okay with you going after Wendy, but now thinking about it makes me all confused.”

“Do you want me to stop?”

Mabel pulled back. “What?”

“I asked if you want me to stop. Look, Mabel, if me liking Wendy is hurting you then… then I’ll stop.”

Mabel scowled. “Dipper, you can’t just turn love off like that.”

“Well, maybe it isn’t love. Maybe it’s just a passing crush.”

“Yeah, a two-way crush. Did you seriously just miss the way she was looking at you?” Mabel demanded. “I swear, if it was just you two alone, she’d rip you right out of that cherry and start making out here and now.”

It was Dipper’s turn to flinch at this unexpected revelation. There was a lot to unpack there. “Wait, so, you’d be fine with that?”

“I… I don’t think it really matters what I think.”

“Well it matters to me.”

“But I can’t get in the way of your love life, Dipper. You and Wendy would make such a cute couple.” She sounded almost urging.

Dipper just looked thoughtful as he tried to process all this. “Then… what can I do to make you less angry? You know you’re prettier when you smile.”

Mabel buried her face back in her sleeves to hide her grin. “Shut up.”

“Make me.”

“How’d you like to spend the rest of the night shoved down my panties?”

“Eh. Seven fifty, even split.”

“That doesn’t even make any sense,” Mabel laughed.

“Yeah. I’ve been trying to learn to speak Mabel, but I can never get the accent right.”

Laughing uncontrollably, Mabel seized her brother and held him tight to her cheek. “You’re such a goofus,” she tittered. “You make me so mad, I just wanna kiss you all over.”

“Hold on. Is this regular happy, or angry happy?”

Open palm, she held Dipper out in front of her. “I’ve got the best brother in the world trying to cheer me up. I’m happy enough.”

“Good, cuz as your brother, I’m going to keep bugging you about this until we figure it out.”

Mabel giggled. “That’s all I need,” she sighed, finally feeling at peace.

“Uh, guys?” asked Grenda, startling the twins. “Not to break up this cute moment, but where’s the candy?”

“Oh, it must still be in the bushes. Come over here. I’ll show ya.” Wiping her face clean, Mabel pushed the shrubbery aside. Her gut and expression immediately dropped like stones as she watched the bag and what remained of the barrel’s candy floating down the stream. “Uh oh.”

“Mabel, what happened?”

“I, it was, um…”

“Look, the jackomelons!” Dipper deflected.

But seriously, all the lights were going out. All save one. The kids all rushed McGucket to steal his hollowed gourd, but their collective sighs of relief blew out the candle.

With only a single blinking streetlight left on, the Trickster stepped out from the dark and knocked on the air. “Knock, knock,” he wheezed, resuming his approach. “So, children. Where’s my candyyy?”

“I swear we had all 500 pieces!” Dipper pleaded. “Hell, we had 700. This nice lady-” He remembered. “Sheela Corduroy!”

The Trickster stopped. “What did you say?”

“Sh-Sheela Corduroy. She said she wanted you out of Gravity Falls by sunup.”

“Sunup, aye?” Then the Trickster started to laugh. “Mwahahaha! HA-HA-HA! Plenty of time.” The monster grew tall. It’s back swelled out of his shirt until an extra pair of arms burst out. Now more than twice its original size, the Trickster snatched up all four children and wheezed its terrible, sickly laugh.

Then Soos drove up in his truck, hitting the Trickster and smashing it to bits. When everyone was satisfied that they weren’t hurt, the kids all ran up to the very anxious hero of the hour. “That wasn’t, like, a regular pedestrian, was it?”

“No, Soos. That was the Trickster. And you saved us.”

“By killing it,” Mabel added. “You killed it to death!”

Everyone loaded up on the truck and they departed for somewhere to rest for the evening, not noticing how the chunks of monster moved across the ground and fused back together. In no time the Trickster had regained his full mass, now with a body like an eggplant with stick arms and a narrow head. The only bit of clothing he had left was his mask and he hissed as his instincts told him exactly where his prey was. But before he could resume his chase, he felt a presence. He turned to see a woman, lavishly dressed, and carrying a glass of what looked like wine in one hand.

“Ah wouldn’t do that if Ah was you, honey bun.”

“Sh-Sheela?” the Trickster said in alarm.

“Howdy there, Tricky,” she greeted with a friendly wave. “Fancy seein’ ya’ll here, in mah town.”

“Hey, this is Summerween. For this one night, all of Gravity Falls is my turf.”

“Mighty tall claim.” She took a sip of her drink. “Think ya can back it up?”

For a while, nothing happened. A standoff was in play between the voluptuous Sheela Corduroy, and the grotesque Summerween Trickster. Then the silence was broken.

“Filthy sugar golem,” Sheela spat, swirling her drink. “All the little feelings of disgust as kids threw away their unwanted candy, all added up to one hideous waste of space. Your whole existence is a bad joke.”

“Perhaps,” allowed the Trickster. “But tonight, it’s a joke on everyone’s lips. That belief gives me power; power enough to trounce the likes of you, witch.” He shook his fist at her.

“This is mah final warning, Tricky. Leave Gravity Falls ‘n’ never come back. Cuz if Ah catch you after the sun rises, well, you know what’ll happen.”

“Oh, very well. I’ll leave. This town was getting too small for me, anyway. Think I’ll go restart my legend elsewhere. However, I still have one last curse to cast.”

“You leave those kids alone!” Sheela stomped her foot down, leaving a small dent in the gravel. “Or Ah swear Ah’ll hunt you down for the remainder of yer short existence!”

The Trickster just laughed. “Try me.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Truth

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
“So, that was some pretty heavy stuff back there,” Grenda said from the backseat, staring straight at the twins. “Is, uh, everything alright?”

“Yes. I hope everyone is feeling okay now that the danger has passed.” As Candy finished speaking, everyone but her face palmed. “What?”

“You jinxed it,” Grenda answered. “Bad Candy. Bad.”

“Uh, dudes,” Soos said, checking the rearview mirror.

The monster was back in pursuit. It hobbled a little, almost like it had a limp, but it was still faster than any motor vehicle. The Trickster leapt into the air and jumped down on the truck, denting the roof as it maneuvered to block the front. Soos managed to swerve and knock it into a lamppost, breaking it. However, he lost control and drove straight into the store from earlier. Everyone hid as the monster followed after them and began its search.

“Okay, I was trying to be delicate before, but this is serious,” Grenda whisper hissed. “Mabel, did something happen to you?”

Candy narrowed her eyes on the minizora, though her words were directed at Mabel. “I hope no one was stupid enough to hurt you.”

“Guys, this is seriously not a good time,” Dipper stressed.

“No, this needs to be said,” Mabel relented. “Guys, I’m sorry for how I acted tonight. I’ve been kind of moody for a while. I know it’s no excuse, but I want you to understand that… that when the Trickster said one of us didn’t have the Summerween spirit, I’m pretty sure he meant me. I understand if you guys don’t want to hang out with me anymore after this.”

Candy adjusted her glasses. “No offense, Mabel, but you are quite stupid.”

“Say what now?”

“Yeah. The whole point of being friends is to stick together through the hard times. We’ve been trick or treating together all night, and you think we’d abandon you now? Honestly, I’m insulted.”

Mabel sniffled, fighting a losing battle against her tears. “You guys!”

“Hey, I just thought of something.” Dipper tapped his foot to Mabel’s neck. “If this thing can sense spirit, how come he hasn’t found us yet?”

“I don’t know, dude. Looks to me like he ain’t walkin’ straight.” As Soos spoke, the Trickster tripped on its own feet and knocked over a display. “Maybe he hit his head and now there’s a screw loose.”

“Probably the truck,” reasoned Dipper.

Unable to find its prey, the Trickster roared.

“We have to escape.”

“What if it sees us?”

“If only there was something we could use to cover our bodies and faces with. You know, like a disguise,” suggested Soos. However, while everyone was in awe and waited for the mic to drop, Soos disappointingly proved to be just as oblivious as he sounded.

The children and man-child did manage to find alternate costumes to resemble inanimate decorations. Following video game logic, they moved only when the Trickster had its back turned and froze when it looked their way. It was working and they almost made it out. Unfortunately, just when it looked like they were home free, Soos soosed up by tapping a singing skeleton head. The Trickster appeared behind him, opened its enormously grotesque mouth, and swallowed the big guy in one gulp.

Mabel let out an unearthly shriek and charged in a blind rage towards the monster. After the night she’d had so far, she was in no mood to lose anyone. While she scurried around its arms, breaking them with her bare hands while they kept reforming, the others armed. Whatever those fake Medieval weapons were made of, they were definitely not child friendly as the kids hacked away. Dipper, remembering the Multibear, had Candy throw him approximately where the monster’s groin was in the hopes of hitting the weak point. However, as he trudged through the gooey stickiness, something became apparent.

Mabel spat after biting through the Trickster’s elbow. “Bleh! Saltwater taffy?”

Dipper tripped and face planted on the monster’s flesh. “Candy corn?”

“You really haven’t figured it out yet?” Having recovered from the surprise attack, the Trickster once more grabbed up all the kids. Candy, Grenda, and Dipper had to share one hand since two were needed to restrain both Mabel’s body and mouth. The last hand removed the Trickster’s mask. “Don’t you recognize me? Look at my face. Look… closely.”

Everyone gasped. “Loser candy.”

The Trickster was made up entirely of unpopular candy. Like any good villain, with the heroes unable to escape, he exposited his backstory. He was made up of all the candy the kids of Gravity Falls ever threw away, so now he seeks revenge for their pickiness. “No one would eat me, so now I’m going to eat you.” Then he started to scream and writhe in agony. Something was moving deep in his gut.

Soos burst forth, squealing like a mad pig as he held a large pulsing clump of candy. He pushed it out further, severing the strands that connected it to the main body. As a result, the Trickster fell over, spewing sugary gore as he dropped the children. Soos, meanwhile, sat atop his fallen enemy and casually ate his internal organs. “Dudes, you want some of this?” he asked with a level of casualness that frightened the other kids.

“Wait,” wheezed the Trickster. “You think I taste… good?”

“Yeah. Sure.”

“All I ever wanted was for someone to say that I was… good.” Crying candy tears of joy, the Trickster stopped fighting and finally passed away.

Also the other kid emerged from the corpse, having somehow remained inside and unharmed even after the truck impact. Soos’ truck was still in reasonable order, so they all took it and left, calling it a night. Back at the Shack, everyone found Stan looking very pleased with himself for scaring some trick or treaters, along with a certain someone carving a jackomellon in the corner.

“Hey guys.”

“Wendy,” Dipper greeted excitedly, only to pause and check with Mabel. She smiled appreciatively of his consideration and carried him over. “How was the party?”

“Ugh. Lame. The highlight was Robbie eating a lollipop stick first and needing to go to the hospital. Honestly, I think I would’ve had more fun trick or treating with you guys.” She sighed wistfully. “I miss those days.”

“Yeah, we could have used your help,” Mabel said.

“We fought the Summerween Trickster!” Grenda cheered.

Candy straightened her glasses. “It was a harrowing and stressful ordeal, but we have emerged stronger for it.”

Wendy blinked and looked at Dipper. “Seriously?”

“We’re never going to throw away unwanted candy ever again,” he avowed. “From now on, we’re throwing it into the fire so it can’t come back and get us later. Also Soos ate him from the inside out.”

Wendy turned to Soos who was smacking his lips from an apparently delicious aftertaste. “Why do you guys get all the fun?”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Trickster Trounced

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Manly Dan was a mighty proud father. His children had claimed a mighty haul of treasure this year. So much so that they were having a hard time carrying it all, which was probably the best kind of problem one could have. They didn’t complain, though. They’d seen that one group with the wheel barrel, but not one mentioned regret at not bringing one themselves. This made Dan proud. Hard work, he’d taught them, was its own reward. The candy was just a bonus. They’d learned this lesson well and it almost moved him to manly tears.

“Hey, dad,” said Gus, the youngest of his sons. “What’s that?”

“Looks like some kind of speedbump, but really weirdly shaped,” added Kevin, the middle son.

“I don’t think they’d do construction tonight. Maybe it fell off a truck,” reasoned eldest son Marcus.

Manly Dan, after his eyes adjusted to the dim light, recognized the voluptuous shape and his face went pale. “Uh, kids, lets hurry home.” He started pushing them away from the scene. “You’ll need to sort out your candy so it’ll last a few weeks. Remember to share,” he added, finally getting them to their front door. Luckily it was unlocked.

“Aren’t you gonna help us, dad?” asked Gus.

“Not right now, my sons. Dad, uh, needs to…”

Kevin pushed the door open and noticed the absence of a constrictive hug threatening to suffocate him in soft, womanly flesh. “And where’s mom?”

“Dad has to go find mom,” Dan answered honestly enough. “She probably saw Wendy’s new boyfriend and has him pinned up a tree somewhere.”

The boys laughed, accepting the plausibility of this explanation without question and headed inside. Once the door was shut, Dan sprinted over to the scene of the incident. The gravel road was a mess with chunks of debris torn up and scattered all over the place. At the epicenter, in a modest crater, was the back of a woman. Her front half was submerged in the ground. Her formfitting dress had been torn to shreds, barely containing her curvaceous figure. In fact, it was that rounded booty that Dan recognized as his wife’s.

“Honey, can you hear me?” Dan boomed.

Recognizing his voice, Sheela started twitching and making sounds. Unfortunately, the road muffled her voice and she was wedged in too deep to get any leverage to pull herself out.

“Don’t worry, honey. I got ya!” Dan stabbed his fingers to either side of his wife’s waist, wrapped them around her child bearing hips, and carefully extricated her from the ground. Chunks of rock fell all around her as she coughed and sputtered. The front of her dress was even worse than the back and something the kids were not ready to see. Though to be fair, no kid was ever ready to see their mom in such a state. Cradling his wife bridal style, he tapped on her cheek. “Speak to me, honey.”

Sheela groaned. “Ah’m in tremendous pain.”

“I see that.” Dan looked her up and down, already imagining all the terrible things he would do to whoever did this to his beloved. “What happened?”

Sheela coughed and spat out some gravel mixed with blood. “It was… Tricky.”

“The Trickster?” Dan said in alarm. “I thought you took care of that monster already.”

“Ah did, too,” Sheela groaned. She curled up against her husband’s chest, finding comfort in his warm muscles. “Ah might be gone for a few months. You understand.”

“I do,” Dan grimly agreed, knowing full well what had happened and what his wife was honor bound to do. It was a tragic thing, but justice needed to be served. “Who was it?”

Sheela pressed herself tighter into her husband. “Wendy’s friends. The Pines twins.”

“Pines? The tiny boy and his demon attack dog?”

Sheela looked up, confused by her husband’s tone. “Yes. Why?”

“I just saw them not a few minutes ago. They were driving with that chipmunk guy from the Mystery Shack. Pretty sure I heard them laughing.”

“A few minutes?” Sheela’s eyes darted around as she processed this. “Ah was down there for a good half hour, at least.” Her expression of embittered sorrow quickly morphed to one of joy. “So then… they survived! Ye-haw!” With new energy she jumped up and wrapped her arms around Dan’s neck, peppering his face with kisses. She then regretted her emotional outburst. “Yikes! Ow, ow, ow,” she winced while slipping back to her more relaxed position. “This can only mean… they beat ‘im,” she giggled.

“Those kids and the fat guy beat the Trickster?” Dan asked, barely able to believe it. Then he looked down at the woman in his arms and smiled. “Let me guess. You softened him up for ‘em.”

“Even if I did, that’s still a hell of a thing,” Sheela intoned. “Ah knew there was somethin’ Ah liked about those kids. Looks like they’ve got a lot more goin’ for ‘em than jus’ bein’ cute,” she giggled, looking around. “The boys?”

“At home sorting candy. I told ‘em you were giving Wendy’s new boyfriend a rough time.”

Sheela smiled contentedly at her husband’s reliable and rugged face. “You always know just what to say.” She lifted her head and puckered up, but didn’t make it too far before Dan met her half way. The kiss wasn’t terribly long, but it was enough to quiet her aches enough that it no longer hurt to breathe.

Manly Dan snickered and motioned down past his wife to the road. “That’s some mark you left.”

Sheela had to bite her lip to keep from bursting out in laughter. Down in the ground, in the middle of the crater, was a near perfect impression of her luscious body. Her face was a little obscure, but her tits were clear as day.

“Be a shame to lose such a lovely work of art,” Dan said, having never given a single dam about art in his life (except for the drawings his kids made). “After I chuck you through the window so the kids don’t have to see, want me to come back, dig it out, and hang it on the wall?”

Sheela slammed her face into her husband’s plastic chest piece, denting it as her muffled laughs reverberated through his body. When she’d finally gotten control of herself, she pulled her face out and wiped away the tears. “You know we can’t do that. What would the neighbors think?”

“Yeah, I know,” Dan conceded.

“Obviously we’re keeping it in the secret basement.”

“I love you.” Dan didn’t give his wife a chance to reply before encompassing her lips with his own. He walked her back to their home, carrying her just as he’d done on their wedding day. And, just like their wedding day, he made good on his word by hurling her like a javelin through the window, where she landed perfectly on the bed. Manly Dan knew his wife, and knew that she liked it rough.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Summerween Cleanup

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The hot shower felt amazing as the water droplets cascaded down Mabel’s body. “It’s like I’m being bombarded by a thousand tiny Dipper hands all giving me a massage,” she breathlessly thought aloud.

“Is that a request? Because it sounded like a request.” Dipper was in Mabel’s hand, fingers closed so that he didn’t get knocked down. It was currently his turn with the washcloth, which he was using to get under his pits from a long night of fear sweating.

“Yes, please.” Mabel took the cloth from Dipper and pressed his body to her chest. Her hand was gentle yet firm as she rubbed him against her sensitive chest. She moaned as his expert little hands got to work in kneading her skin in the way he knew she liked. However, she was so caught up in the sensation that she didn’t give him much time to focus on an area before moving him around. He was like one of those handheld massage machines and she was just too impatient to feel him everywhere that she needed attention.

Dipper was only slightly annoyed at not being able to give each area its due focus as he would have liked. However, if this was what Mabel needed, then he would comply. Instead of deep presses, he switched to a lighter touch, trying to match the movement of her hands to ensure maximum skin contact. Her fair skin was smooth against his own and his erection was quickly triggered, which just made Mabel moan all the louder. Even so, as lovely as this moment was, Dipper still felt the need to address the elephant in the room.

“Are you ready to talk?”

Mabel’s movements slowed, but they didn’t stop as she ran Dipper through a tour across her chest and belly. “I don’t want you to ever leave me, Dipper, but everyone says you have to.”

“Who’s everyone?”

“Our therapist, mom and dad, and now Stan. They say we need to be our own people and that we can’t do that if we don’t start getting some distance.”

Dipper sighed, having heard the same arguments. They all made sense and were coming from a place of genuine concern. “I don’t think making distance means being apart. Mom and dad do a bunch of different stuff. He likes bowling and she likes knitting. They also have different jobs, but they always come back to each other at the end of the day.”

Mabel stopped using her brother as a soap bar and held him out to see her smile. “But can we have that? If we each get married, are we gonna live in some kind of duplex? Will our spouses be okay with us sharing each other?”

This was the fantasy the twins had always shared. Marrying each other had never really been on the table. For as much as they loved one another, there was always the understanding that their hearts yearned for that little bit extra, those lovers who were just lovers and not also siblings. It made perfect sense to them. They thought of themselves more like siblings with benefits. Their therapist had struggled to understand, but their parents were far more accepting. The pair had never showed the serious affection they shared in public, but neither did they really try hiding it. What they had was more of an open secret. Dipper was a minizora and people just had certain assumptions for how he was and should be treated. Thanks in part to old customs and popular media, most folks just assumed that Dipper was Mabel’s sex toy, a plaything that she kept on her for convenience, rather than a person.

“What would you do with Wendy?” Mabel asked after Dipper took too long. “Let’s say you got the balls to finally confess and she was into it. What would you do?”

Dipper shot her a playful smirk. “With or without you watching?”

“With. Doy.”

Dipper sat back in Mabel’s cupped palm and started stroking himself while she watched. “I’d be a gentleman and start with a kiss.”

“A full body kiss?” Mabel asked, turning off the shower and carrying him to be dried off.

“No. It’d start small. My lips on hers and hers over my head,” Dipper chuckled. “Then maybe she’d bring out her tongue.”

“What about her boobs?” Mabel asked. “Don’t you want her to stick you in her chest? Maybe squish you around like they do on TV?”

Dipper winced, worried that this may still be a sore subject.

“I’d be okay with it,” Mabel assured as she toweled off, careful not to jostle Dipper. “If I was there watching, it means she’s accepted you, including the part that’s mine,” she giggled, set the towel aside, and touched her free hand to her chest. “I’d want to see it. I’d want to see you totally at her mercy as she squishes you around, and I’d want her to describe it. How does his squirming feel?”

“Only one way to find out.” Dipper beckoned Mabel down. “You’ll have to taste. Come on. I’m on her boobs. They’re so big and soft, but also sensitive like yours. It feels just as good for her when I move around, so maybe you can help. C’mon Mabel, help a guy out.”

Lost in the fantasy, Mabel licked her lips and dropped her mouth down onto her palm. Dipper’s taste was distinct, but she imagined her hand as something else. It was Wendy’s boob flesh, warm and probably salty from sweat. Mabel made multiple ‘nom’ sounds as she licked, forcing Dipper back instead of pulling him in. “So… big!”

“Yeah,” Dipper strained to say as the oral muscle had its way with him. Based on her going for a wide area instead of concentrating on his underwear region, the minizora had a good idea of what she was imagining. “Big and soft?”

“Big as my fist,” Mabel cooed as the imagined taste rippled across her sensitive taste buds, almost eclipsing the sharp implement stabbing into her organ. “I want my whole mouth around it.” Her maw engulfed her whole palm, finally pulling Dipper in and submitting him to a proper tongue bathing. “Nnngh! So good,” she said around her mouthful. Then, surprising herself, she sat on the bed and spat out her tiny morsel before finishing him.

“Wh-why’d you do that?” Dipper answered tiredly, a big goofy grin on his lips.

“We’re sharing, remember,” Mabel cooed. “If you’re gonna be hers, then you’ve got to seal the deal and make her yours, too.”

“Put me there,” Dipper demanded. “With your mouth. I want you to put me there and your tongue to push me in. I want to hear her moan all around me, but I want to hear you, too. Your hands can be wherever, but I want us all to get off together. I want us to cum, me and her, but I want you to taste it. I want to come gushing out of her and into your mouth.” His hand found its way to his cock. “Then… then I want you two to clean me off together.”

“That’s so gross,” Mabel giggled breathlessly, her other hand where Dipper couldn’t see. Her fingers were probing deep while also paying special attention to her little nub. She imagined another Dipper down there, stirring her up, but there was also Wendy to take care of. “You want me to make out with another girl while her juices are in my mouth?”

Dipper arched his back as he pumped away at his slickened member. “I want all three of us to make out. I want your tongues all around me, holding me. And I want you to t-touch each other. Grab her boobs while she grabs your butt, or whatever. I just want us all in the moment!”

Unable to take it anymore, Mabel slapped her hand to her lips and brought Dipper back in. Her tongue fought with his hand for control of his prick. Somehow he tasted even better than usual, possibly still mixed with the imaginary flavors. Mabel stuck two fingers in her mouth and suckled like they were another tongue, the tongue of another girl that she was making out with. Finally it all became too much for the both of them. Dipper released his delicious seed upon her tongue, pushing her over the edge as she made a mess on her fingers. Luckily she’d had the foresight to sit on the towel beforehand.

Mabel collapsed against the sheets, naked and breathless. Her brother was allowed to ooze his way out, dropping with a wet plop beside her. She smiled at his naked butt. “That would be the best.”

“Yeah, it would.” Dipper flipped himself over and stared up at the happy giantess. “Still want to make it happen?”

“Definitely.”
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Summerween Aftermath

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The family was down in the living room veg’ing out in front of the TV for Cash Shower, Stan’s favorite show. Mabel was enjoying some chip flavored crackers, dividing her attention between feeding herself, her pet pig, and her pet brother on her shoulder. Stan started really laughing when one of the show’s contestants got violent.

Then Soos hurried in and alerted them to a bus full of suckers-er-tourists. Stan got dressed with lightning speed and ordered everyone to get to work. Soos was instructed to make some new attractions out of their spare taxonomy animal parts and glue. Wendy had the arduous task of marking up the prices so high that she had no sympathy for whatever idiot actually bought the things. And while Mabel got to use her winning smile to welcome guests, Dipper got the ‘privilege’ of cleaning up fresh puke on the front lawn with his specialized cleaning gear. It was a bot that piloted like construction equipment with mechanical arms.

“Grunkle Stan, I’ve been meaning to ask something.”

“Well hurry it up, kid. I’ve got customers to bleed dry.”

“This place is probably the most minizora friendly I’ve ever been in, including my house. Did you really set all this stuff up just for me?”

For just a second, Stan froze, but then he recalled his plan. “Don’t think too highly of yourself, kid. All this stuff was set up years before you came along.”

“But… why?”

“Tax credits, obviously. You have any idea what kind of deals the bleeding hearts of this state are offering for guys like me to make things minizora friendly? It’d be a crime not to exploit it. That’s why I’m glad you’re here to finally put this stuff to use.”

“Really?”

“Sure. It was just gathering dust before. Now it won’t break down from lack of use. You’re saving me a lot of money, kid. Now,” he clapped, “chop-chop.”

Dipper sighed and went on his way, driving the specialized Roomba to do his ‘duty’. Stan’s explanation made sense, especially for Stan. However, Dipper couldn’t shake the feeling that there was still something a little off. Normally Stan would have gone for the cheapest products to do the job, but everything Dipper had used so far seemed like top quality and to have been moderately used before. The tax thing, as Dipper understood it, should have only barely covered the cost of buying and setting everything up, which was why so few businesses bothered. It would make sense if Stan pulled some other con on the tax people to make them pay more. It certainly worked on the tourists. But there was still something off about the whole thing that Dipper couldn’t quite put his finger on.

Throughout the day, it was mostly business as usual. Dressed in his standard suit, fez, and fake eyepatch, Stand guided the tourists through the Shack and never ran out of embellishments to keep them entertained. He even put Dipper on display as an extra special attraction: the tiny wolf boy!

Standing behind the velvet rope, shirtless and dressed in itchy fur pants, wolf ears, and fake teeth (seriously, Soos’ craftsmanship was amazing), Dipper was forced to endure strangers gawking at him like he was even more of a freak than usual. Taking the teeth out, he said, “Grunkle Stan, this is demeaning.”

“What? I don’t know… d’meaning of the word,” joked the old man. Even the audience laughed as though they hadn’t just seen the fakeness of the exhibit. “If you throw money at him, he dances.”

Then, just as everyone was about to pummel the tiny boy with their spare change, the rug was literally pulled out from under them. Everyone fell and hurt themselves, but they also threw their money all at once. Stan looked pleased, even as he shrugged apologetically at the bemused little girl by the rug.

Mabel returned to her post in the gift shop and helped Wendy by pushing additional sales. The taller twin was good at smiling and putting people in a good mood. However, between customers, she found herself staring at the red head like she’d never done before. Wendy was pretty. That much was obvious. She had a laidback charm and a pretty nice laugh. And after learning the story of what she’d gone through in grade school, Mabel felt a new kind of kinship with a fellow protector. It was easy to see why Dipper would fall for a girl like this.

The thing was, however, that Mabel’s thoughts weren’t entirely innocent. She’d caught sight of Wendy’s bra from time to time, which only happened because she was already staring at the other girl’s chest. Wendy’s breasts weren’t as big as Mabel fantasized that one time, but they were still impressive for her age. Certainly she’d be capable of carrying Dipper in them. Dipper would look so cute in there, living out the dreams of every boy his age by touching some boob.

But what would happen after? When Wendy left for the day, logically she’d hand Dipper back to his sister. But would that sister be able to resist sniffing where her brother had been? Probably not. Also, why should Dipper be the only one who got to touch them? Also-also, he was her brother. Why should he be the only one with touching privileges? Surely it’d only be fair if she got to put Dipper between those freckled melons now and then, right? It wouldn’t be weird or anything if she copped a feel on the way out, right?

Then, upon scratching an itch on her chest, Mabel froze. It was a good thing she was wearing a sweater, otherwise her ‘headlights’ would be showing. Luckily, Stan was there to calm her down… with harsh criticism. He was upset with her for giving away some of the cheaper items, arguing that this wasn’t how business was conducted.

“You’re back to greeter duty. Now shut yer yap and get out the door.”

But Mabel resisted his pushing. “Grunkle Stan, whatever happened to please and thank you, hmm?” She then planted stickers on his face just because she could.

“Ugh. ‘Please’ never made me any money. In fact, just saying the word makes me ill.”

“Grunkle Stan, why do I have to wear this wolf costume?” asked Dipper after bailing on the display. “You have all these fake exhibits, but I’ve seen actual amazing things out in the forest. What if you got a real attraction instead of lying to people for a living?”

“And you should be nicer to your employees, too,” agreed Mabel.

Over the day, Stan continued to get on everyone’s nerves until Mabel finally had enough. They couldn’t agree on Stan’s management practices, so a bet was made. Stan would go on vacation for 72 hours while Mabel ran the Shack. Whoever made more money would run the Shack for the rest of the summer, and also had to perform a humiliating dance.

Dipper was understandably skeptical about making a deal with a professional con man, but Mabel was her usual confident self. After all, how much money could Stan actually make on vacation? It wasn’t like the studio that filmed his favorite game show was just up the road… right?
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Dealing the Dealer

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Once the taller twin presented herself wearing Stan’s fez and a business suit with shoulder pads, and after Soos had calmed down from his panic attack, Mabel told everyone the arrangement. She’d binge read a book on outdated but seemingly friendly managerial practices. The plan was to make the work space more friendly for the workers, improving morale and motivating them to increase profits. To that end she agreed to let Wendy have friends over for work, gave Soos his Questiony the Questionmark costume, and instructed Dipper to go out and get a real attraction after pocketing his wolf costume… for later. And to make sure she had her bases covered, Mabel called her friends over with the promise of a less life-threatening adventure if they helped Dipper, for which they were thrilled.

Grenda and Candy were stoked. It wasn’t everyday they got to go monster hunting in the woods, or be entrusted with such a cute boy. To keep things fair, they flipped a coin and Dipper would spend the first half of the journey on Candy’s shoulder.

“This is stupendous,” cheered the Korean girl in her adorably fragmented accent. “I’m so happy Mabel is trusting us to look after you.”

“Yeah, me to,” agreed Dipper.

“She’s feeling better, right?” Grenda pressed.

“I think so. We had a talk and now she’s in a much better head space.”

Candy adjusted her glasses. “That is good. So, what kind of critter are we going to catch? Something warm and fuzzy?”

“Or something big and cuddly?” Grenda boomed.

Dipper flipped through the journal. “Hmm. Maybe both. It says here that the gremloblin has a nest near here. It’s pretty big, but if we can blindfold it, that should keep it passive enough to transport. Got the wagon and gear?”

Grenda saluted, pulling a wagon full of weapons taken from the Shack. “Check.”

“Caramel sweets to lure it into the trap?”

“Double check,” Candy saluted.

“Then onwards to victory!”

***

Back at the Shack, Mabel had just finished the all-important task of putting up stickers and motivational posters to keep spirits high. So far, things were turning out good. The first round of customers were all satisfied and showed their appreciation with plenty of money. Soos, however, wasn’t so sure. His Questiony costume was more revealing than he expected. In his underwear, he was basically showing about as much skin as if he wore a bikini. Fortunately, Mabel’s boundless optimism managed to encourage him to press on.

“Mabel, we caught something!” Dipper called from Grenda’s shoulder.

“That’s great, you guys. But,” she looked them over, “what happened?”

Grenda looked to have been roughed up pretty bad, but she still hauled the large sack behind her with a spring in her step. Beside her, Candy carried the wagon with the gear, most of which looked like it had been chewed on, along with her shirt. Dipper’s smile seemed like the most forced with his clothes in shambles and smelling like he’d rolled around in feces.

“The blindfold came loose, and our new pet got a little feisty,” Candy explained calmly. “Luckily, Dipper managed to-”

“The point is we got it!” he cut her off. “We’re just gonna set this guy up, and maybe wash up afterwards.”

“Together?” Grenda asked eagerly, earning a sprits from a water bottle to the face. “Okay, sheesh. I was just asking.”

“If you spray her, then you must spray me too, for I thought the same,” Candy added somberly, also earning a refreshing spray to the face. “That feels much better. Thank you.”

“Happy to help,” Mabel replied, stowing the sprayer back in her suit pocket for later use.

The last stop on the new boss’ tour was Wendy. The counter girl had brought her friends over, but they were making quite the mess of the gift shop. Discarded cans and food wrappers were everywhere and the guys were tossing the merchandise around while Tambry filmed it all. A severed head went wild and hit a kid in the face, making him cry and forcing Mabel to apologize with a refund.

“Hey guys, maybe we should be a bit more careful,” Wendy said to her friends.

Robbie scoffed. “Why bother?”

“I told you, already. If Mabel can make more money than Stan, then you guys can visit every day.” They cheered. “But that means the Shack still needs to be standing, so no more catch.”

Mabel beamed. “Excellently said, valued employee. Now, could you please clean this mess up?”

“Whoa. All this rule stuff is starting to make you sound like Stan,” Wendy warned.

“What!? No, I’m nothing like Stan.”

“Haha. I’m kidding. Hey guys, clean up after yourselves, will ya.”

The guys, however, seemed reluctant.

“So where’s that brother of yours?” asked Tambry. “Think he wouldn’t mind posing for a selfie?”

“Dipper is busy getting our new monster attraction set up.” Mabel had a light bulb moment. “Clean up, and you guys can see it for free.”

As everyone begrudgingly got to work getting the gift shop to a minimum state of cleanliness, Wendy extended a fist for Mabel to bump. “Nice going, boss.”

Now that the monster hunters didn’t look so disheveled, they were ready to present. “Ladies and gentlemen,” Dipper announced while being held high on the palms of Candy and Grenda’s hands. His audience was a couple of tourists and Wendy’s friends. “My name is Honest Dipper, and unlike my cheating uncle, I have something to show you that isn’t a hoax. It nearly killed us getting it into this cage,” he gestured to the tarp. “Part gremlin. Part goblin. I give you,” he gave the signal and all three kids pulled the tarp down, “the gremloblin!”

The beast was two or three times the size of Soos, only proportioned more like Grenda with extra thick arms. Its face was apelike with gray skin, patches of dark fur, a sickly yellow underbelly, and a blindfold. It sat in the corner of the cage, not doing much other than snoring. It did pick through its teeth and casually flick out some rather large bones.

“Well that’s fun,” said one tourist.

“It’s fake, honey. You can see the strings,” said the wife.

“Strings? That’s body hair,” asserted Dipper, incensed that the hard work of capturing this thing was being so callously dismissed.

Then, when the tourists got caught up with another exhibit, Candy ran out to block them. “Are you nuts? This thing is real. You can see it breathing.”

“See it? You can feel it.” Grenda put her hand in front of the beast’s face. “Smell it, too.”

“Yeah. Everything else here is fake. This is a real paranormal beast,” Dipper added. “Fun fact about this guy. If you look into his eyes, you can see your worst nightmare.”

“Oh yeah? That’s something I’d like to see,” Robbie boasted, reaching into the cage.

“No, stop!”

But it was too late. With the blindfold removed, the creature resumed its active state and intently stared at everyone, turning everyone into a jabbering mess. The only survivors were the kids with the good sense to look away, and Tambry who was watching the creature through her phone. The paramedics were called and all those too traumatized to move were taken to the hospital.

“Thanks for visiting,” Dipper strained to say as he waved goodbye.

Wendy ran up. “Dude, what happened?”

“Dipper said the creature had nightmares in his eyes,” Candy said. “Then the emo one took off the blindfold.”

“Dammit, Robbie!” Wendy called after the ambulance. “Wait, what about Tambry?”

“The phone girl’s still on her phone,” answered Grenda. “She only saw the eyes through her screen, but she’s still pretty shook up, so we left her in the corner to watch cat videos to calm down.”

“It’s okay, guys,” Mabel assured. “We’ve had a couple hiccups, but we can still prove Stan wrong. Putting employees first is the best idea. Maybe… get a red rope so no one can touch the monster, and also no more playing in the store.”

Miraculously, the promise of proving Stan wrong was enough of a motivation to get everyone back to work. Wendy got back to the gift shop and pulled Tambry behind the counter with her. Every now and then she’d check on her jabbering friend as she handled purchases. Candy and Grenda took Mabel’s old job of handling customers out on the floor with smiles and cuteness. Unfortunately, this bunch of tourists proved a lot harder to please than usual. Dipper tried his hand at giving tours with Soos as his valet, but the Questiony costume kept putting people off. Worse, somehow it had gotten around that the Shack had a new refund policy, which the tourists were all too happy to exploit and Mabel was too committed to being friendly to resist.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Under New Management

choices: The Shack is Fixed in Time (Reserved)
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
For a while, it looked like everything was getting better. The team had hit a speedbump, or six, but now everyone was getting into the new rhythm.

“Wow. Look at everyone pulling together for a common goal,” Mabel marveled.

Dipper sat on her shoulder and smiled. “I know, right. Can you imagine how quick this place would fall apart if it was just the two of us?”

“Hehe. Yeah. Hey, I just thought of something. What if we’d gotten Candy and Grenda to help us back at the fair, you know, with the time tape?”

“What do you mean?”

“Well, if we’d invited them along, they could have helped you with Wendy and Robbie and I could’ve won Waddles all on my own. Everyone would win.”

Dipper stared blankly off into space, unresponsive even as Mabel snapped her fingers in front of him. All of that hardship, emotional turmoil, and even Blendin’s misfortune could have been avoided if they’d just gone back a few hours earlier and gotten Candy and Grenda to help. A single tear ran down Dipper’s cheek.

“What was that about Robbie?” Wendy asked.

“Oh, I guess we didn’t tell you in this timeline. You see-hrrgh!” Mabel’s explanation was blocked by Dipper hurling himself into her mouth. Luckily, Wendy was too distracted with customers to see.

“Look, I’m sorry again about him. I don’t know why he does these things. It’s like he’s got the impulse control of-of… of something that doesn’t think before doing stupid stuff.” She angrily rang the purchase and growled, “Thank you! Have a nice day!”

Mabel, devious little devil, spat out her brother and took her chance. “What do you see in that guy, anyway?”

“Eh. I don’t know. He used to be a lot more chillax, ya know. But for the last few months it’s like he’s gotten really insecure about stuff. Maybe he thinks he’s got to prove himself with stupid stunts. When Thompson does it its funny, but Robbie…” She gave a forlorn sigh.

Then, before Dipper could say anything stupid, Mabel pinched her thumb over his mouth. “Actually, while we’re on the subject…”

Dipper gave a muffled scream as he fought to free himself.

“I was wondering if you-”

Suddenly the wall separating the exhibit hall and gift shop was knocked down as the gremloblin stormed in. It gave a thunderous roar that sent the tourists fleeing with soiled britches. The workers had sense enough to take cover behind the counter.

“How did that thing get out!?” demanded Wendy in a panic.

Dipper face palmed. “The cage. We got it from Stan’s stash. I’ll bet he got it used or something. It doesn’t matter now. We’ve gotta round it up. Where’s Soos?”

“He was looking stressed out, so I told him to take a soothing nature walk,” Mabel said apologetically. “Why can’t you just catch it again?”

“That was when we caught it sleeping, and even that was mostly luck. Now the thing’s fully active and pissed off.”

“Hey, it’s the mystery man,” giggled Tambry, speaking for the first time in hours. Everyone gathered around her phone to see that she was watching a live broadcast from Cash Shower. Stan was there, apparently poised to be the grand winner. When asked, he said he was looking forward to returning to his family, followed by laughing menacingly.

“Well guys, it was fun while it lasted,” said Wendy, resigned to their doom. Then there came a crash and she suddenly felt like living again. When the creature’s back was turned, she and Mabel grabbed Tambry and quickly ferried her into the adjacent room, where they also found Candy and Grenda waiting. “Okay, we’re all here. So what’s the plan, guys?”

Candy poked her head out the hole in the wall. “He seems to like stickers. Maybe we lure him out?”

Dipper dove into the journal. “Okay. It says when fighting a gremloblin to use water…”

Channeling her inner Leeroy Jenkins, Mabel charged out of their hiding spot, unscrewed the lid on her spray bottle, and dumbed the full contents on the monster’s face.

Dipper turned the page. “… only as a last resort, as it will make the creature much scarier? Agh! Who writes sentences like that?”

The gremloblin transformed, almost doubling in size, growing spikes, and gaining the ability to spit fire. Poor coo-coo clock. Luckily, Mabel managed to retreat before it could retaliate. Unluckily, rather than just returning to its cave, the gremloblin became enraptured with a novelty singing salmon and kept pressing the button for hours.

“I think I’m going to start bringing cards to work,” Wendy said to no one. “Like an emergency kit. So next time I’m stuck hiding while some crazy monster is stomping around, at least I won’t be bored.”

“I’m really sorry, guys. This is all my fault,” bemoaned Dipper.

“Hey, don’t beat yourself up, little guy,” Grenda encouraged.

“Yes. If not for you, the monster would have eaten us, instead,” added Candy.

Mabel and Wendy turned as one to face Dipper. “Instead?”

“… I’ve seen things,” Dipper said ominously.

Grenda waved attention back to her. “The point is that we all agreed to this. You had a plan and it worked.”

“You just did not properly account for idiots wearing eyeshadow,” Candy offered helpfully.

“I’m gonna kill Robbie for this.”

“Guys, this is really my fault,” insisted Mabel. “I thought I knew business, but I guess I didn’t. Maybe Stan had a point about being more assertive.”

“Hey, sitting around and feeling sorry for ourselves isn’t going to fix anything,” asserted Wendy. “And as fun as it sounds to just lie around all day and wait for that thing to eat Stan, I say we show what we’re made of and take the fight to the enemy.”

“How?” asked Candy. “He is so much stronger than last time.”

“And I really don’t want to get eaten again.”

“Does that stupid journal really not have anything useful?” demanded Mabel. “Seriously, if I ever meet the guy who wrote it, I’m gonna make him pay for that water line.”

Dipper kept flipping between the same two pages. “No. Just the caramel, migration patterns, water, and the eyes. The guy even underlined the evil eye part.”

Mabel snorted. “I wish we had an evil eye to show him.”

That’s when everyone got the same idea, only to get distracted by Tambry mindlessly laughing at her phone.

“Even if it’s weaker than the real thing, it’s the only plan we’ve got,” asserted Dipper.

Mabel punched her palm. “Alright. Let’s do this.”

The plan was actually pretty simple. As their heavy hitters, Wendy, Mabel, and Grenda would lead the frontal assault. Using rope and anything else they could find, they’d lasso the creature to minimize its movements. Once immobilized, Candy would run up with the mirror. Dipper, mournful that this thing had no weaknesses for him to exploit, was forced to stay back where it was safe. He hated watching everyone else put themselves in danger. In fact, just as he’d decided to run out there after the gremloblin knocked Candy away, a hand fell around him.

“Hehe. You’re cute,” Tambry said, sounding intoxicated. “Little boy. Little boy, little bum-um-um.”

“Not the time, Tambry. Our friends are in danger!” But she just laughed, still not quite lucid enough to do anything more than text. Dipper got an idea. “Hey, I’ll let you take a selfie with me if you let me go.”

“Okaaay,” Tambry enthused.

Before Dipper knew what was happening, he’d been brought up to the girl’s face. She kissed him, making him blush. Then she opened her mouth and dropped him inside. Luckily she didn’t close her lips. With gooey saliva dripping around him and burrito breath threatening to suffocate him, Dipper turned to the opening and saw the phone pointed at them. Tambry smiled with her tongue out and shot a victory sign. Not knowing what else to do, Dipper forced a smile and tried the same. Satisfied, Tambry took the photo, spat Dipper back out, and he went for the dropped mirror.

The gremloblin looked into its own reflection. Whatevver it saw didn’t drive it mad, but it did send the thing away crying.
1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Managing is Hard

1152111111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It was a long and grueling day for the crew of the Mystery Shack. Not only did they have to repair all the damages, but they had to simultaneously earn the money to pay for it all by running the parts of the Shack that still worked. Mabel finally put her foot down, more or less fully embracing Stan’s usual level of callousness to his workers and customers, and even adopted some of his vocabulary. No more refunds, minimal breaks, and only safe fake attractions from now on. Luckily, Candy and Grenda agreed to stay on board, even after being told they wouldn’t be paid. Apparently fun with friends was its own reward.

Also Soos came back. His memory was fuzzy, but while he was out, he’d been taken in by a wolf pack that seemed to want to raise him as one of their own. At least one of them did. He couldn’t remember much after that, but whatever happened must have been rough, as he was covered in scratches and a couple bites. Otherwise he seemed good as new. It was probably no big deal.

As Tambry was finally deemed well enough to go home where she could be someone else’s problem, she seemed especially fixated on one picture on her phone. Foolishly, she sought to spread the joy by showing it to Mabel and Wendy. Upon seeing Dipper’s uncomfortable expression and location, the pair exchanged knowing looks. Mabel ran distraction, keeping Tambry’s simple state entertained with funny faces while Wendy mercilessly hunted through her friend’s phone and deleted every photo of Dipper she could find. And to spare Tambry Mabel’s wrath, Wendy also kept silent on just how many photos there were.

Without monsters or entitled teens running amok, things actually went remarkably smoothly for the crew. Soos was able to handle most of the repairs with minimal assistance from Grenda where lifting was needed. Candy, once she got her hands on the minizora cleaning equipment, was able to make some tweaks here and there to improve their efficiency under her direction. Wendy stuck behind the counter, almost relieved by the monotony of work after the last couple days.
